title: Cresko Laboratory Procedures and Protocols
text:
How to use this book
This is a Quarto book that contains all of the Procedures and Protocols for the Cresko Laboratory in the Institute of Ecology and Evolution at the University of Oregon.
The book is organized into major section that contain

General Laboratory Protocols or the lab
More detailed Laboratory Protocols
Husbandry protocols for vertebrate animals primarily stickleback and pipefish, but also zebrafish
Husbandry protocols for Daphnia
Bioinformatic protocols including how to get on to Talapas

You can scroll through the book using the index on the left, but also use the search field to find all relevant protocols.
There are also useful appendices at the end, as well as a section for the references cited throughout the book.
This book was written in Markdown using Quarto. To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

text: This section of the book contains general protocols for working in the laboratory.

title: 2  Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
text: Introduction

title: 2  Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes important rules to heed in the lab for your safety and for the safety of others.
Procedure Type: General Lab Safety
Author: Cresko Lab Safety Committee
Date Created: Updated regularly







Warning



All lab members must review and follow these safety guidelines. Failure to comply with safety procedures puts you and others at risk.

title: 2  Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
text:
Required Safety Equipment

Lab coat (when working with hazardous chemicals)
Safety glasses or goggles (for UV work, acids/bases, splash hazards)
Nitrile gloves (standard for most procedures)
Closed-toed shoes (required in laboratory)

title: 2  Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
text:
Emergency Equipment Locations

Safety showers and eyewash stations (see lab map)
Fire extinguishers (see lab map)
First aid kit
Spill cleanup materials

title: 2  Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
text:
Safety Procedures






Important - Emergency Contacts



EMERGENCY CONTACT: Dial 911 first, AND 6-2919 (EHS). Mark Cell 541-505-0006
See Chapter 1 for additional contact information.



Safety Shower, Eyewash, Fire Extinguishers.
Eyewashes must be flushed weekly. Undergraduate research assistants are responsible for flushing the safety showers each week. Each lab member is responsible for knowing the locations of safety showers and fire extinguishers in the lab. Safety showers and fire extinguishers are tested annually by EHS.
Wear a lab coat and closed-toed shoes when working with the following chemicals:

Organics (e.g. phenol/chloroform, Trizol, DNAzol, formaldehyde, formamide, methanol)
Strong acids and bases

Wear eye protection when working with:

UV light (UV opaque glasses/face shield).
Phenol/chloroform, strong acids/bases, and any splash hazard with anything hazardous in it.

Wear safety gloves when working with ANY of the reagents above.
Heed the “one glove rule”: remove one glove when moving between rooms to avoid touching doorknobs with a contaminated glove. Note that glove materials differ in their permeability to different reagents. Standard nitrile gloves are adequate for our lab’s standard procedures. However, if you are planning experiments that involve more dangerous reagents, consult with Luke Sitts at EHS to select appropriate gloves.
Disposal of common hazardous reagents (EHS DISPOSAL: 6-3192)
For detailed waste disposal procedures, see Chapter 5 and Chapter 6.

E. coli plates and recombinant materials: autoclave buckets or EHS biohazard incineration boxes.
E. coli flasks/liquids: bleach, rinse, drain.
Used alcohols, formaldehyde, and kit waste: waste containers under the thermocyclers.
Organic solvents: waste bottles in hood.







Warning



All hazardous waste containers must be labeled with contents, date, and owner.


Storage of Hazardous Liquids

Store flammables and strong acids in a latched METAL SAFETY CABINET UNDER THE HOOD.

Heating Liquids in the Microwave Oven
Triple check that the cap is very loose or (better) remove it entirely. Re-melting of gels with DNA binding dyes is forbidden.
Bunsen Burners

Triple check that the gas is shut completely off before you leave the bench/hood.
Keep burners far away from any flammable liquids.

Liquid Nitrogen and Dry Ice

Liquid nitrogen and dry ice can cause serious injury. Follow all precautions.


Use only in well ventilated spaces to avoid asphyxiation.
Never store in sealed containers to avoid explosions.
Wear lab coat, gloves, goggles. In case of frostbite or burn, soak affected part in tepid water, seek medical attention.

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text: Introduction

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to clean and decontaminate PCR mats for reuse.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Author: N. Earp
Date Created: 2024

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Materials

Used PCR mats
Container or tray for soaking
Nitrile gloves
Lab coat
Safety glasses

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Solutions

5% bleach solution (diluted from stock bleach)
Tap water
DI water (deionized water)

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Chemical Hazard



Bleach Safety: - Wear nitrile gloves, lab coat, and safety glasses when working with bleach solutions - Work in a well-ventilated area - Never mix bleach with acids or ammonia-containing products - Rinse skin immediately if contact occurs
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Procedure

Put on appropriate PPE (gloves, lab coat, safety glasses).
Place used PCR mats in a container or tray.
Cover PCR mats completely with 5% bleach solution.






Note



Ensure all surfaces of the mats are submerged in the bleach solution for effective decontamination.


Let sit in 5% bleach solution for 15 minutes to decontaminate.
Rinse PCR mats thoroughly with tap water to remove bleach residue.
Rinse PCR mats with DI water for a final rinse.
Lay PCR mats flat on clean paper towels or a drying rack to air dry completely.
Once dry, store cleaned PCR mats in a clean, designated location.

title: 3  Cleaning PCR Mats
text:
Waste Disposal

Dispose of bleach solution down the sink with running water
Discard disposable gloves in regular trash
For hazardous waste disposal guidelines, see Chapter 5

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text: Introduction

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to clean and sterilize pestles used for tissue homogenization.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Author: Cresko Lab
Date Created: 2024

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Materials

Large beaker (or similar vessel for soaking pestles)
Aluminum foil
Autoclave tape
Autoclave (PAC 306D)
Nitrile gloves
Lab coat
Safety glasses

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Solutions

10% bleach solution (diluted from stock bleach)
Tap water
DI water (deionized water)

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Chemical and Heat Hazards



Bleach Safety: - Wear nitrile gloves, lab coat, and safety glasses when working with bleach solutions - Work in a well-ventilated area - Never mix bleach with acids or ammonia-containing products
Autoclave Safety: - Items removed from autoclave will be extremely hot - Allow items to cool completely before handling - Use heat-resistant gloves if items must be moved while warm - Follow autoclave operating procedures
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Procedure

Put on appropriate PPE (gloves, lab coat, safety glasses).
Rinse dirty pestles thoroughly with tap water to remove tissue debris and residue.
Place pestles into a large beaker and fill the beaker with 10% bleach solution, ensuring all pestles are submerged.
Let the pestles sit for 10 minutes to decontaminate.






Note



The 10-minute bleach treatment helps eliminate biological contamination before autoclaving.


Drain the bleach solution and rinse the pestles thoroughly with DI water to remove all bleach residue.
Section the pestles into bunches of 5-10 pestles each.
Wrap each bunch securely in aluminum foil.
Use autoclave tape to seal the foil packages. Write the date on the autoclave tape.
Transport wrapped pestles to the autoclave in room PAC 306D.
Autoclave foil-wrapped pestles using the 25-minute Gravity program.






Important



Allow pestles to cool completely in the autoclave before removing. Hot items can cause burns.


Once cooled, store autoclaved pestles in a clean, dry location until needed.

title: 4  Cleaning Pestles
text:
Waste Disposal

Dispose of bleach solution down the sink with running water
Recycle used aluminum foil if not contaminated, otherwise dispose in regular trash
For hazardous waste disposal guidelines, see Chapter 5

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text: Introduction

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text:
Purpose: This procedure provides a guideline of how to store and get rid of various forms of hazardous waste (HW) that are produced in the Cresko Lab.
Procedure Type: General Lab
Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: July 30, 2022

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text:
Materials

Appropriate waste containers (carboys, bottles, buckets, or EHS-provided containers)
Chemical-resistant labels
Permanent marker
Nitrile gloves (minimum requirement)
Lab coat
Safety glasses
Secondary containment if needed

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text:
Common Hazardous Waste Types

Paraformaldehyde (PFA)
Alcohols (ethanol, methanol, isopropanol)
Organic solvents (phenol, chloroform, formamide)
Trizol and other nucleic acid extraction reagents
Kit waste containing hazardous components
Contaminated solid waste (tips, tubes)

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Hazardous Materials



General Safety: - Always wear appropriate PPE (gloves, lab coat, safety glasses) - Work in a fume hood when handling volatile or toxic chemicals - Never mix incompatible chemicals (e.g., acids with bases, bleach with acids) - Consult Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for specific chemical hazards - Know the location of safety showers, eyewash stations, and spill kits
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.

title: 5  Disposing of Hazardous Waste
text:
Procedure






Important - Labeling Requirements



ALL CONTAINERS USED TO HOUSE HAZARDOUS WASTE MUST BE LABELED WITH: - Contents (specific chemical names, not abbreviations) - Date waste collection started - Owner/Principal Investigator name
Failure to properly label waste may result in non-compliance with EHS regulations.



1. Common Hazardous Waste Streams
Materials: Paraformaldehyde (PFA), alcohols (ethanol, methanol, isopropanol), and common kit waste.
Collection Procedure:

Collect these waste streams separately in appropriately labeled containers






Note



Do not mix different chemical waste streams. Each type of waste should be collected separately.


Small containers can be used for local collection on lab benches
Transfer contents to the designated large carboy for consolidated storage
Ensure the carboy is properly labeled with all required information

Pickup Schedule:

Every two weeks, a lab assistant will assess if waste containers need pickup
If pickup is needed, the lab assistant will initiate a waste pickup request through EHS
Submit requests at: https://safety.uoregon.edu/hazardous-materials
EHS contact for waste disposal: 6-3192



2. Exotic or Highly Hazardous Waste
Materials: Trizol, phenol, chloroform, formamide, and other highly toxic or corrosive materials.

These materials pose significant health risks. Always handle in a fume hood with appropriate PPE.

Collection Procedure:

Before beginning work: Communicate with the lab assistant about:

Storage location for waste (typically in fume hood)
Expected volume of waste
Duration of waste collection period
Specific hazards of materials being used

During work: Collect waste in the designated location

Solid waste (tips, tubes) contaminated with these materials must be collected separately
Liquid waste should be collected in appropriate, chemically-resistant containers
Keep containers in the fume hood to contain vapors

Container requirements:

Use secondary containment for liquid waste
Ensure containers are compatible with waste chemicals
Keep containers closed when not actively adding waste


Pickup Schedule:

Request pickup within two weeks of starting waste collection OR immediately upon completion of experiments, whichever comes first
Do not allow highly hazardous waste to accumulate for extended periods
Submit waste pickup requests at: https://safety.uoregon.edu/hazardous-materials



3. Special Waste Categories
For bacterial waste disposal procedures, see Chapter 6.






Tip



If you are unsure whether a material is hazardous waste or how to dispose of it, contact EHS at 6-3192 or consult with the lab manager.

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text: Introduction
crumbs: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to clean and dispose of bacterial waste (E. coli and other recombinant materials).
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Species: E. coli and recombinant bacterial cultures
Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 8, 2024
Date Updated: 2024







Note



This protocol is specifically for bacterial culture waste. For other types of hazardous waste disposal, see Chapter 5.
crumbs: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text:
Materials

Bacterial waste tubes/flasks
Large carboy labeled ‘Bacterial Waste’ (located next to North side sink)
Graduated cylinder or measuring device (for bleach)
Nitrile gloves
Lab coat
Safety glasses
crumbs: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text:
Solutions

30% Bleach solution (diluted from stock bleach)
DI water (for rinsing)
crumbs: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Biohazard and Chemical Hazard



Biological Safety: - Bacterial cultures and recombinant materials must be properly decontaminated before disposal - Treat all bacterial waste as potentially hazardous - Never pour untreated bacterial waste down the drain
Bleach Safety: - Wear nitrile gloves, lab coat, and safety glasses when working with bleach solutions - Work in a well-ventilated area - 30% bleach is a concentrated solution - handle with care - Rinse skin immediately if contact occurs
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.
crumbs: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal

title: 6  Bacterial Waste Cleaning and Disposal
text:
Procedure

Decontaminating Bacterial Waste

Put on appropriate PPE (gloves, lab coat, safety glasses).
Pour approximately 10-15 mL of 30% bleach solution into each tube containing bacterial waste.






Note



More bleach solution is acceptable if there is a large amount of bacterial waste. Ensure sufficient bleach to effectively decontaminate all material.


Let the bleach solution sit for 3-5 hours, or until the solution becomes clear again.






Tip



The solution becoming clear indicates that the bleach has effectively killed the bacteria. Turbid solutions indicate live bacteria.


Once the solution is clear, pour the bleach and decontaminated bacterial waste into the large carboy labeled ‘Bacterial Waste’ next to the North side sink.
Rinse the empty tubes thoroughly with DI water.
Place cleaned tubes on the shelving units below the kitchen water bath to dry.



Managing the Bacterial Waste Carboy






Important



When the bacterial waste carboy becomes full or every two weeks (whichever comes first): - Contact the lab assistant to arrange for proper disposal - Do not overfill the carboy (leave at least 2 inches of headspace) - Ensure the carboy is properly labeled with contents and date



Monitor the fill level of the bacterial waste carboy regularly.
When the carboy is approximately 80% full, notify the lab assistant.
The lab assistant will coordinate with EHS for proper disposal of the bacterial waste carboy.
For questions about bacterial waste disposal, contact EHS at 6-3192 or see Chapter 5.

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text: Introduction

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to clean and sterilize loading boats used in gel electrophoresis.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Species: N/A
Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 8, 2024
Date Updated: 2024







Note



Loading boats are used to hold DNA samples before loading into agarose gels. Regular cleaning and sterilization prevent cross-contamination between samples.

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Materials

Used loading boats (approximately 2 in x 5 in)
Aluminum foil
Autoclave tape
Autoclave (PAC 306D)
Nitrile gloves (if using bleach solution)

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Solutions

Tap water
DI water (deionized water)
10% bleach solution (optional, for heavily contaminated boats)

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Heat Hazard



Autoclave Safety: - Items removed from autoclave will be extremely hot - Allow items to cool completely before handling - Use heat-resistant gloves if items must be moved while warm - Follow autoclave operating procedures
If using bleach solution for heavily soiled boats: - Wear nitrile gloves - Work in a well-ventilated area - See Chapter 2 for bleach safety guidelines

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Procedure

Cleaning Loading Boats

Rinse dirty loading boats thoroughly with tap water to remove gel debris and sample residue.
Rinse again with DI water for a final rinse.






Note



If loading boats are extremely dirty or contaminated, rinse them in a 10% bleach solution for 10 minutes before rinsing with tap water and DI water. Wear gloves when handling bleach.


Allow loading boats to air dry completely on a clean surface or paper towel.



Sterilizing Loading Boats

Once dry, cover each large loading boat (approximately 2 in x 5 in) completely with aluminum foil.
Use autoclave tape to secure the foil to the loading boat, ensuring a tight seal.






Tip



Write the date on the autoclave tape for tracking when items were sterilized.


Transport wrapped loading boats to the autoclave in room PAC 306D.
Autoclave foil-wrapped loading boats using the 25-minute Gravity program.






Important



Allow loading boats to cool completely in the autoclave before removing. Hot items can cause burns.


Once cooled, store autoclaved loading boats in a clean, dry location until needed.

title: 7  Cleaning Loading Boats
text:
Waste Disposal

Dispose of heavily contaminated loading boats that cannot be cleaned in regular trash
Recycle aluminum foil if not contaminated
If bleach was used, dispose of solution down the sink with running water

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text: Introduction

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to change spill paper (bench covers) in common laboratory areas.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Species: N/A
Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 8, 2024
Date Updated: 2024







Note



Spill paper (also called bench paper or absorbent bench covers) protects work surfaces from chemical spills and contamination. Regular replacement maintains a clean and safe working environment.

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Materials

Roll of spill paper (absorbent bench covers)
Tape (lab tape or masking tape)
Scissors
Nitrile gloves
Paper towels or cleaning cloths
Spray bottle with 70% ethanol or appropriate cleaning solution

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Solutions

70% ethanol (for cleaning surfaces)
DI water (if needed for cleaning)
10% bleach solution (for contaminated surfaces, if needed)

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Contamination Hazard



When handling used spill paper: - Assume all used spill paper may be contaminated with chemicals or biological materials - Always wear nitrile gloves when removing old spill paper - If spill paper is visibly contaminated with hazardous materials, dispose of it according to Chapter 5 procedures - Wash hands thoroughly after completing the procedure
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Procedure

Removing Old Spill Paper

Put on nitrile gloves before handling used spill paper.
Carefully remove old spill paper from the work surface.






Important



Check the condition of the spill paper:

Not contaminated: Place in regular trash
Contaminated with hazardous materials: Dispose in solid waste or follow Chapter 5 procedures
Contaminated with biological materials: Treat as biohazard waste



Inspect the surface where the spill paper was located for any remaining residue or contamination.



Cleaning the Surface

If there is any residue or visible contamination on the surface:

Spray the surface with 70% ethanol (or 10% bleach if biologically contaminated)
Wipe the surface thoroughly with paper towels or a cleaning cloth
Allow the surface to air dry
Dispose of contaminated cleaning materials appropriately

Ensure the surface is clean and dry before applying new spill paper.



Installing New Spill Paper

Measure the work surface to determine the appropriate size of spill paper needed.
Cut out the appropriate-sized piece of spill paper using scissors.






Tip



Cut the spill paper slightly smaller than the work surface to prevent edges from curling up.


Place the spill paper flat on the clean, dry surface with the plastic-coated side facing down and the absorbent paper side facing up.






Note



The plastic side protects the bench surface from spills, while the absorbent paper side faces up to catch any drips or spills.


Tape the edges of the spill paper to the work surface, ensuring the paper lies flat without wrinkles or bubbles.
Smooth out any wrinkles or air pockets to create a flat working surface.

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Maintenance Schedule






Note



Recommended replacement schedule: - Replace spill paper weekly in high-use areas - Replace immediately if visibly contaminated or damaged - Replace after any significant spill

title: 8  Changing Spill Paper
text:
Waste Disposal

Uncontaminated spill paper: Regular trash
Chemically contaminated spill paper: See Chapter 5
Biologically contaminated spill paper: Autoclave or dispose as biohazard waste
Cleaning materials: Dispose according to contamination level

text:

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text: Introduction

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to refill the 20L Nalgene carboy with nanopure water for laboratory use.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 11, 2024







Note



Nanopure water (ultrapure water) is required for many molecular biology procedures to prevent contamination. The lab maintains a 20L carboy for convenient access to this water.

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Materials

20L Nalgene carboy (polycarbonate or HDPE)
Barnstead NANOpure Infinity ultrapure water system (located in PAC 314)
Cart or dolly for transporting heavy carboy (optional)

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Water Quality

Nanopure water specifications:

Resistivity: 18.2 MΩ·cm at 25°C
TOC (Total Organic Carbon): < 5 ppb
Type I ultrapure water quality

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Heavy Object



Lifting Safety: - The 20L carboy when full weighs approximately 20 kg (44 lbs) - Use proper lifting technique to avoid back injury - Use a cart or dolly for transport if available - Get assistance if needed - do not attempt to lift alone if uncomfortable - Ensure the cap is tightly secured before moving to prevent spills
See Chapter 2 for complete laboratory safety guidelines.

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Procedure

Transporting the Carboy

Check if the 20L carboy is empty or nearly empty.
If there is water remaining, empty it or use it before refilling.
Transport the empty 20L carboy to room PAC 314 where the Barnstead NANOpure Infinity machine is located.






Tip



Use a cart or dolly for easier transport of the carboy.





Operating the NANOpure Machine

Position the carboy under the dispensing nozzle of the NANOpure Infinity machine.
Remove the cap from the carboy.
Turn the top dial on the NANOpure machine to “On.”
Press the “Standby” button to activate the system.
Press the “Start/Stop” button to begin dispensing water.






Note



Check the display to ensure water quality is within acceptable limits (resistivity should be 18.2 MΩ·cm). If not, contact lab staff before using the water.


Monitor to ensure that water is flowing continuously into the carboy.
Wait approximately 20 minutes for the carboy to fill completely.






Important



Do not leave the machine unattended for extended periods. Check periodically to prevent overflow.





Shutting Down the Machine

When the carboy is full (filled to the shoulder, not to the very top), press the “Start/Stop” button to stop water flow.
Press the “Standby” button to return the system to standby mode.
Turn the top dial to “Off.”
Replace the cap on the filled carboy and tighten securely.



Returning to the Lab

Carefully transport the filled carboy back to the laboratory.






Warning



The filled carboy is heavy (approximately 20 kg). Use proper lifting technique and/or a cart.


Store the carboy in the designated location in the lab.
Label the carboy with the date filled if not already labeled.

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Troubleshooting






Tip - Common Issues



If water quality is poor (resistivity below 18.2 MΩ·cm): - Check if filters or purification cartridges need replacement - Contact lab manager or EHS
If machine does not dispense: - Check that machine is properly turned on - Check water supply connection - Contact lab manager if issue persists

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Maintenance Notes

The NANOpure system is maintained by facility staff
Report any issues with water quality or machine function to the lab manager
Check water quality reading on display before filling

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Related Protocols

title: 9  Refilling Nanopure Water
text:
Additional Resources

Barnstead NANOpure Infinity User Manual (contact lab manager for access)

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text: Introduction

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to clean, refill, and sterilize pipette tip boxes for laboratory use.
Procedure Type: General Lab Maintenance
Author: Cresko Lab
Date Created: 2024







Note



This protocol covers both filtered and non-filtered pipette tips in 20 µL, 200 µL, and 1000 µL sizes. Proper sterilization of tip boxes prevents contamination of sensitive molecular biology experiments.

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Materials

Used/empty pipette tip boxes (20 µL, 200 µL, 1000 µL)
Autoclave (located in PAC 306D)
Autoclave tape
Pipette tip refills (available in lab stock)
Permanent marker for labeling

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Tip Box Types

Non-filtered tips: Standard tips for general use, can be autoclaved
Filtered tips: Barrier tips to prevent aerosol contamination, CANNOT be autoclaved (see warning below)

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Safety Precautions






Warning - Heat Hazard



Autoclave Safety: - Items removed from autoclave will be extremely hot (121°C) - Allow autoclaved boxes to cool completely before handling - Do not open autoclave until pressure has completely released - Use heat-resistant gloves if boxes must be moved while warm - Condensation on boxes indicates they are still hot - allow more cooling time
See Chapter 2 for complete autoclave safety guidelines.



CRITICAL: DO NOT autoclave filter tips or filter tip boxes. The heat will damage the filters and compromise their function. Filter tips are purchased pre-sterilized and should be used directly from the manufacturer’s packaging.

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Procedure

Preparing Empty Tip Boxes (Non-Filtered Tips Only)

Remove all autoclave tape from used pipette tip boxes.
Remove and recycle the inner cartridge:

For 20 µL and 1000 µL boxes: Remove entire inner cartridge
For 200 µL boxes: Remove only the thin removable portion

Ensure boxes are empty and clean. If contaminated, rinse with DI water and allow to dry completely before proceeding.



Autoclaving Empty Boxes (Non-Filtered Tips Only)

Close the lids on the empty tip boxes.
Seal boxes with autoclave tape:

For 20 µL boxes: Tape front side only
For 200 µL boxes: Tape both front and back sides
For 1000 µL boxes: Tape front side only







Tip



Write the date on the autoclave tape to track when boxes were sterilized.


Transport sealed boxes to the autoclave in room PAC 306D.
Load boxes into the autoclave and run the Gravity cycle for 25 minutes at 121°C.






Note



Autoclave cycle selector (for reference):

1 = OK (cycle complete, safe to remove)
4 = Back (cycle in progress or failed, do not open)



After the autoclave cycle completes, allow boxes to cool completely in the autoclave.






Important



Wait until there is NO visible condensation on the boxes before removing them. This typically takes 30-60 minutes. Hot boxes can cause burns and condensation can contaminate sterile tips.





Refilling Non-Filtered Tips (Previously Autoclaved Boxes)

Once boxes are completely cool and dry, proceed to refill with tips.


For 20 µL and 1000 µL Tips:

Remove the lid from the autoclaved box.
Remove the paper backing from the bottom of the new tip refill.
Position the new tips on top of the empty tip box, ensuring proper alignment.
Slightly push inward on the edges of the tip refill to ensure the tabs fit properly inside the box.
Press down firmly on one side of the tips until they snap into place.
Repeat for the other side until the tips are fully seated in the box.
Remove the plastic protective covering from the top of the tips.
Replace the lid on the box.



For 200 µL Tips:

Remove the lid from the autoclaved box.
Remove the paper backing from the bottom of the new tip refill.
Position the new tips on top of the empty tip box, ensuring proper alignment.
Press down firmly until the tips snap into place.
Remove the plastic protective covering from the top of the tips.
Replace the lid on the box.




Refilling Filter Tips (No Autoclaving Required)

For filter tips, use pre-sterilized boxes directly from the manufacturer.






Important



Filter tips come pre-sterilized. When the box is empty:

Recycle the empty box (do NOT autoclave)
Use a new pre-sterilized filter tip box from lab stock
Mark the box with “FILTER” if not already labeled






Labeling and Storage

Label all refilled boxes appropriately:

Non-filtered tips: Can be labeled with date of sterilization
Filter tips: Mark clearly as “FILTER” to prevent accidental autoclaving

Store refilled tip boxes in a clean, dry location until needed.

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Waste Disposal

Empty tip boxes (if not being reused): Recycle plastic
Used filter tip boxes: Recycle (do not autoclave)
Paper backing from tip refills: Recycle
Plastic covering from tip refills: Regular trash

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Related Protocols

Chapter 2 - Cresko Lab Safety Highlights
Chapter 4 - Cleaning Pestles (autoclave procedures)
Chapter 7 - Cleaning Loading Boats (autoclave procedures)

title: 10  Refilling Pipette Tips
text:
Troubleshooting






Tip - Common Issues



Tips don’t fit properly in box: - Ensure you’re using the correct size refill for the box - Check that the box is completely dry before inserting tips - Verify proper alignment before pressing down
Condensation on autoclaved boxes: - Allow more cooling time in the autoclave - Do not refill boxes until completely dry to prevent contamination
Filter tips accidentally autoclaved: - Discard the entire box of tips - the filters are compromised - Use new pre-sterilized filter tips

title: Molecular Protocols
text: This section of the book contains common protocols used for molecular biology and genomics in the laboratory. These include standard protocols such as setting up creating reagents, setting up PCRs and running gels, as well as advanced protocols such as creating constructs.

title: 11  PCR with Phusion
text:
Introduction
The following guidelines are provided to ensure successful PCR using Phusion® DNA Polymerase. These guidelines cover routine PCR. Amplification of templates with high GC content, high secondary structure, low template concentrations or long amplicons may require further optimization.
We recommend assembling all reaction components on ice and quickly transferring the reactions to a thermocycler preheated to the denaturation temperature (98°C). All components should be mixed and centrifuged prior to use. It is important to add Phusion DNA Polymerase last in order to prevent any primer degradation caused by the 3´→ 5´ exonuclease activity.
Phusion DNA Polymerase may be diluted in 1X HF or GC Buffer just prior to use in order to reduce pipetting errors. Please note that protocols with Phusion DNA Polymerase may differ from protocols with other standard polymerases. As such, conditions recommended below should be used for optimal performance.

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to pour and run a gel to visualize DNA.
Procedure Type: Molecular
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: February 14, 2024







Safety



Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):

Lab coat
Safety glasses or UV-protective eyewear when viewing gels
Heat-resistant gloves when handling hot agarose
Nitrile gloves for all steps

Chemical Safety:

Ethidium bromide alternative (Safe View) binds DNA and may be mutagenic; handle with care
Hot agarose can cause severe burns; use heat-resistant gloves
UV light exposure can damage eyes and skin; use protective equipment when imaging
TBE buffer contains borate; avoid skin contact

Electrical Safety:

Always turn off power supply before connecting or disconnecting electrodes
Never reach into gel box while power is on
Ensure gel box is on a dry, stable surface
crumbs: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Background
Gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate mixtures of DNA, RNA, or proteins based on their molecular size. During gel electrophoresis, an electrical field is used to help molecules travel through the pores of an agarose gel matrix. At one end of the gel, furthest away from where the samples are loaded, is a positive charge, and at the other end is a negative charge. Since DNA and RNA are both negatively charged molecules, they are pulled through the gel matrix towards the positive charge. Since proteins do not have a negative charge, researchers must first mix them with a sodium dodecyl sulfate detergent which gives them the negative charge needed to migrate towards the positive end of the gel. The speed at which molecules travel through the gel is inversely related to their molecular size. For example, small DNA molecules have a low molecular weight, enabling them to travel further through the gel matrix than a larger DNA molecule. When a gel is stained with DNA/RNA/protein-binding dye, these molecules can be seen as bands, whose location along the length of the gel represents the molecule?s size in terms of number of base pairs. When dye-stained DNA/RNA/protein is run beside a ladder with known fragment size, one can estimate the size of the assayed molecule. After the DNA/RNA/protein molecules have been separated using gel electrophoresis, the gel is imaged under UV light, visualizing the DNA/RNA/proteins present across the length of the gel.
crumbs: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:

500 ml Corning glass bottle labeled “Agarose Gels”
Scale
Weigh paper
Microwave

Gel tray
Pipets
Pipet tips

Gel box with enough buffer inside to cover gel
Electrodes attached to power supply (Bio-Rad PowerPac)
Gel transferring tray
Device for visualizing gel

Azure Biosystems c200, located in Pacific 314

Gel image printer
Kimwipes

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Solutions

0.5X TBE
Safe View
Molecular Biology Grade Agarose
6X Loading Dye
Ladder of choice
EB Buffer
crumbs: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 20 for size selection using gel extraction
crumbs: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Procedure






Important



Before beginning this procedure, read the section “Electrophoresis Tips” at the bottom of this procedure for more background information and to understand and anticipate the mistakes commonly associated with this protocol.



Weigh desired amount of Molecular Biology Grade Agarose - scale, weigh paper, and Agarose located on the common use bench on the north end of the laboratory - and pour it into the 500 ml Corning glass bottle labeled “Agarose Gels” (located on top of or inside the microwave on the south end of the laboratory).

1-1.2% Agarose (1 g-1.2 g) is a good starting amount of Agarose for DNA samples, though the amount of Agarose can vary depending on your particular samples and goals. The concentration of Agarose in a gel depends on the sizes of DNA fragments to be separated, with most gels ranging between 0.5%-2% Agarose.

Fill bottle with 0.5X TBE buffer, located in the 20-liter Nalgene located at the south sink. The volume of TBE buffer used will be based on the size of the gel mold. For example, for a 14”x10” gel tray, use 100 ml of 0.5X TBE buffer. 3. Put bottle in microwave and microwave for one minute.
Using the heat mittens located on top of the microwave, remove the bottle from the microwave, swirl the mixture around, and put it back in the microwave for 30 seconds. By the end of this step, the Agarose should be melted into the TBE and there should be no remaining solid Agarose particles.
Using the heat mittens, remove the bottle from the microwave and carry it to the fume hood.
Select a gel tray from the drawer under the gel boxes. Put tape around the two longest sides of the gel tray, pressing tape on firmly so it is air-tight with the tray. The distance between the top of the tape and the bottom of the tray should be at least half-an-inch tall so that it can hold all of the liquid from the Agarose Gel bottle without it spilling over the sides or leaking through any air gaps in the tape.
Select a gel comb from the drawer under the gel boxes. Different combs make different sized wells that can hold different volumes, so select a comb based on your specific experiment. Place the gel comb in the notches of the gel tray. The combs should not touch the bottom of the tray but be slightly above it.
Let the agarose solution cool for a few minutes. Using the heat mittens, swirl the Agarose Gel bottle again. Add 5 ul of Safe View (located in the Styrofoam box in the fume hood) to the Agarose Gel bottle. Gently swirl the bottle to mix in the Safe View; try to avoid creating bubbles while swirling.
Slowly pour the Agarose Gel mixture into the gel tray with gel comb. Be careful not to create bubbles in the gel mixture while pouring. If there are bubbles, pop or move them to the bottom of the tray, away from the comb. Slowly lift the comb up and down a few times to ensure there are no bubbles around the comb.
Let the gel mixture sit in the tray under the hood until it solidifies (usually takes around 20 minutes).
While you are waiting for the gel to solidify, clean the Agarose Gel bottle. Fill the bottle halfway with water, swirl the water, microwave for 30 seconds, swirl again and microwave for another 30 seconds. Pour out the water and set the bottle out to dry next to the microwave.
Once the agarose mixture has solidified, carefully remove the tape from the sides of the tray.






Important



Tape should be removed from the tray while held under the fume hood. Tape should be removed slowly to prevent any splattering of residual liquid on the top of the solidified gel.


Carefully remove the comb from the gel matrix by slowly pulling it straight up.
Carry the gel in the gel plate to the gel boxes, remove gel box lid, and slowly lower the gel and plate into gel boxes.
Load ladder of choice into the left-most well of the gel. The volume of ladder you load will vary depending on your experiment.






Important



When expelling the ladder into the well, only pipet to the first stop. Pipetting to the second stop risks expelling bubbles into the well which could interfere with the experiment.








Notes



The ladder is made of DNA and needs a gel loading dye. When selecting a ladder to use, make sure that the ladder is not clear but has been mixed with a loading dye (should be a bright color like blue, orange, green, or purple).


Prepare DNA samples to be loaded into the wells of the gel. Pipet out 10 ul of DNA from each sample onto a piece of parafilm or into a PCR strip tube, using a fresh pipet tip for each sample to avoid cross contamination.






Notes



The volume of DNA you mix load into each well depends on the concentration of DNA and how much of DNA of your total you can afford to use for the gel, though a generally good concentration range is 10-100 ng/ul to ensure the DNA can be visualized on the gel. If you are aiming to load a specific concentration of DNA into each well, calculate the concentration of your DNA sample and find that the corresponding volume is less than 10 ul, you can add the appropriate volume of EB Buffer to bring the sample’s volume up to 10 ul.


Add 2 ul of 6X Loading Dye to each DNA sample. Thoroughly mix the dye and DNA sample by aspiration, but mix slowly to avoid creating bubbles. Be sure to use a fresh pipet tip in between DNA samples.






Notes



*The exact volume of loading dye you add to each sample can change depending on the amount of DNA you add, but the final dilution should be 1 part 6X Loading Dye to 5 parts DNA sample.


Load 10 ul of the DNA sample/dye mixture into the next available well in the gel.






Important



When expelling the DNA sample/dye mixture into the well, only pipet to the first stop. Pipetting to the second stop risks expelling bubbles into the well which could interfere with the experiment.


Put gel box cover on. Attach the electrodes to the metal posts at the top and bottom of gel box; the black electrode (-) attaches to the metal post on the top of the box and the red electrode (+) attaches to the metal post on the bottom of the box.






Notes



Since DNA is a negatively charged molecule, it will run through the gel matrix towards a positive charge. A helpful way to remember electrode placement, then, is “Run to red,” since the red electrode has a positive charge and should be placed furthest away from the DNA samples.


Turn on the Bio-Rad PowerPac and set it to your desired voltage. Press “Run.” You can check to see if an electric current is running through the gel box by looking for a stream of small bubbles rising up the back of the gel box.
Run samples for desired time.
Press the “Stop” button on the Bio-Rad PowerPac and turn off the power. Remove the electrodes from either end of the gel box, loosely wind them up and place them above or next to the Bio-Rad PowerPac.
Remove the lid from the gel box. Carefully lift the gel tray out of the gel box, ensuring that the gel does not slide off the tray. Place the gel tray and gel onto the gel transferring tray (located behind the faucet on the south sink). Carry the gel to the gel imaging station (Azure Biosystems c200) in the Phillips Microfluidics Laboratory (Pacific 314).
To image the gel,

Open the door of the c200 Azure Biosystems gel imaging station, and carefully slide the gel inside. The long side of the gel should be facing the opening of the imaging station. Position the gel so that it is centered inside the imaging platform, and the short sides of the gel are parallel to the sides of the imaging platform. Close the door.
Select the “cSeries Capture Software” on the screen.
Select the “GEL” option in the top left corner, to the right of the “GALLERY” option.
Select the “BRIGHT BANDS” option in the bottom right corner.
Select “CAPTURE” to take an image of the gel.
Once your image has been captured, you may rotate, flip, crop, or zoom in/out of the image.
To print the image, select “PRINT” and choose the number of copies you would like to print.

Open the door of the c200 Azure Biosystems gel imaging station and carefully remove the gel. Wipe down the gel platform using a Kimwipe and close the door.
Carry your gel and printed images back to the lab. You may either dispose of your gel in the trash or store the gel in a plastic bag in the refrigerator for future use.
Rise off the gel transferring tray and set it to dry behind the south sink faucets. Rinse off the gel tray and the gel comb, ensuring that there is no remaining agarose between the tines of the gel comb. Set the comb and the tray to dry on the drying rack hanging above the south sink.
crumbs: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel

title: 13  Pouring and Running a Gel
text:
Electrophoresis Tips
Background
The effect of electrophoresis is to separate DNA fragments by size in an agarose matrix and buffer using an electrical current. DNA is negatively charged and will migrate toward the positive pole. Many parameters can affect how the DNA moves through the gel: buffer composition, voltage, length of the gel, percentage of agarose in the gel (in other words, the density of the gel matrix), presence of salt in the DNA, protein bound to DNA, and other factors. Some of these conditions also affect which size ranges of DNA will effectively be “resolved” (i.e., separated enough from one another so you can see them as distinct fragment sizes). “Safeview” is a dye we use in the gel that fluoresces under UV or blue light when bound to DNA, allowing us to see and photograph it when viewed through a special orange filter to cut out the background light. The research goals of using electrophoresis might include:

measuring the size of fragments in a DNA sample such as the products of PCR or assessing the intactness of the purified DNA from a tissue extraction
separating fragments from one another so that a particular amplicon or size range of DNA can be purified out of the gel for other downstream applications (such as for cloning a PCR fragment for making probes or for Sanger sequencing, or for size selecting a smear of fragments for making a RAD library) while excluding the other fragment sizes
checking for the presence or absence of a particular product of PCR as in a screen for orientation of a cloned fragment in a plasmid present in different bacterial colonies, a screen for an insertion in a transgenic animal, a screen to determine the genetic sex or the mitotype of a fish.

Common Mistakes

Boiling over the agarose when making a gel. Result: failure to monitor the agarose when you are trying to dissolve it in the microwave can easily cause it to boil over because powdered substances create a lot of “nodes of nucleation” for bubbles to form. This is especially easy to accidentally do with higher percentages of agarose. It wastes expensive agarose and creates a mess in the microwave. What remains in the bottle will be of an indeterminate percentage/gel stiffness.
Not making sure the tape is adhering well to the mold before casting a gel. Result: liquid agarose will leak out causing a mess and reagent waste. Make sure the mold is dry beforehand, and use the back edge of a comb, e.g., to run across the tape and make sure it has firm contact.
Positioning the comb teeth too close to one side or to the bottom of the mold when setting up for pouring a gel. Result: the bottoms (or that side) of wells may be torn when the comb is pulled out, causing the loaded samples to leak out into the buffer during gel loading.






Note



Even when the comb teeth are not too close to the bottom, low percentage gels are soft and will benefit from having the comb pulled while submerged in the tank - otherwise the suction created by surface tension between the comb plastic and the agarose as you pull up on the comb can tear the bottoms out of the wells, causing loss of samples during loading.


Not using the right % of agarose for your DNA size range of interest. Result: bands you care about won’t resolve optimally (i.e., you might not be able to accurately measure the sizes of your bands and might not be able to tell if something is one band or multiple bands). Pour a higher percentage gel to resolve large fragments (e.g. less than 1%) or a lower percentage gel (i.e. between 1 and 4%) to resolve small to very small ones, depending on your needs/expectations for what size bands you will see, how many of them, or how important it is to accurately estimate their sizes.
Not homogeneously mixing the Safeview into the agarose before pouring. Result: DNA might not be visible in all parts of the gel.
Over-cooling the agarose before pouring. Result: Safeview will not be evenly distributed in the gel, and/or the gel will have lumps and not be of uniform thickness because some of the agarose will have already started polymerizing.
Running a gel with a lot of bubbles in it. Result: DNA migration can be impeded/distorted by bubbles in the gel. Usually as a gel is cooling, bubbles will migrate to the top where (usually) they will be out of the path of the DNA unless the DNA volume fills the wells to the top. But bubbles can sometimes occur deeper in the gel – particularly in a very high % agarose gel. Try to nudge bubbles out of the way before the gel solidifies, either by raking them with a comb that is not on a holder or nudging individual bubbles with a pipette tip before the gel congeals. If the gel is already solid, avoid loading in lanes that will run across a bubble.
Running a gel that wasn’t mixed homogeneously before pouring in the mold. Result: there will be lumps in the gel of more dense agarose that will cause distortion of how the DNA migrates.
Accidentally contacting the agarose with a pipette tip. Result: the bottom or side of the well can become perforated, causing the sample to leak out the bottom or into the next well. If the tip is pressed against the agarose, the sample can be forcefully and suddenly expelled and blast out of the well.
Overloading the wells with too much sample volume. Result: samples can become cross-contaminated by DNA from adjacent wells.
Overloading the lane with too much DNA. Result: DNA can become retarded during running and the apparent size will not be accurately gauged by the ladder.
Forgetting to load a DNA ladder. Result: you won’t know if your DNA bands are the right size when you look at and photograph your gel.
Not adjusting the amount of ladder for the comb width. Result: if you use a wider comb, you need to increase the amount of ladder or it will appear dimmer (because ladder DNA is more dilute across the span of the lane).
Not using gel loading mix in the DNA or using ladder that isn’t premixed with gel loading mix. The DNA or ladder (which is also DNA) will be lost mostly during loading without the gel loading mix that makes it sink to the bottom of the wells in the gel and stay there while you are loading. Both your samples and the ladder are DNA in an aqueous solution that is about the same density as the buffer (usually) – therefore they both should have gel loading mix in them in order to be denser than the tank buffer. The gel loading mix also includes convenient, charged dyes that migrate at different rates to help you see that your gel is running and how far it has progressed. The gel loading mix types only really matter if one type happens to have a dye that migrates exactly like your band of interest - in that case, you may want to switch to a different mix so that the dye doesn’t block the fluorescence of your band during visualization.
Not thoroughly mixing gel loading mix into your DNA before loading. Result: you could lose part of your DNA to floating out of the well during loading. (This can also happen if there are other reasons your DNA is not very dense, such as if there is residual ethanol in it from preceding processing. In that case, you will see your DNA rapidly floating up to the surface as soon as you start expelling it from the tip).
Adding premixed DNA ladder to your samples instead of gel loading mix. Result: ladder will appear in every lane, obscuring your bands and wasting expensive ladder.
Forgetting to start the current on your loaded gel. Result: DNA will diffuse both out of the wells and into the gel in all directions causing loss of some of the DNA and blurriness of the remaining DNA once the gel is run. Diffusion can also happen if it takes a long time to load the gel. If there are a great number of samples to load – such as in a two- or three-comb gel, it is often best to load one tier and run the gel for 5 minutes so the DNA enters the gel and diffuses more slowly before moving on to load the next tier. Diffusion can happen more quickly if the buffer is warm from a previous run. If the buffer is warm, replace it before trying to load another gel in the same box.
Not keeping track of the order of sample loading. Result: you won’t know which lane corresponds to which sample. This can happen, for example, when loading samples from a strip of PCR tubes, where their order can accidentally be rotated 180 degrees, or when loading from a PCR plate, where the plate orientation can be rotated 180 or 90 degrees (e.g., wells are loaded with respect to rows versus columns).
Running your gel backwards by accidentally reversing the positive and negative electrodes. Result, your DNA will migrate out of the end of the gel nearest the wells (the “top” of the gel) and be lost into the tank buffer. Always check that your electrodes are hooked up to the correct leads relative to the terminals at the power source, that your gel is oriented so that the DNA will run toward the positive pole. If you have already loaded your gel in the wrong orientation, do not lift the gel out of the tank, but just reverse the leads (red to black) to correct the current. Remember that DNA is negatively charged and will run to the positive (red) pole. When you start the current, the negative electrode (anode) at the well end of the gel should be making noticeably more bubbles than the positive electrode (cathode) at the bottom end of the gel. That’s because electrolysis of water (H2O) will produce twice as much free hydrogen at the anode than the cathode makes free oxygen. Making a habit of checking that tells you two things: that current is really flowing and that you do have the right orientation of poles.
Running a gel at too low a voltage. Result: low molecular weight bands may look fuzzy and faint because they will be diffusing in random directions as they migrate.
Running DNA that is too salty - e.g., DNA in Phusion buffer or in NEB restriction buffer 3 (or 3.1) etc. Result: a “salt front” will form where DNA in those salty buffers will be slowed (“retarded”) relative to the ladder, making the ladder a useless measure of the actual size of the DNA. Bands will be compressed at a “front” and will be a weird shape like a smile or a frown rather than a straight band. If you know your DNA is in a salty buffer, you can remove this problem by cleaning the DNA first (i.e., via a cleanup column or with paramagnetic beads), or you can mitigate the problem by diluting only a few microliters (e.g. 5 µl) of your DNA into water and gel loading mix before loading (assuming you have a high enough concentration of DNA that it can still be seen if you load only a small fraction of it).
Running a gel made up in a different buffer (or different concentration of buffer) than the buffer in the gel tank; this includes using old buffer that has been evaporating in the tank through multiple runs or over time. Result: bands will not migrate as expected. “Fronts” may form where the leading edge of the migrating DNA is compressed.
Losing your gel off the end of the gel mold/gel sliding off the end of the gel mold when you are taking it out of the gel box. Result: the gel could shatter and be unsalvageable. Solution: transport gels in a dish and be especially careful when moving flabby, low percentage agarose gels (under 1%).

Potentially Dangerous and/or Destructive Mistakes

Heating a bottle with a lid on it. Result: possible explosion. Just leave the lid off when heating agarose.
Adding Safeview to molten agarose that is too hot. Result: much of the Safeview will be degraded by heat, causing your DNA to be hard to see or image. The plastic gel mold could be permanently warped if the agarose is too hot. The tape may fail, causing a mess in the fume hood and reagent wastage. A swirled bottle should be just comfortable (70°C or a bit less).
Running a gel at too high a voltage. Result: buffer could overheat during running and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box. Bands might look smear and not be well resolved.
Dissolving agarose in water instead of electrophoresis buffer or putting water in the electrophoresis tank instead of buffer. Result - total failure for DNA to migrate into the gel, loss of samples. If there is only water and not buffer in the tank, it could overheat and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box.
Over-running your gel. Result: the DNA might run off the bottom of the gel and be lost. If you had more than one tier of wells in the gel, the DNA in the top tier will run into the zone of the next tier down, causing distortion and blurriness of the bands as they cross the wells of the lower tier and creating confusion in interpretation because very small fragments from the top tier will be overlapping very large fragments of the lower tier. If the gel runs for a long time, the buffer could overheat and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box.

Conscientiousness
Please really clean the gel molds and combs after use. The next person shouldn’t have to fish another lab mate’s combs and molds out of the sink and clean and dry them before they can pour their gel. After pulling combs from a polymerized gel, make sure to really rub them under a flow of water; a skin of polymerized agarose left on the combs (higher percentages of agarose are especially prone to this) will mean the next person has to clean this off before they can pour a gel. Likewise, make sure the gel melting bottle is rinsed immediately after you pour your gel. If residual agarose is allowed to dry in the bottle, it can create an almost insoluble blob in the gel of the next person to use the bottle. If you see that some of your agarose has polymerized in the bottle, add water to the bottle and microwave it for a few minutes to dissolve and discard the residue.

title: 14  cDNA Synthesis for PCR

Purpose: This procedure describes how to synthesize cDNA for use with PCR.
Procedure Type: Molecular
Author: Susie Bassham
Date Created: July 2011







Safety



Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):

Lab coat
Safety glasses
Nitrile gloves

Chemical Safety:

Handle DTT with care; it is an irritant and has a strong odor
Work in a well-ventilated area
RNase-free technique required; wear gloves at all times

title: 14  cDNA Synthesis for PCR
text:
Materials

Thermal cycler or heat block
Ice
Microcentrifuge tubes (RNase-free)
Pipettes and RNase-free tips

title: 14  cDNA Synthesis for PCR
text:
Solutions

2 µl Oligo d(T)23 VN (50 µM, NEB; anchored-dT primer)
X µl up to 5 µg total RNA
1 µl 10 mM dNTP mix
Nuclease-free water
2 µl 10x RT buffer (Invitrogen)
4 µl 25 mM MgCl2
2 µl 0.1 M DTT (Invitrogen)
1 µl RNase inhibitor, e.g., RNAseOUT (Invitrogen)
1 µl Superscript III reverse transcriptase (200 u/µl, Invitrogen)

title: 14  cDNA Synthesis for PCR
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 11 for using cDNA as PCR template
See Chapter 15 for double-stranded cDNA synthesis

title: 14  cDNA Synthesis for PCR
text:
Procedure

First strand synthesis

Combine:

2 µl Oligo d(T)23 VN (50 µM, NEB; anchored-dT primer)*
X µl up to 5 µg total RNA
1 µl 10 mM dNTP mix
Water (if necessary) to bring total to 10 µl







Note



Recommend using Oligo d(T)23 VN if starting with total RNA to bias cDNA to messenger RNA. Random Primer Mix will do a better job of covering 5’ ends if starting with mRNA. If the RNA is degraded or if very long sequences are required, may instead use 2 µl Random Primer Mix (60 µM, NEB; a mix of random hexamers, anchored-dT primers, and 1 mM dNTPs).



Heat to 65°C for 5 min., then place on ice
Collect contents at bottom of tube by brief centrifugation.
Add:

2 µl 10x RT buffer (Invitrogen)
4 µl 25 mM MgCl2
2 µl 0.1 M DTT (Invitrogen)
1 µl RNase inhibitor, e.g., RNAseOUT (Invitrogen)
1 µl Superscript III reverse transcriptase (200 u/µl, Invitrogen)







Note



Reaction can be scaled up to accommodate more starting RNA.


Mix by gentle aspiration
Incubate at 25°C for 5 min.
Synthesis: Incubate at 50°C for 50 min.
Inactivation: Heat to 85°C for 5 min. Chill on ice, collect contents to bottom by short spin.
Destroy RNA template: Add 1 µl RNase H (2 u/µl), incubate at 37°C for 20 min.
Proceed to PCR (see Chapter 11). Depending on expression level, may be able to use a dilution of cDNA as template – try 1:50 dilution in EB, use 2 µl as template in a 20 µl reaction. Don’t dilute your entire amount of cDNA, as some products may require a higher concentration of template.







Storage



cDNA can be stored at -20°C for several months or at -80°C for long-term storage.

title: 15  Double Stranded cDNA Synthesis
text:
Solutions

Random Primer Mix (60 µM, NEB)
10 mM dNTP mix
mRNA
Nuclease-free water
5x First-Strand Buffer (Invitrogen)
0.1 M DTT (Invitrogen)
RNase inhibitor, e.g., RNAseOUT (Invitrogen)
Superscript III reverse transcriptase (200 u/µl, Invitrogen)
10x Second-Strand Synthesis Reaction Buffer (B6117S, NEB)
E. coli ligase (10 u/µl)
E. coli DNA Polymerase I (10 u/µl)
E. coli RNase H (5 u/µl)
T4 DNA polymerase (3 u/µl, NEB)
0.5 M EDTA

title: 15  Double Stranded cDNA Synthesis
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 14 for single-stranded cDNA synthesis
See Chapter 16 for using double-stranded cDNA in eRAD protocols
See Chapter 18 for DNA cleanup with Zymo columns

title: 15  Double Stranded cDNA Synthesis
text:
Procedure

First strand synthesis

Combine:

2 µl Random Primer Mix (60 µM, NEB; a mix of random hexamers, anchored-dT primers, and 1 mM dNTPs)*
0.8 µl 10 mM dNTP mix
X µl up to 0.5 µg mRNA
Water (if necessary) to bring total to 12 µl







Note



Random Primer Mix should do a better job of covering 5’ and 3’ ends than Oligo d(T) or random hexamer primers alone.


Heat to 65°C for 5 min., then place on ice
Collect contents at bottom of tube by brief centrifugation.
Add:

4 µl 5x First-Strand Buffer (Invitrogen)
1 µl 0.1 M DTT (Invitrogen)
1 µl RNase inhibitor, e.g., RNAseOUT (Invitrogen)
1 µl Superscript III reverse transcriptase (200 u/µl, Invitrogen)







Note



Reaction can be scaled up to accommodate more starting RNA.


Mix by gentle aspiration
Incubate at 25°C for 10 min.
Synthesis: Incubate at 50°C for 50 min.
Inactivation: Heat to 85°C for 5 min. Chill on ice, collect contents to bottom by short spin.

Second strand synthesis:

On ice, add:

106.6 µl water
15 µl 10x Second-Strand Synthesis Reaction Buffer (B6117S, NEB)
3 µl 10 mM dNTPs
1 µl E. coli ligase (10 u/µl)
4 µl E. coli DNA Polymerase I (10 u/µl)
0.4 µl E. coli RNase H (5 u/µl)

Mix by aspiration on ice.
Synthesis: Incubate at 16°C for 2 hours (do not allow to warm above 16°C).

Optional (for cloning cDNAs, required to blunt ends):

Add 3.3 µl (10 u) T4 DNA polymerase (3 u/µl, NEB). Incubate 5 min. at 16°C.
Add 10 µl 0.5 M EDTA to stop reaction.

Purify with Zymo DNA column (see Chapter 18):

Elute two times with 50 µl EB and proceed to shearing and adaptor ligation for EST building or expression profiling via Illumina sequencing, OR,
Elute two times with 20 µl EB and proceed to restriction digestion for eRAD (see Chapter 16).








Storage



Double-stranded cDNA can be stored at -20°C for several months or at -80°C for long-term storage.

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text: Introduction

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to concentrate DNA or to clean DNA using magnetic beads. You might use this to elute the DNA from a larger volume to a smaller one, or to remove oligo DNA such as primers, remove very short fragments of DNA, remove salts and other soluble impurities, or to change the buffer type the DNA is dissolved in (e.g., TE, AE, or EB).
Procedure Type: Molecular
Species:
Author: Susan Bassham
Date Created: November 27, 2023
Date Updated: November 27, 2023







Safety



Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):

Lab coat
Safety glasses
Nitrile gloves

Chemical Safety:

Ethanol is flammable; keep away from open flames
Work in a well-ventilated area when handling ethanol

Magnetic Safety:

Do not use magnets if you have a pacemaker
Keep magnets away from electronic devices (laptops, cell phones, etc.)
Magnets can pinch skin; handle carefully

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Materials

DNAse-free tubes, such as microcentrifuge tubes, PCR strip tubes, or plates
Magnet (for 1.5 ml tubes, use Invitrogen DynaMag-Spin Magnetic Particle Concentrator; for PCR plate or strip tubes, use DynaMag-96 Slide magnet or Catalyst 96 Slotted Ring Magnet Plate)






Important



Do not use magnets if you have a pacemaker. Do not use these powerful magnets near electronic devices like laptops or cell phones.


Pipettes
Pipette tips

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Solutions

DNA in solution
Omega Tech paramagnetic beads (we buy through GC3F, our sequencing Core facility)
80% ethanol
Elution buffer of choice for re-elution (e.g., EB, TE, or AE)

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 18 for DNA extraction from tissue using beads
See Chapter 11 for PCR after DNA cleanup
See Chapter 20 for using cleaned DNA in library preparation

title: 17  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Procedure

Determine the volume of beads you need to add based on starting volume of DNA.

For genomic and higher molecular weight DNA, calculate 60% of the starting volume of DNA; this is the volume of beads that will be added to each tube (e.g., if the starting volume of DNA in buffer is 100 uL, then 60 uL of beads will be added to that sample in step 4). For purifying lower molecular weight DNA, you might need a higher proportion of beads. Consult the attached figure provided by UO GC3F or consult manufacturer’s instructions (Omega Tech; Total Pure NGS beads).

Make up 80% ethanol solution.
Bring beads to room temperature. Fully homogenize beads via vortexing.
Add appropriate volume of homogenized room temperature beads calculated in step 1 to each DNA sample. Mix by aspiration using a pipette set at a volume at least double the volume of beads added to allow for adequate mixing.
Cover the plate or close the tubes and let samples incubate for 10 minutes at room temperature.
Put samples on magnet. Wait until mix clears and beads condense to the magnet.
Pull off supernatant, careful not to disturb the beads. Discard supernatant.
Wash the beads with 200 ul 80% ethanol two times (3 minutes/wash). During each wash, let the beads condense to the magnet before removing the supernatant. Dispersing the beads with each wash isn’t necessary.
Discard the supernatant, trying to get as much as you can. You might want to first use a larger tip size and then switch to a smaller tip size to collect all of the ethanol.
Allow the beads to dry for 5 minutes. If you weren’t able to get all the visible liquid out after the second wash, you might have to go longer. You should not see any liquid after drying but do not let the beads dry completely (if they are starting to get lighter in color around the edges, that is long enough; if the middle of the bead pellet is turning light or if the pellet is starting to crack, that is too long for high molecular weight DNA, which has a harder time going back into solution after being dried).
Remove plate or tubes from magnet and add desired volume of elution buffer of choice to each sample. Make sure there are no beads out of the solution. Pipet the buffer onto the beads to wash them down.
Incubate at room temperature for 10 minutes.
Put the samples back on the magnet and let the beads condense.
Transfer the supernatant with your DNA to a fresh plate or tubes.







Quality Control




Quantify DNA using a fluorometer (e.g., Qubit) or spectrophotometer
Check DNA integrity on a gel if needed (see Chapter 13)









Figure 17.1: DNA Molecular Weight to Bead Proportion (UO GC3F)

title: 18  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 17 for cleaning/concentrating already-extracted DNA
See Chapter 11 for using extracted DNA in PCR
See Chapter 20 for using extracted DNA in RAD-seq

title: 18  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Background
This protocol uses magnetic beads (also known as superparamagnetic particles) and magnets to extract DNA. Magnetic beads are made of tiny (20 to 30 nm) particles of iron oxide and exhibit magnetic behavior in the presence of an external magnetic field. Using a magnetic field, magnetic beads can be separated from a suspension. In molecular biology, magnetic beads modified with different surface properties can be used to purify various types of biomolecules (genomic DNA, plasmids, mitochondrial DNA, RNA, and proteins). Below is a step-by-step overview of how DNA extraction using magnetic beads works:

You’ll use a buffer that contains a detergent to lyse the cells open and solubilize proteins etc., while a proteinase cuts the proteins up (and deactivates enzymes like nucleases that would degrade DNA).
Then add some of the magnetic beads, mix, allow time to bind, then use a magnet to pull the beads into a pellet and get rid of the liquid.
Wash the beads with an aqueous ethanol solution to get rid of all the residual chewed up molecules from the cells, but while still retaining the DNA on the beads. Pull the beads down again with the magnet and remove the wash solution.
Allow the beads to dry a short time just to get rid of the remaining ethanol.
Add an aqueous buffer and let the DNA release from the beads (this is called “eluting” the DNA into the buffer).
Use the magnet one more time to pull down the beads, leaving the DNA in solution. Transfer this aqueous DNA to a new, clean tube.

title: 18  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Materials

DNAse-free tubes, such as microcentrifuge tubes, PCR strip tubes, or plates
Magnet (for 1.5 ml tubes, use Invitrogen DynaMag-Spin Magnetic Particle Concentrator; for PCR plate or strip tubes, use DynaMag-96 Slide magnet or Catalyst 96 Slotted Ring Magnet Plate) o






IMPORTANT



Do not use magnets if you have a pacemaker. Do not place these powerful magnets near electronic devices like laptops or cell phones.


Pipettes






IMPORTANT



Use filter tips for entire protocol.


Thermocycler

title: 18  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Solutions

Tissue samples (fin, skin, or organ tissue like liver, brain, spleen are preferable to skeletal muscle). Amount of tissue might need optimization depending on preservation (e.g., fresh/frozen, in RNALater, or in ethanol) and tissue type. A good starting amount is 5-10 mg. If more DNA is needed, all solutions can be scaled up, but you might need to use microcentrifuge tubes and the magnet that can accept these tubes.
ATL buffer (from Qiagen DNeasy Tissue kit).






IMPORTANT



Check solution for white precipitate before use. If present, warm solution in water bath for a few minutes until the solution is clear and homogenous.


Proteinase K (from Qiagen DNeasy Tissue kit)
RNase A (10 mg/mL stock)
Omega Tech paramagnetic beads (we buy through GC3F, our sequencing Core facility)
75% ethanol
Elution buffer of choice (e.g., EB, TE, AE-AE and TE contain EDTA, which can inhibit some enzymes, so for some applications EB will be better)

title: 18  Cleaning/concentrating DNA with magnetic beads
text:
Procedure

Before digestion:

Put pieces of tissue sample into tubes of choice depending on number of preps (96-well PCR plate/part of 96-well plate, PCR tubes in strips of 8, or 1.5 ml tubes) on ice. Either proceed to the tissue digestion or seal and refreeze the plates/tubes at -20°C until you are ready to start.

On the day of the digestion:

Preheat a thermocycler to 56°C (choose the heated lid option).
Make up 75% ethanol in water.
Make up enough lysis/digestion buffer for all of your samples, plus about 5% extra (depending on how the pipetting goes, you might need to make up a bit more if you run out):

Calculate the volume of lysis/digestion buffer you need: (117 µl ATL buffer + 13 µl proteinase K) all multiplied by your number of tissue samples. Calculate an additional 5%. Mix these total volumes in a clean tube at room temperature.


Add 130 µl lysis/digestion buffer to each of the wells or tubes with the tissue, working quickly but carefully. If you run out of this solution, make as much as you need to complete the remaining reactions.
Optional: add 1.3 µl RNase A to each of the wells or tubes with the tissue.
Seal the plate or well with plastic film or close tubes and place in thermocycler (thermomixer or oven if using microcentrifuge tubes) for 2 hours.






NOTE



Tissue digestion can take longer than 2 hours, in which case, allow the digestion to proceed until tissue is fully digested. Samples may be left on thermocycler/thermomixer/oven for more than 2 hours and even overnight.


In the last half hour of the reaction, let the paramagnetic beads warm up to room temperature.
After the tissue digestion (step 5), remove the reactions from the thermocycler and allow them to cool to room temperature (about 15 minutes).
Vortex the beads to completely homogenize them.
Carefully unseal the plate with the digested tissue (place in a rack and hold firmly so there is no danger of splashing).
Vortex the beads once more to be sure they haven’t settled. Add 78 µl of the beads to each sample.
Mix by aspiration, waiting a little time for the viscous solution to sheet down the inside of the tip before expelling this last drop. You will need to use 200 µl tips for aspiration, with your pipet set equal or greater than half the volume of the digest to get adequate mixing.
Cover the plate or tubes and let the samples sit at room temperature for 10 minutes.
Put the plate on the magnet and let the beads collect into a pellet. This will take a while.
Pull off the supernatant carefully, trying not to disturb the beads. Discard the supernatant.
Wash the beads with 200 µl 75% ethanol two times (3 minutes/wash). During each wash, let the beads condense to the magnet before removing the supernatant. Dspersing the beads with each wash isn’t necessary.
Discard the supernatant, trying to get as much as you can. You might want to first use a larger tip size and then switch to a smaller tip size to collect all of the ethanol.
Allow the beads to dry for 5 minutes. If you weren’t able to get all the visible liquid out after the second wash, you might have to go longer. You should not see any liquid after drying but do not let the beads dry completely (if they are starting to get lighter in color around the edges, that is long enough; if the middle of the bead pellet is turning light or if the pellet is starting to crack, that is too long for high molecular weight DNA, which has a harder time going back into solution after being dried).
Remove plate or tubes from magnet and add desired volume of elution buffer of choice to each sample. Make sure there are no beads stranded on the wall of the tube and not submerged - pipet the buffer onto the beads to wash them down.






NOTE



For RAD-seq, it is best to use EB Buffer rather than AE buffer.


Incubate at room temperature for 10 minutes.
Put the samples back on the magnet and let the beads condense.
Transfer the supernatant with your DNA to a fresh plate or tubes.

title: 20  Sequenced RAD Tags
text:
Purpose: To produce Illumina Libraries of Sequenced RAD tags
