title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text: Introduction

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Purpose: This protocol describes how to safely anesthetize adult fish for imaging, measurements, surgical procedures, or other manipulations
Procedure Type: Husbandry/Anesthesia
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: February 28, 2024, updated November 22, 2025
IACUC Protocol: Required for all anesthesia procedures







Safety and Handling




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
MS-222 (tricaine) can be absorbed through skin - always wear gloves
Work in well-ventilated area
Never consume food or drink in anesthesia work area
Dispose of MS-222 solutions according to chemical waste protocols
Keep MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) readily accessible









IACUC Compliance



All anesthesia procedures must be:

Covered by current IACUC protocol
Performed by trained personnel
Documented in laboratory records
Monitored for fish welfare
Ended with appropriate recovery or euthanasia

Anesthesia is not euthanasia: Fish must either fully recover or be properly euthanized. Prolonged anesthesia without recovery or euthanasia is not acceptable.

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Background
MS-222 (tricaine methanesulfonate, also called tricaine or ethyl 3-aminobenzoate methanesulfonate) is the most commonly used anesthetic for fish. It is FDA-approved for use in fish and acts as a central nervous system depressant, inducing a dose-dependent sedation and anesthesia.

Mechanism of Action
MS-222 works by blocking sodium channels in nerve cell membranes, similar to local anesthetics like lidocaine. At appropriate concentrations, it produces:

Light sedation (reduced activity, maintained equilibrium)
Deep sedation (loss of equilibrium, reduced opercular rate)
Surgical anesthesia (no response to stimuli, slow opercular rate)
Overdose/death (cessation of opercular movements)

The goal for most procedures is to achieve deep sedation or light surgical anesthesia - enough to immobilize the fish for manipulation but maintaining respiratory movements.


Factors Affecting Anesthesia

Water temperature: Warmer water increases metabolic rate and speeds induction
Fish size: Smaller fish require less time to anesthetize
Fish health: Stressed or sick fish are more sensitive
Water chemistry: pH, salinity, oxygen levels all affect uptake
Individual variation: Always monitor each fish individually

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Materials

Equipment

Small containers or petri dishes (for anesthesia)
Larger containers or tanks (for recovery)
Transfer pipettes or small nets
Timer or clock
Thermometer
pH meter or pH strips
Imaging equipment or other experimental apparatus (as needed)



Optional

Dissecting microscope (for detailed observation)
Small sponge or soft surface (for positioning during imaging)
Gloves (nitrile or latex)

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Solutions

MS-222 Stock Solution (4g/L)






Pharmaceutical Grade Tricaine



CRITICAL: Tricaine must be pharmaceutical-grade. We use tricaine purchased from Pentair (manufactured by Western Chemical, FDA approved). Tricaine (3-amino benzoic acid ethyl ester, also called ethyl m-aminobenzoate) comes in powdered form. Purchase the smallest amount possible because tricaine expires quickly (typically 1-2 years from manufacture date).

Check expiration date before use
Store powder at 4°C in original container
Protect from light and moisture
Discard if discolored or clumped



Tris-Buffered MS-222 Stock (4g/L)
-   4 g tricaine powder
-   979 ml deionized (DD) water
-   ~21 ml 1 M Tris (pH 9)
-   Adjust pH to ~7.0
-   Aliquot in 50ml tubes
-   Label with "MS-222 Stock Solution 4g/L" and date
-   Store at -20°C
-   This makes 1 liter of stock solution
-   Stable for 6 months when frozen






Why Buffer MS-222?



Unbuffered MS-222 is very acidic (pH ~3), which is stressful to fish and less effective as an anesthetic. Buffering to neutral pH (7.0-7.5) with Tris improves efficacy and reduces stress. Always check pH before use.




Anesthesia Working Solution
The standard anesthesia concentration for adult fish is 168 mg/L (also written as 0.168 g/L or 168 ppm).

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


For 100 ml working solution:

92.5 ml of 3 ppt Instant Ocean solution
7.5 ml of MS-222 stock (4g/L)
Final concentration: 168 mg/L in 3 ppt salinity

Prepare 3 ppt Instant Ocean:

0.3 g Instant Ocean salt mix
100 ml deionized water
Mix until fully dissolved

Storage:

Store in amber (dark) bottle to protect from light
Label with: “MS-222 Anesthesia 168 mg/L”, preparation date, expiration date (6 months)
Keep at room temperature or 4°C
Discard if discolored, precipitated, or past expiration



For 100 ml working solution:

92.5 ml of 25-30 ppt Instant Ocean solution
7.5 ml of MS-222 stock (4g/L)
Final concentration: 168 mg/L in 25-30 ppt salinity

Prepare 25-30 ppt Instant Ocean:

2.5-3.0 g Instant Ocean salt mix
100 ml deionized water
Mix until fully dissolved

Notes for Syngnathids:

Use full-strength seawater (25-30 ppt) to match their osmotic requirements
Bay pipefish are more sensitive - may need lower concentration (start with 120-140 mg/L)
Gulf pipefish tolerate wider salinity range but prefer 25-30 ppt

Storage:

Store in amber bottle to protect from light
Label with: “MS-222 Anesthesia 168 mg/L”, preparation date, expiration date (6 months)
Keep at room temperature or 4°C






Recovery Water
Prepare fresh water appropriate for your species:

Stickleback: 3 ppt Instant Ocean or system water
Pipefish: 25-30 ppt Instant Ocean or system water
Use same temperature as holding system
Ensure adequate oxygenation (aeration or frequent water changes)

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Procedure

Pre-Anesthesia Preparation






Planning Ahead




Know exactly what procedure you will perform and estimate duration
Have all equipment ready before anesthetizing fish
Work quickly but carefully - minimize anesthesia time
Target total anesthesia time: <10 minutes for routine procedures
Plan recovery container and monitoring schedule




Prepare workspace

Set up anesthesia container (petri dish or small container)
Set up recovery container with fresh, aerated water
Prepare imaging or experimental equipment
Ensure adequate lighting
Have timer ready

Prepare solutions

Pour ~50-100 ml MS-222 anesthesia solution into anesthesia container
Fill recovery container with fresh water (200-500 ml, depending on fish size)
Verify temperature is appropriate (16-20°C for stickleback, 18-22°C for pipefish)
Optional: Check pH of anesthesia solution (should be 7.0-7.5)

Select and observe fish

Choose healthy fish only - do not anesthetize sick or stressed fish
Observe for 5 minutes: normal swimming, feeding, coloration
Record fish ID or description
Note start time




Anesthesia Induction

Transfer fish to anesthesia solution

Use transfer pipette or small net
Minimize air exposure
Gently place fish in anesthesia container
Start timer immediately

Monitor anesthesia stages






Stages of Anesthesia



Stage 1: Light Sedation (0-2 minutes)

Decreased swimming activity
Decreased response to external stimuli
Normal opercular rate
Normal equilibrium

Stage 2: Deep Sedation (2-4 minutes)

Increased loss of muscle tone
Erratic swimming
Decreased opercular rate
Loss of equilibrium (fish tips on side or inverts)

Stage 3: Surgical Anesthesia (4-6 minutes)

Total loss of muscle tone
No response to handling
Slow, regular opercular movements
No reflex response to tail pinch

Stage 4: Overdose

Opercular movements very slow or stopped
Cardiac arrest (if prolonged)
AVOID THIS STAGE unless euthanizing



Achieve appropriate anesthesia depth

For imaging or measurements: Stage 2 (loss of equilibrium) is usually sufficient
For surgery or manipulations: Stage 3 (surgical anesthesia) required
Key indicator: Fish should not respond to gentle handling but maintain slow opercular movements
Typical induction time: 3-6 minutes for adults (faster for smaller fish)




During Anesthesia

Perform procedure

Work quickly but carefully
Keep fish moist if out of water

Use transfer pipettes to drip anesthesia solution on gills
Can place fish on damp sponge or soft surface
Never let fish dry out

Monitor opercular movements continuously
Target procedure time: <5 minutes for routine work, <10 minutes maximum








Monitoring During Anesthesia



CRITICAL MONITORING:

Opercular (gill cover) movements must continue throughout procedure
If opercular movements stop: immediately transfer to recovery water
If opercular movements become very slow (<10 per minute): prepare to end procedure
If fish appears too deeply anesthetized: transfer to recovery water immediately

Normal opercular rates during anesthesia:

Light sedation: 50-80% of normal rate
Deep sedation: 30-50% of normal rate
Surgical anesthesia: 20-40% of normal rate
Danger zone: <20% of normal rate




Complete procedure

Finish procedure as quickly as possible
Record any observations or measurements
Take photos if needed
Note total anesthesia time




Recovery

Transfer to recovery water

Gently transfer fish using pipette or soft net
Place in recovery container with fresh, aerated water
Position fish upright if needed
Note time of transfer to recovery

Support recovery

If fish is deeply anesthetized, gently move through water to pass water over gills
Hold fish upright with head facing into gentle current (if using airstone)
Can use transfer pipette to gently direct water flow over gills
Continue until fish shows signs of increased opercular rate

Monitor recovery progression






Stages of Recovery



Early Recovery (0-5 minutes):

Opercular rate increases
May remain on side or inverted
No swimming movements

Mid Recovery (5-10 minutes):

Opercular rate near normal
Fish rights itself
Weak swimming movements begin

Late Recovery (10-20 minutes):

Normal opercular rate
Active swimming
Maintains equilibrium
May still have reduced response to external stimuli

Full Recovery (20+ minutes):

Normal swimming behavior
Normal response to stimuli
Normal coloration



Check recovery every 2-5 minutes

Look for increasing opercular rate
Watch for return of swimming ability
Note return of equilibrium
Check for normal coloration
Typical recovery time: 5-20 minutes








Recovery Problems



If fish is not recovering:

Ensure water is well-oxygenated (add airstone if not present)
Check water temperature (should match system temperature)
Gently move fish through water to increase gill perfusion
Continue support for up to 30 minutes
If no signs of recovery after 30 minutes, consult with supervisor

Signs of successful recovery:

Normal opercular rate
Active swimming
Attempts to evade handling
Normal coloration (not pale or dark)





Post-Recovery

Return to system or continue monitoring

Once fully recovered (normal swimming, equilibrium, responsiveness), fish can be returned to home tank
Alternative: Keep in recovery tank for additional monitoring (2-24 hours)
Monitor during next daily health check
Record successful recovery and any observations

Documentation

Record in laboratory notebook or database:

Fish ID
Date and time
Anesthesia concentration and duration
Procedure performed
Recovery time
Any complications or observations

Update IACUC records if required

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




Slow or no induction
Anesthesia solution too dilute
Check concentration; make fresh solution



Old or degraded MS-222
Use fresh stock; check expiration date



pH too low or high
Verify pH is 7.0-7.5; adjust if needed



Water temperature too cold
Warm to appropriate temperature


Rapid, deep anesthesia
Concentration too high
Use lower concentration (120-140 mg/L)



Fish too small for adult dose
Reduce concentration or volume



Fish stressed or weakened
Select healthier fish; pre-screen carefully


Fish stops breathing
Over-anesthetization
Immediately transfer to recovery water; support gills



Procedure too long
Work faster; plan procedure better



Anesthesia too concentrated
Reduce concentration for next fish


Slow recovery
Excessive anesthesia depth
Reduce concentration or time for next fish



Inadequate oxygenation
Add airstone; change water



Fish exhausted or stressed
Provide extended recovery time; monitor closely


No recovery
Overdose
Ensure opercular monitoring during procedure



Procedure too long
Limit anesthesia time to <10 minutes



Underlying health issue
Pre-screen fish health carefully


Fish hyperactive after recovery
Insufficient anesthesia
Increase concentration slightly



Stress response
Normal for some fish; monitor, usually resolves


Repeat anesthesia needed
First dose insufficient
Acceptable to re-anesthetize after full recovery




Allow at least 30 minutes between anesthesia events

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Concentration Adjustments

When to Use Lower Concentrations

Very small fish (<30 mm)
Fish in poor health or stressed
Prolonged procedures (>10 minutes)
Species known to be sensitive (e.g., bay pipefish)

Suggested lower dose: 120-140 mg/L


When to Use Higher Concentrations

Very large fish (>60 mm)
Fish resistant to anesthesia
Quick procedures (<2 minutes)

Suggested higher dose: 200-250 mg/L






Warning



Always start with standard concentration (168 mg/L) for new species or procedures. Adjust only after observing response. Never exceed 300 mg/L for routine anesthesia.

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Special Considerations

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Anesthesia Response: - Generally robust and tolerate anesthesia well - Adult males in breeding condition may be more sensitive - Spines can make handling difficult - use soft nets or careful hand positioning
Recovery: - Usually quick and uneventful - Can be quite active immediately upon recovery - use covered containers to prevent jumping
Typical Timings: - Induction: 3-5 minutes - Recovery: 5-15 minutes


Anesthesia Response: - More delicate than stickleback - require careful monitoring - Bay pipefish (S. leptorhyncus) may be more sensitive than gulf pipefish - Body shape makes it difficult to assess equilibrium loss - watch for cessation of swimming
Recovery: - May be slower than stickleback (10-20 minutes) - Often settle to bottom during recovery - this is normal - Pregnant males: extra care to avoid embryo loss
Typical Timings: - Induction: 4-6 minutes (bay pipefish often faster) - Recovery: 10-20 minutes
Special Notes: - Use full-strength seawater (25-30 ppt) - Ensure water temperature matches system (18-22°C) - Can be more prone to jumping during light sedation - use covered containers

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Alternative Anesthetics
While MS-222 is the standard, other anesthetics are occasionally used:

Clove Oil (Eugenol)

Natural anesthetic derived from clove plants
Less expensive than MS-222
Must be dissolved in ethanol first (1:10 clove oil:ethanol)
Working concentration: 40-100 mg/L
Not FDA approved for fish
Recovery can be longer than MS-222



2-Phenoxyethanol

Alternative to MS-222
Working concentration: 0.1-0.5 ml/L
Less commonly used
Not FDA approved







Note



This protocol focuses on MS-222 as it is FDA-approved and most commonly used in research settings. Consult with supervisor and IACUC before using alternative anesthetics.

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Quality Control

Test anesthesia solution with control fish before critical experiments
Keep log of induction and recovery times to track consistency
Make fresh working solutions every 6 months
Check pH of stock solutions periodically
Maintain accurate records for IACUC compliance

title: 44  Adult Fish Anesthesia
text:
Associated Papers

Neiffer, D. L., & Stamper, M. A. (2009). Fish sedation, anesthesia, analgesia, and euthanasia: considerations, methods, and types of drugs. ILAR Journal, 51(4), 343-357.
Ross, L. G., & Ross, B. (2008). Anaesthetic and Sedative Techniques for Aquatic Animals (3rd ed.). Blackwell Publishing.
Summerfelt, R. C., & Smith, L. S. (1990). Anesthesia, surgery, and related techniques. In C. B. Schreck & P. B. Moyle (Eds.), Methods for Fish Biology (pp. 213-272). American Fisheries Society.
Zahl, I. H., Samuelsen, O., & Kiessling, A. (2012). Anaesthesia of farmed fish: implications for welfare. Fish Physiology and Biochemistry, 38(1), 201-218.

title: 45  Live Food Culture - Rotifers
text: Introduction

title: 45  Live Food Culture - Rotifers
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes standard practices for culturing live foods, rotifers, for pipefish and threespine stickleback.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)
ADD SPECIES OF ROTIFERS AND SUPPLIER INFO

Author: Tiffany Thornton
Date Created: 2023

title: 45  Live Food Culture - Rotifers
text:
Materials

Fish-safe gloves (e.g., blue nitrile “clean room” gloves)
70% ethanol used to disinfect surfaces
Germicidal bleach (minimum 5.25% sodium hypochlorite)
Sodium thiosulfate crystals
Reverse-osmosis filtered water (“RO” water)
Reed Mariculture “Rotigrow Plus” rotifer food
Reed Mariculture “N-rich” gut-loading food






Note



Not used by zebrafish facility - has a short shelf life


Straining sieves, 20 µm pore size
Salinity test pen (e.g., Oakton SaltTestr 11 pocket meter)






Note



Use refractometer for saltwater system. The stickleback facility uses a refractometer for salinity testing


Harvesting pail (e.g., plastic 3-gallon bucket, with graduated lines showing gallons)
Sink or wastewater bucket (e.g., plastic 5-gallon bucket)
Brackish water mixing bucket (e.g., clean, plastic 5-gallon bucket)
Sea salt (e.g., Instant Ocean commercial sea salt mix)
Stir stick (e.g., clean, plastic stir rod approximately 18 inches to 24 inches long)
Clean 1-Liter beaker for holding harvested rotifers
Clean measuring cups (green and blue) or graduated cylinder or calibrated balance to measure sea salt mix
Disposable graduated transfer pipettes

title: 45  Live Food Culture - Rotifers
text:
Solutions:

25-27 ppt brackish water (prepared fresh during procedure using Instant Ocean sea salt mix and RO water)

title: 45  Live Food Culture - Rotifers
text:
Procedure:






Safety



Wear clean fish-safe gloves.


Rotifer Harvest

Prepare two gallons of 25-27 part-per-thousand (ppt) brackish water (E5).

Ensure RO water source is clean.

Use 70% ethanol to disinfect RO water hose end, if using RO hose.
Use dedicated, clean RO vessels (carboys), if using vessels.

Add 2 gallons clean RO water to harvesting pail.

Use 2-gallon graduated mark to ensure volume.

Add up to 210 grams Instant Ocean to harvesting pail.

Use graduated beaker to measure Instant Ocean.
Alternatively, use provided labeled and color-coded tool specific to making 25-27 ppt brackish water.

Use stir stick to mix and dissolve salt mix into RO water.
Test the salinity using the refractometer to ensure 25-27 ppt salinity has been achieved.

Harvest rotifers.

Strain 40% of the rotifer culture through the 20?m sieve.
Transfer the collected rotifers from the sieve to the pail of 25-27 ppt brackish water: place sieve in brackish water

Concentrate rotifers.

Pour rotifers through 20µm sieve, fill sieve with brackish water and gently pour into 1 L beaker.
IMPORTANT - Keep sieve wet at all times.

Use RO water to loosen rotifers from sieve into beaker, if necessary.


Gut-load the rotifers.

Add 2 ml “Rotigrow Plus” rotifer food to the beaker and aerate.
Allow the rotifers to feed for 15 minutes to 1 hour before feeding to the fish.






Note



Adjust down for smaller harvests


Test the salinity with the refractometer and adjust using RO water or Instant Ocean sea salt mix as needed to achieve 25-27 ppt.

Use rotifers as food for larval fish.

Rotifer Water Replacement

Replace 40% rotifer bucket water using new brackish water.

Prepare 25-27 ppt brackish water.

Pour 340 grams (need to recalculate for 5 gallons) Instant Ocean sea salt mix into a clean 5-gallon bucket. Use provided marked and color-coded green tool specific to making replacement water if balance unavailable.
Fill bucket with RO water.
Use clean stir stick to mix sea salt mix and RO water completely.

Pour brackish water into rotifer buckets until full.


Rotifer Feeding

Feed rotifers.

Add 6 ml “Rotigrow Plus” rotifer food to each rotifer bucket.

Use new graduated transfer pipette to measure and transfer food to rotifers.
Feed in the morning and again in the afternoon.



Clean Up

Sanitize equipment.

Place sieves into harvesting pail.
Add two capfuls of 10% bleach.
Fill harvesting pail with municipal water.

Ensure all equipment and bucket interior are covered by bleach water.

Wait 10 minutes.
Dump harvesting pail bleach water into sink.
Add 2 tablespoons sodium thiosulfate to harvesting pail.
Fill harvesting pail with municipal water.

Ensure all equipment and bucket interior are covered by sodium thiosulfate water.

Dump harvesting pail water into sink.
Use 70% ethanol to disinfect exterior of harvesting pail and storage shelf.
Place harvesting pail now containing sanitized equipment on storage cart.
Use Facility rack washer to sanitize wastewater buckets and brackish water mixing buckets then place buckets on storage cart.

title: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks
text: Introduction
crumbs: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks

title: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to conduct weekend feedings and health checks for stickleback and pipefish
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: December 15, 2023; modified January 2, 2023 by Micah Woods
crumbs: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks

title: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks
text:
Materials

Adult stickleback food
Juvenile stickleback food
Brine shrimp
Squirt bottle
De-capsulated brine shrimp
Rock salt
105 μm mesh shrimp collector
Baking soda
Frozen mysids
1000 ml beaker labeled “Pipefish Only”
Net
Container to hold fish while being euthanized
Postmortem fixing equipment
Morgue
crumbs: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks

title: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks
text:
Solutions

Euthanasia strength Mesab (located in Mark’s fridge in 324 Pacific)
crumbs: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks

title: 46  Weekend Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding and Health Checks
text:
Procedure






Note



Fish only need to be fed once per day on weekends. Ideally, fish will be fed on weekends around noon since they only receive one feeding, but this time can be flexible to accommodate weekend feeders’ schedules.



Conduct health checks of all fish in Winter Room and Summer Room according to the steps described in Chapter 33.
Prepare brine cone for feeding by following the steps described in the brine shrimp hatching and feeding protocol.







Note



Since fish are only fed once per day on weekends, use the entire brine cone to feed fish.



Feed Stickleback

Winter Room

20g tanks

Feed 1 scoop of adult stickleback food.


Summer Room

20g tanks

Feed 1 scoop of adult stickleback food.

4.5 and 10.5 liter tanks

Larval (red tags): feed small squirt of brine shrimp.
Juvenile (green and blue tags): feed half of a scoop of juvenile food.









Note



If there is not sufficient adult or juvenile food to conduct feedings, see the Stickleback Dry Food Mix protocol for instructions on making more food.


Feed Pipefish

Summer Room

20g tanks (adults and juveniles)

Adults: feed frozen mysids







Preparing and Feeding Frozen Mysids



Partially fill the 1000 ml beaker labeled “Pipefish Only” located on the pipefish rack with pipefish water. Place a dime sized piece of frozen mysids (bottom shelf in freezer) in the beaker with water, and swirl water to thaw mysids. Once thawed, feed to the adult pipefish.



Juveniles: feed squirt of brine shrimp.

10.5 liter tanks (mysids, pregnant males, and juvenile pipefish)

Juvenile pipefish/mysids: feed small squirt of brine shrimp.










Important



Please move any male that has given birth into a community (20g) adult pipefish tank



Reset brine shrimp cone according to steps described in the brine shrimp hatching and feeding protocol.







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish husbandry. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare.

title: 47  Weekday Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to conduct weekday feedings for stickleback and pipefish
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 08, 2024
IACUC Protocol: Covered under facility animal care procedures







Notes




Fish are fed twice per day during weekdays
Feed fish at the start of the shift in the morning and at the end of the shift in the afternoons
Since fish are fed twice per day, only collect one half of the brine shrimp in the morning and make sure to reset the cone during the afternoon feeding

text:
Solutions

crumbs: 47  Weekday Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding

title: 47  Weekday Stickleback and Pipefish Feeding
text:
Procedure

Conduct health checks of all fish in Winter Room and Summer Room according to Chapter 33.
Prepare brine cone for feeding by following the steps described in Chapter 40.
Feed Stickleback twice per day

Winter Room

20g tanks: Feed 1 scoop of adult stickleback food per feeding.

Summer Room

20g tanks: Feed 1 scoop of adult stickleback food per feeding.
4.5 and 10.5 liter tanks:

Larval (2.8L and 9.5L tanks): feed small squirt of brine shrimp.
Juvenile (9.5L tanks): feed half of a scoop of juvenile food.










Notes



Please pay attention to the fish size in the 9.5L tanks and feed accordingly. Tanks of similar sized fish will try to be clustered together on the racks for ease of feeding. Also pay attention to signs and/or tags and messages on the white board or Teams for direction on how 9.5L tanks are to be fed.








Notes



If there is not sufficient adult or juvenile food to conduct feedings, see Chapter 50 for instructions on making more food.



Feed Pipefish twice per day

Summer Room - 20g tanks (adults and juveniles)

Adults: feed frozen mysids

During the morning feeding please feed the adults only frozen mysids
In the evenings please feed frozen mysids and live brine shrimp (see Chapter 34 for mysid culture)

Juveniles: feed squirt of brine shrimp









Preparing and Feeding Frozen Mysids



Partially fill the 1000 ml beaker labeled “Pipefish Only” located on the pipefish rack with pipefish water. Place a dime sized piece of frozen mysids (bottom shelf in freezer) in the beaker with water, and swirl water to thaw mysids. Once thawed, feed to the adult pipefish.


b.  **10.5 liter tanks (mysids, pregnant males, and juvenile pipefish)**

    -   **Juvenile pipefish/mysids**: feed small squirt of brine shrimp






Notes



Please move any male that has given birth into a community (20g) adult pipefish tank

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text: Introduction

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Purpose: This document describes stickleback and pipefish density standards that are used in the Cresko Lab.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey

Date Created: January 01, 2020, updated February 05, 2024

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Materials

N/A

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Solutions

N/A

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Procedure:






Note




Fry and early juveniles stickleback are kept in long day conditions (Summer Room) with 16 hours of light/day with a 1/2 hours dawn and dusk.
Growing juveniles to adult stickleback are kept in short day conditions (Winter Room) with 10 hours of light/day.
Breeding age stickleback are kept in long day conditions (Summer Room) with 16 hours of light/day with a 1/2 hours dawn and dusk.
All pipefish are kept in long day conditions (Summer Room) with 16 hours of light/day with a 1/2 hours dawn and dusk.
These standards for fish densities are what we in the Cresko lab have determined optimal after 20 years of keeping threespine stickleback and 8 years of keeping pipefish in recirculating aquaculture systems.




Stickleback Fry (9dpf - 2 months)

Fry are kept in 4.5 L tanks at an ideal density of 20 fish per container.
Fry can be kept in densities of up to 40 fish per tank.
If fish densities are near 40 per tank fish are transferred or thinned after 1 month of age.



Stickleback Juveniles (2 months - 3 months) Early Grow Out

Juvenile fish are transferred from fry tanks into 10.5 L tanks and kept at a density of 20 fish per container.

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
section: Stickleback post-Juvenile (3 months - 1 year) Late Grow Out
text:
Stickleback post-Juvenile (3 months - 1 year) Late Grow Out

Fish older are then 3 months are transferred into 20 gallon tanks (if not already in a 20 gallon) and grown to 1 year of age in the Winter room.

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Stickleback Adults (1 year - 1.5 years) Breeding:

Adult fish are transferred to 20 gallon tanks in the long day room.
Fish can be kept at a density of 40 fish per tank if space is needed.
Adult fish become sexually mature 4-6 weeks after being in long day conditions and will stay in breeding condition for 1-3 months.

title: 48  Stickleback Density Standards
text:
Pipefish

Pregnant males are placed in 10.5 L tanks and moved back to 20 gallon tanks when they have given birth.
Young pipefish (0-3 months) are grown in 10.5 L tanks at the density they are born at.
Adult pipefish are kept in mixed gender 20 gallon tanks at no more than 15 fish per tank.







IACUC Protocol



These density standards are established under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish husbandry. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare.

text:

Chapter 42 - Room lighting requirements

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text: Introduction

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text:
Purpose: The procedure describes the creation of stickleback crosses via in vitro fertilization.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: created March 4th, 2004, updated February 2nd, 2024
IACUC Protocol: Required for all crosses and animal procedures







IACUC Compliance




All crosses must be documented in laboratory records
Fish must be euthanized following approved protocols
Embryos must be monitored daily for health and development
See Chapter 37 for euthanasia procedures









Chemical Hygiene




When using MS-222 and ethanol, wear gloves and eye protection
Work in well-ventilated area
Dispose of chemicals according to waste protocols

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text:
Materials

25 and 90mm disposable sterile petri dishes (standard)
Fine scissors and forceps
Wide-blade entomology forceps
Squeeze wash bottles
Stress coat (standard from pet store)
Sterile flat razor blades
Sterile disposable large bore transfer pipettes (VWR cat# 691)
Dissecting microscope

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text:
Solutions

Testes Solution - see ?sec-recipes_testes_solution
MS222 Tricaine Methanesulfonate - see ?sec-recipes_Mesab
95% ethanol
Embryo medium - see ?sec-general-em

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text:
Procedures

Squeeze Female






Tip



Gravid females can be identified by those that have large rounded abdomens and a slightly extended cloaca. If you can see individual eggs in the abdomen this is an indication that the eggs are old.



Cover fingers with stress coat and gently squeeze gravid female.
If eggs do not emerge with very slight pressure the female is not quite ready or the eggs are too old.
Remove eggs by slightly squeezing the abdomen starting just posterior of the pectoral girdle towards the cloaca expelling the eggs into a 25mm sterile petri dish.
Note the stock number of the female on the petri dish.







Note



The small size of petri dish allows the sperm to be concentrated on the eggs.




Dissect Testes From Male

Euthanize male by placing him into a small container containing a lethal volume of MS222.
Clean a large, 30cm by 60cm or similar size, glass sheet, fine scissors, and forceps with 95% ethanol.
When male is motionless and not responding in accordance with the Chapter 37, remove the fish and place on the glass sheet. Sever the spinal cord behind skull using a razor to be sure of euthanization.
Use scissors to make incision from the cloaca anteriorly to the pelvic girdle making the incision along the mid line of the fish.
Make another cut to each side of the fish from the cloaca dorsally approximately 15mm so that the body cavity is easily accessed.







Note



Incisions should be made just deep enough to cut the skin and body wall muscle while being wary to not cut into the stomach and intestines that are located just below the skin surface.



Locate paired testes and vas deferens.







Note



Testes are variable in shape and coloration, but are usually long and pigmented, usually having the same pigmentation as the skin surface, and sit in the dorsal part of the coelom near the kidneys. The vas deferens are threadlike and are usually as long as the testis to which it connects.



Use fine forceps to grab vas deferens, sever near the cloaca, and remove one (or often) both testes.







Note



Doing so keeps the testes intact, allowing them to contain viable sperm for up to 1 month at 4°C in Testes Solution.




Storing of Testes

If only a single cross is to be made with a male, proceed to step 16.
Otherwise, place testes into 15 ml tube filled with cold Testes Solution and label tube with male stock number and date.
Store testes at 4°C.
To store testes for extended periods, change out medium once a week. See Chapter 51 for detailed testes storage procedures.



Prepare Testis

If multiple crosses are to be performed from a single pair of male’s testes, place both testes on the inside lid of the 25mm petri dish into which a female’s eggs have been squeezed.
Using a sterile razor to macerate testis.







Note



Under a dissecting scope swimming sperm should cause a ‘sparkling’ refraction.



Add approximately 1.0 ml of sterile embryo medium to testes prep with disposable pipette, mix, and then add to the eggs one drop at a time, using same disposable pipette, dispersing drops between petri dishes so that all eggs are covered with sperm mixture. Label petri dish(s) with male stock number and time/date of fertilization.
Leave sperm on the eggs for about 5-10 minutes.
Add embryo medium to cover the embryos.
Place in incubator at 20°C.



Separation of Embryos and Second Cleaning (t = 2 hr)






Note



The animal pole of the embryo is established at the site of sperm entry, and at 20°C the first cell syncitium is usually visible within 45 minutes. The first cell division usually occurs approximately 25 minutes later, and the two cell stage is fully visible approximately 1.5 - 2 hr post fertilization. During this time, the chorion thickens and attaches to the petri dish as well as to other embryos.



After 2 hours post fertilization, use the wide blade entomological forceps to detach the embryos from one another, as well as to dislodge embryos from the bottom of the petri dish.
Remove all of the unfertilized eggs to limit mold contamination, and record the total number of eggs and embryos.
Rinse embryos 3 to 4 more times then distribute embryos to 90mm petri dishes (30-50 embryos per dish) filled half way with fresh embryo medium.
Enter cross information into database (see Chapter 35), print labels for dishes, and place embryos into incubator at 20°C.



Raise Embryos (check daily)






Note



Embryos will develop at approximately 2.5 times zebrafish time [see http://zfin.org/zf_info/zfbook/stages/index.html], and hatch at approximately 7-9 days. 48 to 52 hpf stickleback embryos have completed most major morphogenetic processes, and the melanic pigment cells are just starting to migrate. A beating heart can be seen after ~72hr.



Check petri dishes daily and remove embryos that have arrested development.
Change of embryo medium at 3-4 dpf and more if water has fouled.
Record health checks on incubator checklist. See Chapter 41 for incubator use procedures.

title: 49  Stickleback Crosses
text:
Place Embryos into Aquaculture System

Prepare small 4.5 L fry tank by adding 400 micron baffle and turning on the system water to the tank while letting it flush for 15 minutes.







Note



If the plumbing line has sat stagnant for awhile flush the line by turning on the valve and expressing system water into a small (not the tank) container.



Once embryos have hatched and their yolks have absorbed (~9 dpf) add aquaculture system water to dish and let sit 15 minutes.
Gently add the fry to the prepared tank making sure all fry have been added.

text:

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text: Introduction
crumbs: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes standard practices for mixing of dry food to feed all life stages of threespine stickleback in the Pacific Stickleback Facility.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: August 25, 2014; updated January 26, 2023 by Mark Currey
IACUC Protocol: Covered under facility maintenance procedures







Notes



At each new mixing of dry food (approximately once per week) food containers will be cleaned (washed in the dishwasher) and spoons cleaned with 70% ETOH. The beaker that holds feeding spoons will also be replaced with clean beaker.








Note



If we are out of one of the types of food it is ok to omit it from the mix. Continue with available ingredients.
crumbs: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text:
Materials

Plastic measuring cup
Clean food container with lid
Clean spoons for feeding
Beaker for storing spoons
70% Ethanol for cleaning
crumbs: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text:
Solutions

None required
crumbs: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text:
Procedure

Food Mix Recipes
Mix equal parts of the following ingredients. Store at 4°C in fish facility food fridge. Label with an expiration date of 1 month from mixing.

Fry Mix:

100-200 micron golden pearls
Ziegler AP100

Juvenile Mix (label with a yellow dot or yellow tape):

Aquanix cool mix flakes (or other flake food)
200-300 micron golden pearls
Otohime C1 pellets

Adult Mix:

Otohime S1
Ziegler zebrafish diet
Hikari micro pellet
Golden pearls 500-800 micron
Aquanix cool mix flakes (or other flake food)




Preparation Steps

Clean containers: Wash food containers in dishwasher. See Chapter 39 for dishwasher use.
Clean spoons: Clean feeding spoons with 70% ETOH.
Clean beaker: Replace beaker that holds feeding spoons with clean beaker.
Measure and mix: Using measuring cup, measure equal parts of each ingredient and mix thoroughly in clean container.
Label: Label container with:

Mix type (Fry, Juvenile, or Adult)
Date mixed
Expiration date (1 month from mixing date)
Color code for juvenile mix (yellow dot or tape)

Store: Store at 4°C in fish facility food fridge.
crumbs: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix

title: 50  Stickleback Dry Fish Food Mix
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 39 for dishwasher use
See Chapter 31 for food storage and sources information
See Chapter 47 for weekday feeding procedures
See Chapter 46 for weekend feeding procedures

title: 51  Testes Storage
text: Introduction

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to store stickleback testes for fertilization up to 1-2 months post extraction.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: May 6, 2008; updated January 15, 2015 by Mark Currey
IACUC Protocol: Covered under breeding and crossing procedures







Note



Both Gentamycin and cell culture anti-biotic/mycotic reagents are located in separate boxes in the scientific -20°C freezer. They are partitioned into 100μl aliquots.

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Materials

15 ml falcon tube
4°C refrigerator
Gentamycin (antimycotic) (Stock - 10mg/ml)
Cell Culture anti-biotic/mycotic from Gibco-BRL (15240-096) 100x Concentration

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Solutions

Ginzberg’s Ringers - see ?sec-recipe_ginzbergs for detailed recipe:

Mix solids into 750 ml of npH2O:

6.6g NaCl
0.25g KCl
0.3g CaCl2
0.2g NaHCO3

Bring to 1 liter total volume with npH2O
Store at 4°C

Testes solution (100ml) - see ?sec-recipe_testes_solution for detailed recipe:

Add 100μl of Gentamycin and 100μl of Anti-biotic/mycotic to 100ml of Ginzburg’s Ringers solution
Store at 4°C

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Procedure

Prepare solutions: Make Ginzberg’s Ringers and Testes solutions as described above.
Dissect testes: Follow procedures in Chapter 49 for testes dissection.
Store in solution: Place testes in 15 ml tube with ~10 ml of testes solution.
Label tube: Label tube with stock number and date of testes dissection.
Refrigerate: Place tube with testes in 4°C refrigerator.
Change solution weekly: Change testes solution once per week to maintain viability.







Notes



Testes can be used up to ~1-2 months when stored this way. Sperm viability decreases over time, so use fresher testes when possible for optimal fertilization rates.

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 49 for stickleback crossing procedures
See ?sec-recipe_ginzbergs for Ginzberg’s Ringers recipe
See ?sec-recipe_testes_solution for testes solution recipe

title: 51  Testes Storage
text:
Associated Papers

None

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text: Introduction

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text:
Purpose: This protocol describes the setup, care, and processing of sentinel fish for the Pacific Stickleback fish room.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: 2010







Note



Sentinel fish are used to monitor the health status of the aquatic system and detect potential disease outbreaks.

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text:
Materials

Dietrich’s fixative (see ?sec-general_recipe_dietrichs_fix)
50 ml tubes
Straight razor

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text:
Solutions

Prepare Dietrich’s Fixative (100 ml) as follows (see ?sec-general_recipe_dietrichs_fix)
Store fixative at room temperature.

30 ml Ethanol (95%)
10 ml Formalin (Formaldehyde 37% solution, histological grade, contains 10-15% methanol, Sigma # F1635)
2 ml Glacial Acetic Acid
58 ml Distilled Water

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text:
Procedure

Location and monitoring of sentinel tanks

Sentinel fish are placed in tanks in both the Summer and Winter rooms.
A subset of a stock cross can be used, allow fish to live in the water system for at least 2 weeks before sampling.
Every 6 months four fish from each tank are fixed with Deitrich’s fixative.
Take fish to the Histology lab for Hematoxylin and Eosin staining and sectioning.
Prepared slides are given to Dr. Kathy Snell for diagnosis.



Fixing of Fish and Sectioning

Fish are euthanized using MS222.
Cut 2 cm segments starting just behind the eye to 2 cm caudally.
Put these segments into Dietrich’s fix for at least 24 hours.
Parafin embedded sagital sections need to be done.
Request cross sections through the gills and into the gut.



Fish to Dr. Kathy Snell

Arrange drop off of slides to Dr. Snell located in Huestis Hall, snellk@uoregon.edu







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish husbandry and health monitoring. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare.

title: 52  Sentinel Fish
text:
Related Protocols

?sec-general_recipe_dietrichs_fix - Dietrich’s fixative recipe

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text: Introduction

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Purpose: This protocol allows for the removal of ecto-parasites from embryos produced from wild-caught stickleback. Use this protocol whenever new fish are added to a pre-existing stickleback rearing system, or whenever stocks are transferred between labs.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: August 25, 2011, update February 29, 2014
IACUC Protocol: Covered under embryo handling and disease prevention procedures







Chemical Hygiene




Wear gloves and eye protection when working with bleach
Work in well-ventilated area
Bleach can damage embryos if exposure time is too long









Important



This procedure is critical for preventing pathogen introduction into established fish colonies. Always bleach embryos from wild-caught fish or when transferring between facilities.

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Materials

Wash bottle and petri dishes
Timer
Wide-blade entomology forceps
Transfer pipettes

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Solutions

6% sodium hypochlorite (standard bleach)
Working stock of bleach: Mix 500 µl of bleach into 1 liter of embryo medium (see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium)
Embryo medium (see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium)

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Procedure

Raise embryos: Raise embryos according to standard crossing and rearing protocols in Chapter 49.
Timing: At 48-60 hours post-fertilization (@ 20°C - at this point most organogenesis is complete) remove embryo medium from petri dishes and rinse embryos once with fresh embryo medium.
Bleach treatment: Fill petri dish with working stock solution of bleach. Swirl and let sit for 1.5 min.







Important Timing



Do not bleach embryos for longer than 1.5 minutes as chorions can thicken and it becomes difficult for embryos to hatch.



Rinse thoroughly: Drain bleach solution from embryos, and wash them three times with fresh embryo medium. This is really important to remove all bleach residue.
Shipping embryos (optional): Replace embryo medium daily. If crosses are done in the field, the embryos can be shipped from day 3 to day 6 post-fertilization. To ship embryos:

Rinse once with embryo medium
Place embryos into a 50ml conical tube (~100 embryos/tube) and fill with fresh embryo medium
Place tubes in a shipping container with wet ice
Separate the tubes from the ice with bubble-wrap and newspapers
Ship the embryos overnight

Receiving shipped embryos: When the embryos arrive at the lab:

Rinse the outside of the containers well before moving into the lab
Allow them to equilibrate to room temp (~20°C)
Place the embryos into petri dishes, rinse once, and add new embryo medium
Rear according to standard protocol in Chapter 49

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 49 for stickleback crossing procedures
See ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium for embryo medium recipe
See Chapter 41 for incubator use and embryo care

title: 53  Embryo Bleaching for Disinfection
text:
Associated Papers

None

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text: Introduction
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes best practices for euthanizing embryonic and larval threespine stickleback.
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Husbandry
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: April 10, 2010, update January 1, 2014
IACUC Protocol: Required for all euthanasia procedures







IACUC Compliance




All euthanasia must be performed by trained personnel
Documented in laboratory records
Follow approved euthanasia protocols
Death must be confirmed before disposal or fixation









Chemical Safety




Tricaine (MS-222) can be absorbed through skin - always wear gloves
Work in well-ventilated area
Dispose of MS-222 solutions according to chemical waste protocols
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Materials

Container to hold fish while being euthanized
Post mortem fixing equipment (if needed)
Morgue (if needed)
95% Ethanol
Gloves
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Solutions

Mesab Stock Solution - see ?sec-general_recipe_mesab for detailed recipe:

4 g tricaine powder
979 ml DD water
~21 ml 1 M Tris (pH 9)
Adjust pH to ~7
Aliquot in 50ml tubes, label with MESAB Stock Solution 4g/L, and store in a -20 freezer
This makes 1 liter of solution

Euthanasia Solution (300 mg/L):

Make Mesab stock solution or obtain an aliquot from the freezer
Make a solution of 3.0 ppt Instant Ocean by adding 0.3 grams of Instant Ocean to 100 ml of DD water
Combine 7.5ml of stock solution into 100 ml of 3 ppt Instant Ocean
Store solution in an amber bottle to protect it from light and add mixed and expiration dates (6 months after being mixed) to the bottle
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Procedure

Procedure for Embryo Euthanasia

Immerse in euthanasia solution: Place embryos into a MS-222 euthanasia solution.
Wait for movement to stop: Leave embryos in solution until movement has stopped, ~ 10 minutes.
Additional confirmation: If fish is to be used for experiments, proceed with fixation or preparation for the experiment. If the fish are to be disposed of, place embryo in 95% ETOH for 5 minutes and then into morgue for disposal.







Notes



The ethanol step is necessary as a startle response is not obvious in unhatched fish. This provides secondary confirmation of death.




Procedure for Larval Euthanasia

Immerse in euthanasia solution: Place larva into a MS-222 euthanasia solution.
Wait and perform tap test: Wait 10 minutes and perform a tap test to look for a startle response.
Repeat if necessary: If there is a response wait 5 minutes and repeat startle response test. Repeat this step every 5 minutes as needed.
Confirm death: If there is no response, death is confirmed. Move to fixing for post mortem experiments or place in morgue.
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Related Protocols

See Chapter 37 for adult euthanasia
See ?sec-general_recipe_mesab for MS-222 solution preparation
See Chapter 49 for stickleback crossing procedures
See Chapter 44 for anesthesia procedures (non-lethal)
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia
text:
Associated Papers

AVMA Guidelines for the Euthanasia of Animals: 2020 Edition
None (lab-specific publications)
crumbs: 54  Stickleback Embryo and Larval Euthanasia

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text: Introduction

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text:
Purpose: The procedure describes how to introduce wild caught gulf pipefish into our aquaculture systems.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey

Date Created: February 29, 2024







Important



Wild pipefish will arrive very stressed out so they need to be handled carefully.

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text:
Materials

Empty 20 gallon Tank
Clean 5 gallon bucket

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text:
Solutions

none

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text:
Procedure

When pipefish arrive remove them from packaging and float them in system water for 15-30 minutes to acclimate to the temperature.
Pour contents of each bag of pipefish into a 5 gallon bucket.
Slowly acclimate the new pipefish by adding 1/4 - 1/2 gallon of system water to the 5 gallon bucket over the course of a few hours. Do this until most of the water in the bucket is system water.
Move pipefish (not water) to clean 20 gallon tank.
Feed lightly for 2-3 days as the fish acclimate to captivity. Slowly introduce frozen mysids along with live mysids.







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish husbandry and wild fish introduction. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare and quarantine procedures.

title: 55  Wild Pipefish Introduction
text:
Related Protocols

Chapter 57 - Pipefish water system maintenance

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text: Introduction

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text:
Purpose: The procedure describes how to set up pipefish for crossing.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey

Date Created: February 29, 2024







Note



Pipefish are housed communally or kept as pairs and allowed to naturally spawn.

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text:
Materials

Empty 20 gallon Tank

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text:
Solutions

none

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text:
Procedure

Setting up crosses

House pairs of adults or groups of mixed sex pipefish in a 20 gallon tank.
Check tanks each day to look for pregnant males.
Place pregnant males singly in 4.5 L tanks containing plastic grass with a 850 mesh baffle installed.
Once the male has given birth move him to a 20 gallon tank.







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish breeding. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare.

title: 56  Pipefish Crossing
text:
Related Protocols

title: 57  Pipefish Water System Maintenance
text: Introduction

title: 57  Pipefish Water System Maintenance
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes maintenance of the pipefish recirculating system. The pipefish system is a ~ 500 gallon recirculating salt water system. Water parameters: 25C, 25ppt salinity, no ammonia, no nitrites, and nitrates below 40 ppm.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey

Date Created: February 29, 2024

title: 57  Pipefish Water System Maintenance
text:
Materials

Clean 20 gallon tanks
Clean tank hardware
Plastic plants
Gravel vacuum

title: 57  Pipefish Water System Maintenance
text:
Procedure
20 gallon adult pipefish tanks






Note



All 20 gallon pipefish tanks are cleaned and reset at least once a month.



Complete take down and cleaning

After transferring fish to a clean tank, take down the old tank as described in ?sec-vert_husb-aquarium_cleaning, but leave the bulkhead on and keep the substrate in the tank.
Put the strainer catch over the drain in the sink to prevent substrate from clogging the drain. Tilt the tank vertically so the substrate pools in the back.
Reset tank as described in ?sec-vert_husb-aquarium_cleaning, but add at least 2 clean plastic plants to the tank for enrichment.
Circulate clean tanks 30 minutes before transferring fish.








Note



If there are not enough open tanks to completely clean and reset 3-5 per week, use the gravel vac to clean all occupied tanks at least 1x per week:



Gravel Vac cleaning

Use an empty bucket (with drain drilled in) to catch the water siphoned out of each tank.
Rinse gravel vac and tube with RO water.
Turn off water and air flow to the tank being cleaned.
Create a siphon with the gravel vac to begin draining the tank water into the bin. Keep a section of the gravel vac hose near the end pinched to control suction by pinching down to stop and releasing slightly to restart. Agitate substrate by “fluffing” up and down with the gravel vac.








Caution



Do not allow water level to be drained below 5-6 inches in the sump. Immediately stop suction if a pipefish enters the gravel vac. Check the bin for any pipefish that may have been accidentally sucked into the gravel vac before moving to the next tank.


10.5 L pipefish fry tanks






Note



Fry are generally large enough to be transferred to clean 10L tanks at 2 months post-birth.



Set up new 10.5 L tanks band place a clean small plastic plant in the tank for enrichment.
Uneaten food will build up quickly. Use a turkey baster and muck bucket to spot clean 2x per week or as needed.
Replace the back 850 screen baffle in tanks when they appear clogged.

Changing water in the system






Note



10-20% of the system water should be changed every week.



Drain system water by attaching a hose to one of the 20 gallon tanks supply placing the other end of the hose in the corner room drain. Turn on valve and allow water to drain until the water level is 3-5 inches above the basket that supplies the system pump (located left side of largest sump under 20 gallon rack).
The makeup water vat should be full. Check makeup water salinity with a refractometer. Target salinity is ~25 ppt. Adjust salinity by adding salt or RO water if necessary. Put the end of the makeup water hose into the small sump.
Turn makeup water pump on until makeup water drops to the drain line marked on the outside of the makeup water vat, then turn off. Lift the makeup water hose out of the sump and rest on the rim of the makeup water vat.
To reset the makeup water vat, use the RO located in the northeast corner of the room to fill the vat up to the fill line. This take about 15 minutes.
Use a 5 L beaker to measure 2.5 L of instant ocean and pour into makeup water vat. Recheck salinity after several minutes and adjust as necessary.







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish husbandry. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare and water quality standards.

title: 57  Pipefish Water System Maintenance
text:

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text: Introduction

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes best practices for euthanizing adult pipefish.
Procedure Type: Husbandry
Species:

Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey

Date Created: February 29, 2024

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text:
Materials

Container to hold fish while being euthanized.
Post mortem fixing equipment
Morgue

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text:
Solutions






Note



Tricaine must be pharmaceutical-grade. We use tricaine purchased from Pentair, manufactured by Western Chemical and FDA approved. Tricaine (3-amino benzoic acid ethyl lester also called ethyl m-aminoboenzoate) comes in a powdered form. Purchase the smallest amount possible because tricaine expires quickly.



Euthanasia strength Mesab (see below and ?sec-general_recipe_mesab)
Mesab Stock Solution (4g/L From Zebrafish Book 4th edition) (tris buffered):

4 g tricaine powder
979 ml DD water
~21 ml 1 M Tris (pH 9).
Adjust pH to ~7.
Aliquot in 50ml tubes, label with MESAB Stock Solution 4g/L, and store in a -20 freezer.
This makes 1 liter of solution.

Euthanasia Solution (300 mg/L):

Make a solution of tris buffered Stock Solution as described above. (Or obtain an aliquot from the freezer)
Make a solution of 3.0 ppt Instant Ocean by adding 0.3 grams of Instant Ocean to 100 ml of DD water.
Combine 7.5ml of stock solution into 100 ml of 3 ppt Instant Ocean.
Store solution in an amber bottle to protect it from light and add mixed and expiration dates (6 months after being mixed) to the bottle.

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text:
Procedure

Place fish in euthanasia strength mesab and wait 10 minutes.
To confirm death wait ten minutes after opercular movement has stopped and perform a tap test. TO do this gently tap on the table next to the container holding the fish. If the fish is still alive this will trigger a startle response, wait 5 more minutes and repeat tap test. If no response, proceed to fixing for post mortem experiments or place fish in the morgue.







IACUC Protocol



This procedure is covered under the University of Oregon IACUC protocol for fish euthanasia. Euthanasia must be performed using approved methods and only by trained personnel. Always follow approved protocols for animal welfare.

title: 58  Pipefish Adult Euthanasia
text:
Related Protocols

?sec-general_recipe_mesab - Mesab stock solution recipe
Chapter 38 - Pipefish embryo and larval euthanasia
Chapter 33 - Daily health checks

title: Vertebrate Experiment
text: This section of the manual contains protocols for the safe and ethical experimental use of vertebrate animals, particular the fish models stickleback, zebrafish and syngnathids.

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text: Introduction

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Purpose: Describe procedures for the collection of fish blood
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)
Zebrafish, (Danio rerio)

Author: Ann Petersen
Date Created: August 1, 2011







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol. Ensure your protocol covers terminal blood collection procedures before beginning. All personnel must be trained in proper euthanasia techniques.








Human Safety Measures




Wear gloves at all times when handling blood collection equipment. While this will not prevent accidents, it may reduce the risk of contamination.
Never attempt to re-sheath needles. Always discard them into a sharps container immediately after use.
Never overfill the sharps container.
Place the sharps container in the area you are working to avoid transporting needles outside of your work area.
Ensure the work area is clean.
Wash hands after handling fish blood.
Follow all biosafety protocols when working with blood samples.

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Materials

Gloves to be worn when handling fish, anesthesia water, blood samples
Disinfectant for cleaning after blood sample
Scalpel or sharp knife for tail ablation
Sterile needles or vacutainer needles from 14-30 gauge
Syringe for collecting samples
Heparinized hematocrit tubes/capillary tubes
Critoseal
Sharps container for needles
Whatman 903 Specimen collection paper
Microhematocrit centrifuge

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Solutions

Euthanasia MS-222 (tricaine-methanesulfonate) - see ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Procedure






Before You Begin



Ensure all materials are prepared and readily accessible before euthanizing the fish. Work quickly to minimize blood coagulation.



Place fish in beaker containing MS-222 euthanasia dose (300 mg/L).
Wait for fish to slow and become unresponsive to taps on the container to ensure it is fully euthanized (lack of opercular movement for at least 1 minute).
Sever the caudal peduncle with a scalpel blade or sharp knife.
For hematocrit analysis: Fill a heparinized hematocrit tube/capillary tube with the blood as it flows from the caudal vein. Plug one end of the hematocrit tube with critoseal. Spin on microhematocrit centrifuge to separate plasma from red blood cells. Measure hematocrit volume %. Use a pipette or break the capillary to extract the plasma or packed cells as needed.
For filter paper collection: Alternatively, collect a 25μL drop of blood at the tail and allow it to drop onto Whatman specimen collection filter paper for some endocrinological downstream applications. Blood spotted filter paper must be dried for 4 hours on the bench away from heat and light, and then may be stored at -20°C in a sealed bag with desiccant packs.
Dispose of fish soma and tail in fish morgue according to institutional guidelines.
Clean and disinfect area where blood was collected with appropriate disinfectant.

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Related Protocols

Euthanasia protocols: ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia
Steroid measurements from blood: Chapter 75

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Blood clots quickly: Ensure hematocrit tubes are properly heparinized and work rapidly after euthanasia.
Insufficient blood volume: For small fish, consider cardiac puncture methods (requires additional training and IACUC approval).
Hemolysis: Avoid excessive handling and agitation of blood samples.

title: 59  Fish Blood Collection
text:
References

Standard methods for fish blood collection and analysis
IACUC guidelines for fish euthanasia and tissue collection

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text: Introduction

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to pull needles for microinjections of embryos.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Zebrafish, (Danio rerio)

Author: Susie Bassham
Date Created: March 1, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



If using these needles for embryo injections, ensure your IACUC protocol covers microinjection procedures.








Background



Properly pulled needles are critical for successful microinjections. The needle must be thin enough to penetrate the chorion without dragging the embryo, yet strong enough not to bend during penetration. The exact pulling parameters may need to be optimized for your specific needle puller and capillary type.

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Materials

Filament capillaries (1.2 mm OD/0.69 mm ID) - for zebrafish
Needle puller (e.g., Sutter Instrument P-97 or equivalent)
Fine-tip permanent marker for labeling
Petri dish or needle holder for storing pulled needles

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Solutions

Not applicable for this protocol

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Procedure

Prepare the needle puller:

Turn on the needle puller and allow it to warm up.
Select Program 1 (or appropriate program for your puller model).

Set pulling parameters:

Set pressure range from 140 to 200 PSI in 20 PSI increments.
Adjust heat and pull settings as needed for your specific puller.

Load capillary:

Place a filament capillary (1.2 mm OD/0.69 mm ID) into the needle puller.
Ensure the capillary is centered and secure.

Pull the needle:

Activate the pulling program.
The puller will heat and pull the capillary to create a fine tip.

Inspect the needle:

Examine the pulled needle under a dissecting microscope.
The tip should be long, thin, and have a gradual taper.
The opening should be fine enough for embryo injection.

Store and label:

Mark the needle appropriately with pressure settings used.
Store in a safe location (e.g., petri dish with clay or dedicated needle holder).
Keep track of which pulling parameters produce the best needles.








Optimization Tips




Test different PSI settings to find the optimal needle shape for your application.
Keep a log of pulling parameters that work best for different injection types.
Pull multiple needles at once to have backups ready during injection sessions.
If needles are too fragile, decrease the pull time or heat; if too blunt, increase these parameters.

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Related Protocols

Embryo injections: Chapter 70
CRISPR/Cas9 injections: Chapter 76
Stickleback crossing for embryo collection: Chapter 49

title: 60  Needle Pulling for Injections
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Needles too fragile: Reduce heat or pull time in the program settings.
Needles too blunt: Increase heat or pull time.
Inconsistent results: Check that capillaries are properly centered and the filament is intact.
Needle bends during injection: Use a thicker-walled capillary or adjust pulling parameters for a stronger needle.

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text: Introduction

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to perform in situ hybridization on whole mount embryos for immunohistochemistry applications.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Susan Bassham
Date Created: March 1, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering tissue fixation and processing. Ensure all personnel are properly trained.








Chemical Safety




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses) when handling paraformaldehyde (PFA).
Work in a fume hood when preparing or using PFA solutions.
PFA is a fixative and potential carcinogen - handle with care.
Acetone is flammable - keep away from ignition sources.
Sodium azide is toxic - handle with care and dispose of properly.

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Materials

Ice
Distilled water
Primary antibody (e.g., mouse anti-fish specific antibody)
Secondary antibody (e.g., goat anti-mouse)
Tertiary antibody (e.g., mouse PAP - peroxidase-antiperoxidase)
Water bath or incubator (35-40°C)
Shaker/rocker (optional, for antibody incubations)
Microcentrifuge tubes or small vials for embryo processing

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Solutions

8% PFA - see ?sec-general_recipe_8%PFA
BT fix: 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS
0.1 M sodium citrate buffer, pH 6.4
Citrate buffer with sodium azide: 0.1 M citrate buffer containing 0.1% sodium azide
Acetone (stored at -20°C for permeabilization step)
Blocking solution: 2% normal goat serum in wash solution
Wash solution: PBS containing 1% BSA, 1% DMSO, 0.2% Triton X-100

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Procedure

Day 1: Fixation

Fix embryos in BT Fix for 4 to 6 hours on ice or at 4°C (see notes below for fixative composition considerations).



Day 1-2: Modified Antigen Retrieval

Wash embryos in 0.1 M sodium citrate buffer, pH 6.4, for 5 minutes.
Replace with fresh citrate buffer containing 0.1% sodium azide.
Incubate overnight in 35-40°C water bath (see optimization notes below).



Day 2: Acetone Permeabilization

Wash in distilled water for 5 minutes.
Transfer to acetone at -20°C for 7 minutes to permeabilize the tissue.
Wash in distilled water for 5 minutes.
Wash in 0.1 M citrate buffer for 5 minutes.



Day 2-3: Immunohistochemistry

Treat with blocking solution (2% normal goat serum in wash solution) to block nonspecific binding sites for 30 minutes at room temperature.
Incubate with primary antibody (e.g., mouse anti-fish) diluted in blocking solution:

5 hours at room temperature, OR
Overnight at 4°C
Optional: Use a shaker or rocker to facilitate antibody penetration.

Wash for approximately 2 hours with frequent changes of wash solution (every 15-20 minutes).
Incubate with secondary antibody (e.g., goat anti-mouse) diluted in wash solution:

Overnight at 4°C, OR
5 hours at room temperature

Wash for approximately 2 hours with frequent changes of wash solution.
If using a tertiary antibody: Incubate with tertiary antibody (e.g., mouse PAP) diluted in wash buffer:

Overnight at 4°C, OR
5 hours at room temperature

Wash for approximately 2 hours with frequent changes of wash solution.
If required: Develop enzyme-mediated stain according to the specific detection system being used.

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Optimization Notes






Fixative Composition



Comparative testing of different aldehyde fixatives showed:

4% paraformaldehyde in phosphate buffer (pH 7.3): Poorly and incompletely stained.
BT fix or 4% PFA in PBS: Demonstrated robust staining throughout the head and trunk of the fish (BT-fixed fish showed slightly better results).
BT fix components: The 4% sucrose in BT fix was required for high-quality staining.
Calcium in BT fix: The quality of staining in fish fixed in BT fixative without calcium was comparable to that of fish fixed in BT fix containing 0.15 mM calcium chloride.

Recommendation: Use BT fix or 4% PFA in PBS for optimal results.








Modified Antigen Retrieval Optimization



Antigen-retrieval methods were first introduced in the early 1990s and have been widely adopted by the clinical community as a way to recover antigenicity in paraffin sections.
Temperature optimization: Several studies have demonstrated that heat is one of the most important variables in antigen retrieval (Brain Res 632:105-113, 1993; Pathol Int 44:759-764, 1994; APMIS 102:295-307, 1994).
Experimental results: - Overnight incubations were tested at four temperatures: 4°C, room temperature, 37°C, and 44°C. - 4°C or room temperature: 5-day embryos were poorly and incompletely stained. - 37°C and 44°C: Embryos were stained robustly throughout the head and trunk. - 44°C: High background staining was observed. - 37°C: No background staining present - optimal temperature.
Recommendation: Use 37-40°C for overnight incubation. Embryos incubated at 4°C can serve as negative controls.
