text:
Related Protocols

Paraformaldehyde solution preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_8%PFA
Live staining protocols for comparison with whole mount techniques

title: 61  Whole Mount In situ Hybridization
text:
Associated Papers

Antigen Retrieval Techniques: Immunohistochemistry and Molecular Morphology, S-R Shi, J Gu and CR Taylor, Eds., Eaton Publishing, Natick, MA, 2000.

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text: Introduction
crumbs: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text:
Purpose: Effectively stain fixed fish with Alcian Blue and Alizarin Red using a non-acidic method that preserves DNA integrity.
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)
Zebrafish, (Danio rerio)
and others

Author: Macie B. Walker (Adapted by Mark Currey 7/9/13)
Date Created: July 9, 2013







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering tissue fixation and staining. Ensure specimens are properly euthanized before fixation.








Chemical Safety




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses) when handling fixatives and stains.
Paraformaldehyde (PFA) is a potential carcinogen - handle with care in a fume hood.
Hydrogen peroxide can cause burns - handle with care.
Potassium hydroxide (KOH) is corrosive - avoid skin contact.
Follow proper chemical waste disposal procedures.
crumbs: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text:
Background and Purpose
Alcian blue is a basic dye which stains acidic mucopolysaccharides. Traditionally alcian staining has utilized acidic conditions to stain cartilage. As acidic conditions negatively affect bone staining, simultaneous cartilage and bone staining is problematic. Also, since acid conditions destroy DNA, embryos to be alcian stained by the acid method AND also prepped for DNA have to be dissected into heads for alcian and tails for DNA. This process is laborious.
The protocols below use MgCl2 rather than acid to differentiate staining, preserving DNA integrity while allowing simultaneous cartilage and bone visualization.






Scale and Volumes




Zebrafish embryos (4-6 dpf): Up to 100 embryos can be stained in a 1.5 ml tube, using 1 ml of stain/washes per tube.
Young adult zebrafish (6 months old): Use 8X volume of stain/washes per volume of fish (roughly 40 ml solution per 20 fish).
All steps are at room temperature with rocking unless otherwise noted.




Important Considerations






Bone Stain Sensitivity



Bone staining is sensitive to protocol changes. It is easy to reduce or lose bone stain.
Common issues: - Reduction of bone stain is apparent when certain regions do not stain well (e.g., OP staining reduced in skirt region, Mx & den staining reduced or gone). - Staining tends to remain in denser regions such as CB5.
Factors that reduce bone staining: - Overfixation (even by just a few hours) - Extended alizarin staining (overnight vs. 30 min - longer is not necessarily better) - Incomplete bleach removal (especially when many embryos are stained in one tube) - Trypsinization (even minimal amounts can dramatically reduce bone stain) - Detergents (Tween at 0.05% can wipe out bone stain)
Recommendation: Follow protocol as written initially, then make adjustments as needed for your specific application.




Protocol Variations
For DNA preparations after staining: Rinse out 50% glycerol/0.1% KOH with 2X quick rinses in low TE plus a squirt of PBSTw. Sort embryos into 96-well plate, remove excess liquid, and lyse under standard conditions. The Tween in PBSTw will help prevent the embryos from getting sticky, but will also remove the bone stain.
For cartilage-only staining: Longer fixes, even 4% PFA overnight, are fine. Cellular detail, including muscles, ligaments, and cartilage nuclei are quite good under Nomarski optics.
For bone-only staining: PFA-fixed embryos have decreased bone fluorescence. For better bone fluorescence, fix and stain in 95% ethanol/0.01% alizarin overnight (one step). Do not use MgCl2 in washes, and extend washes to 10 minutes. Embryos will be soft due to light fixation.






Staining Theory



For a brief discussion of stain theory describing use of pH and salt to control staining, see: http://stainsfile.info/StainsFile/jindex.html
crumbs: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text:
Materials

containers to hold fish and solutions
rocker
crumbs: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text:
Solutions

Solutions for embryos

2% PFA/1X PBS pH 7.5
For 1 ml, add:

250ul 8% PFA
100ul 10X PBS
650ul water
100mM Tris pH 7.5/10mM MgCl2

0.2% alcian blue/90% ETOH







Preparation Note



Alcian blue will not readily dissolve in 90% ETOH. To make 100 ml: add 0.2 g alcian blue 8GX powder to 11.2 ml 50% ETOH. Warm and occasionally swirl. When all is dissolved, add 95% ETOH to 100 ml. Check clarity of solution under a microscope to make sure there are no precipitates.



0.04% Alcian/10mM MgCl2 Stain pH 7.5 Final concentrations:

0.04% alcian blue
80 % ETOH
100mM Tris pH 7.5
10mM MgCl2

To make 50 mls, add:

10ml 0.2% alcian blue in 90% ETOH
5ml 1M Tris pH 7.5
0.5ml 1M MgCl2
32.6ml 95% ETOH
1.9ml water


For Ethanol rehydrations (To make 50 ml of each):

80% ETOH/10 mM MgCl2:

42.1 ml 95% ETOH
5 ml 1M Tris pH 7.5
0.5 ml 1M MgCl2
2.4 ml water

50% ETOH:

26.3 ml 95% ETOH
5 ml 1M Tris pH 7.5
18.7 ml water

25% ETOH:

13.2 ml 95% ETOH
5 ml 1M Tris pH 7.5
31.8 ml water

0.5% alizarin red S (To make 50 ml):

0.25 g alizarin red S powder
50 ml water

3% H2O2/0.5% KOH (Mix just before using):

0.5 ml 6% H2O2
0.5 ml 1% KOH
(or adjust to desired final volume)

50% Isopropanol (To make 50 ml):

25 ml H2O
25 ml Isopropanol
crumbs: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method

title: 62  Alcian and Alizarin Double Stain - No Acid Method
text:
Procedure

Fixation: Fix in 2% PFA/1X PBS for 1 hour.







Fixation Time Optimization



Fixing times can vary depending on the size of the specimen. For 5-10 mm stickleback and pipefish, a fix of 2-3 hours is sufficient. Do not overfix as this can reduce bone staining quality.



Rehydration: Rinse in 50% ETOH/water for 10 minutes.
Double staining: Add 0.04% Alcian Blue/0.01% Alizarin Red S/10 mM MgCl2/80% ETOH.

Add Alizarin Red just before use (add 20 μl 0.5% alizarin red per 1 ml of 0.04% alcian stock).








Staining Time



With very small specimens it’s very easy to overstain. Check amount of staining every 30 minutes until the desired level of staining has been achieved.
Important: Store stock as 0.04% Alcian Blue/10 mM MgCl2/80% ETOH (without alizarin red). Add alizarin fresh for each use.



First rinse: Rinse in 80% ETOH/10 mM MgCl2/water for 10 minutes to overnight.

Note: Cleaner Alcian background with longer rinses.

Rehydration: Rinse in 50% ETOH/water for 5 minutes.
Rehydration: Rinse in 25% ETOH/water for 5 minutes.
Bleaching: Treat with 3% H2O2/0.5% KOH for 10 minutes with lids open.
Rinse: Rinse thoroughly with water.
Clearing: Rinse with 50% Isopropanol.
Storage: Store in 50% Isopropanol.

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text: Introduction

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to live stain fish with alizarin to visualize mineralized bone
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 01, 2024, updated November 22, 2025
IACUC Protocol: Required for live animal procedures







Safety and Handling




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
Alizarin is a dye that can stain skin and clothing
Keep staining solutions in dark containers to prevent degradation
Dispose of staining solutions according to chemical waste protocols

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Background
Alizarin red S is a calcium-binding dye that selectively binds to mineralized bone tissue, making it fluorescent under specific wavelengths. This allows for in vivo visualization of the skeleton in live fish without fixation. The staining is reversible, allowing fish to recover and be used for subsequent experiments or returned to normal husbandry.

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Materials

Large Petri dishes (100mm diameter) or small tanks
Darkened containers or aluminum foil
Transfer pipettes
Alizarin Red S powder (SIGMA cat# A5533, certified)
Sterile water
NaOH solution (10%)
pH meter or pH strips

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Solutions

Alizarin Stock Solution (0.5% or 1%)

0.5% Stock: 0.5g Alizarin Red S in 100ml sterile water
1.0% Stock: 1.0g Alizarin Red S in 100ml sterile water (or 0.5g in 50ml)
Store in dark bottle at room temperature for up to 6 months
Make fresh if precipitation occurs



Staining Solutions
Preparation varies by species due to different osmotic requirements:

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


For 1 Liter (large scale):

990 ml embryo medium (see ?sec-recipe-embryo_medium)
10 ml Alizarin stock (0.5% or 1%)
Final concentration: 0.005% or 0.01%
Adjust to pH 7.5 with NaOH

For 50 ml (single petri dish):

49.5 ml embryo medium
500 µl Alizarin stock (0.5% or 1%)
Adjust to pH 7.5 with NaOH



For 1 Liter (large scale):

990 ml 25 ppt Instant Ocean (artificial seawater)
10 ml Alizarin stock (0.5% or 1%)
Final concentration: 0.005% or 0.01%
Adjust to pH 7.5 with NaOH

For 50 ml (single petri dish):

49.5 ml 25 ppt Instant Ocean
500 µl Alizarin stock (0.5% or 1%)
Adjust to pH 7.5 with NaOH






Additional Solutions

MESAB anesthesia strength (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_stickleback for stickleback, ?sec-husbandry_anesth_pipefish for pipefish)
MESAB euthanasia strength (see Chapter 54 for stickleback, Chapter 38 for pipefish)

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Procedure

Preparation (Day Before if Possible)

Prepare staining solution fresh or use within 1 week of preparation
Verify pH is 7.5 ± 0.2
Cover container with aluminum foil to protect from light
Pre-label all containers with fish ID, date, and treatment



Staining Protocol






Staining Duration Guidelines




Larvae: 1-2 hours
Juveniles: 2-6 hours
Adults: Overnight (8-16 hours)
Longer exposures generally produce brighter staining but monitor fish welfare




Transfer fish to container with staining solution

Use appropriate volume (50ml for 1-5 larvae, 500ml-1L for larger fish)
Ensure adequate oxygenation for overnight staining (gentle aeration or frequent water changes)

Incubate in darkness

Cover container with aluminum foil or place in dark location
Maintain appropriate temperature (16-20°C for stickleback, 18-22°C for pipefish)

Monitor fish during staining period

Check every 30-60 minutes for shorter staining periods
Check every 2-4 hours for overnight staining
Ensure fish are swimming normally and not stressed




De-staining and Imaging

Rinse fish to remove background staining

Transfer fish to fresh medium/seawater (appropriate for species)
Rinse for 30 minutes minimum
Background fluorescence will continue to decrease over time
Can perform 2-3 rinses for better signal-to-background ratio

Optional: Sequential DASPEI staining

If desired, proceed to DASPEI live staining (see Chapter 65)
DASPEI can be performed on already alizarin-stained fish

Anesthetize for imaging

Place fish in anesthesia solution (appropriate strength for species)
Wait until movement slows sufficiently for safe handling
Aim for light plane of anesthesia (reduced gill movement, loss of equilibrium)

Observe and image

Alizarin fluorescence: Excitation ~530-560nm, Emission ~570-600nm (red)
Plan imaging for same day as staining for best results
Keep fish in dark between imaging sessions to preserve fluorescence








Important Imaging Notes




Bone fluorescence decreases over time - plan to image within 24 hours of staining
Keep fish in darkness as much as possible to preserve fluorescence
Use minimal exposure to excitation light to prevent photobleaching





Recovery

Transfer fish to recovery tank

Use fresh medium/seawater at appropriate temperature
Ensure adequate oxygenation

Monitor recovery

Check fish every 5-10 minutes
Look for return of normal swimming behavior
Typical recovery time: 5-20 minutes depending on anesthesia depth

Return to system or proceed to next step

If recovering well: return to normal husbandry system
Monitor during next daily health check
If proceeding to fixation: transfer to euthanasia solution (see appropriate euthanasia SOP for species)

title: 63  Live Alizarin Staining
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




Weak or no staining
pH too low/high
Verify pH is 7.5 ± 0.2



Old alizarin stock
Make fresh stock solution



Insufficient staining time
Increase staining duration


High background
Insufficient rinsing
Extend rinse period or do multiple rinses



Staining solution too concentrated
Use lower concentration (0.005% instead of 0.01%)


Fish stress/mortality
Staining solution too concentrated
Dilute solution to 0.005%



Inadequate oxygenation
Add gentle aeration or change solution every 4 hours


Rapid fluorescence loss
Excessive light exposure
Keep fish in dark; minimize excitation light



Too much time post-staining
Image within 24 hours of staining

text:

Du, S. J., Frenkel, V., Kindschi, G., & Zohar, Y. (2001). Visualizing normal and defective bone development in zebrafish embryos using the fluorescent chromophore calcein. Developmental Biology, 238(2), 239-246. doi:10.1006/dbio.2001.0390
Walker, M. B., & Kimmel, C. B. (2007). A two-color acid-free cartilage and bone stain for zebrafish larvae. Biotechnic & Histochemistry, 82(1), 23-28.

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text: Introduction

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to live stain fish with calcein to visualize mineralized bone
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey, adapted from DOI: 10.1006/dbio.2001.0390
Date Created: January 01, 2024, updated November 22, 2025
IACUC Protocol: Required for live animal procedures







Safety and Handling




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
Calcein is a fluorescent dye that can stain skin and clothing
Keep staining solutions in dark containers to prevent photobleaching
Dispose of staining solutions according to chemical waste protocols
Handle fish gently during all stages to minimize stress

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Background
Calcein is a fluorescent compound that binds to calcium in mineralized bone tissue, making it visible under fluorescence microscopy. Unlike alizarin which binds to the surface of mineralized structures, calcein is incorporated into actively mineralizing bone, making it particularly useful for visualizing bone formation and growth. This allows for in vivo visualization of the skeleton in live fish without fixation. The staining is reversible, allowing fish to recover and be used for subsequent experiments or returned to normal husbandry.
Calcein fluoresces green when excited with blue light (excitation ~495nm, emission ~515nm), providing excellent contrast and can be used in combination with other fluorescent markers like alizarin red (red fluorescence) or DASPEI (yellow-green fluorescence for neuromasts).

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Materials

Large Petri dishes (100mm diameter) or 1L tanks
Darkened containers or aluminum foil
Transfer pipettes
Calcein powder (Molecular Probes; cat# C481)
Sterile water or appropriate base medium
10% NaOH solution
pH meter or pH strips

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Solutions

Calcein Stock Solution

0.5% Stock: 0.5g calcein in 100ml sterile water
Store in dark bottle at 4°C for up to 3 months
Make fresh if precipitation occurs or fluorescence diminishes



Staining Solutions
Preparation varies by species due to different osmotic requirements:

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Working Solution:

0.005% to 0.05% calcein in embryo medium (see ?sec-recipe-embryo_medium)
For 100ml: Add 1-10ml of 0.5% stock to embryo medium
Adjust to pH 8.2 with 10% NaOH
Make fresh, keep in dark

Recommended concentration:

Larvae: 0.005-0.01% (1-2ml stock in 100ml)
Juveniles/Adults: 0.01-0.05% (2-10ml stock in 100ml)



Working Solution:

0.005% to 0.05% calcein in artificial seawater
Use 25 ppt Instant Ocean or natural seawater
For 100ml: Add 1-10ml of 0.5% stock to seawater
Adjust to pH 8.2 with 10% NaOH
Make fresh, keep in dark

Recommended concentration:

Larvae: 0.005-0.01% (1-2ml stock in 100ml)
Juveniles/Adults: 0.01-0.05% (2-10ml stock in 100ml)






Additional Solutions

MESAB anesthesia strength (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_stickleback for stickleback, ?sec-husbandry_anesth_pipefish for pipefish)
MESAB euthanasia strength (see Chapter 54 for stickleback, Chapter 38 for pipefish)

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Procedure

Preparation (Day Before if Possible)

Prepare staining solution fresh or use within 1 week of preparation
Verify pH is 8.2 ± 0.2
Cover container with aluminum foil to protect from light
Pre-label all containers with fish ID, date, and treatment



Staining Protocol






Staining Duration Guidelines




Larvae: 1-2 hours
Juveniles: 2-6 hours (up to overnight)
Adults: 4 hours to overnight
Longer exposures generally produce brighter staining but monitor fish welfare
Fish can tolerate extended exposure without adverse effects




Transfer fish to container with staining solution

Larvae: Use Petri dishes with 50-100ml staining solution
Juveniles/Adults: Use 1L tanks or larger containers with appropriate volume
Ensure adequate volume for fish size and number (minimum 50ml per small fish)
Ensure adequate oxygenation for overnight staining (gentle aeration if needed)

Incubate in darkness

Cover container with aluminum foil or place in dark location
Maintain appropriate temperature:

Stickleback: 16-20°C
Pipefish: 18-22°C


Monitor fish during staining period

Check every 30-60 minutes for short staining periods (1-2 hours)
Check every 2-4 hours for extended staining periods
Ensure fish are swimming normally and not stressed
Stagger fish if imaging multiple individuals to avoid over-staining








Monitoring Staining Progress



For critical experiments, you can check staining intensity by briefly anesthetizing one fish and imaging under fluorescence microscopy, then returning it to the staining solution if more time is needed.




De-staining and Recovery

Rinse fish to remove background staining

Transfer fish to fresh medium/seawater (appropriate for species)
Rinse for 20-60 minutes minimum
Background fluorescence will continue to decrease over time
Can perform 2-3 rinses of 30 minutes each for better signal-to-background ratio

Optional: Sequential staining

If desired, proceed to DASPEI live staining (see Chapter 65)
DASPEI can be performed on already calcein-stained fish
Alizarin staining (see Chapter 63) can also be combined but may require optimization




Imaging

Anesthetize for imaging

Place fish in anesthesia solution (appropriate strength for species)
Wait until fish reaches a light plane of anesthesia
Aim for reduced gill movement and loss of equilibrium but not complete cessation of breathing

Observe and image

Calcein fluorescence: Excitation ~495nm, Emission ~515nm (green)
Bone fluorescence will decrease over time - plan to image same day if possible
Keep fish in the dark as much as reasonably convenient between imaging sessions
Use minimal exposure to excitation light to prevent photobleaching








Important Imaging Notes




Bone fluorescence decreases over time - plan to image within 24 hours of staining
Keep fish in darkness between imaging sessions to preserve fluorescence
Use minimal exposure to excitation light to prevent photobleaching
Consider batch processing: stagger staining start times if imaging multiple fish





Recovery

Transfer fish to recovery container

Use clean system water or fresh medium at appropriate temperature
Place in container of fish water
Ensure adequate oxygenation

Monitor recovery

Check fish every 5-10 minutes until revived
Look for return of normal swimming behavior and equilibrium
Typical recovery time: 5-20 minutes depending on anesthesia depth

Return to system or proceed to next step

Once fish is revived and swimming upright: return to fish system
Monitor during daily health checks
If proceeding to fixation: transfer to euthanasia solution (see appropriate euthanasia SOP for species)

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




Weak or no staining
pH too low/high
Verify pH is 8.2 ± 0.2



Old calcein stock
Make fresh stock solution



Insufficient staining time
Increase staining duration



Concentration too low
Use higher concentration (0.05% for adults)


High background fluorescence
Insufficient rinsing
Extend rinse period or do multiple rinses



Staining solution too concentrated
Use lower concentration (0.005-0.01%)



Inadequate dark adaptation
Keep fish in dark for longer before imaging


Fish stress/mortality
Staining solution too concentrated
Dilute solution to 0.005-0.01%



Inadequate oxygenation
Add gentle aeration or change solution



Overcrowding
Reduce number of fish per container


Rapid fluorescence loss
Excessive light exposure
Keep fish in dark; minimize excitation light



Too much time post-staining
Image within 24 hours of staining


Uneven staining
Fish not fully submerged
Ensure adequate solution volume



Dead/dying tissue
Check fish health before staining

title: 64  Live Calcein Staining
text:
Associated Papers

Du, S. J., Frenkel, V., Kindschi, G., & Zohar, Y. (2001). Visualizing normal and defective bone development in zebrafish embryos using the fluorescent chromophore calcein. Developmental Biology, 238(2), 239-246. doi:10.1006/dbio.2001.0390
Walker, M. B., & Kimmel, C. B. (2007). A two-color acid-free cartilage and bone stain for zebrafish larvae. Biotechnic & Histochemistry, 82(1), 23-28.
xxx (add lab-specific publications)

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text: Introduction

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to live stain fish with DASPEI to visualize neuromasts (lateral line hair cells)
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Susan Bassham
Date Created: October 25, 2021, updated November 22, 2025
Source: Adapted from DOI: 10.1007/s10162-002-3022-x
IACUC Protocol: Required for live animal procedures







Safety and Handling




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
DASPEI is a fluorescent vital dye that can stain skin and clothing
Keep staining solutions in dark containers to prevent photobleaching
DASPEI solutions can be stored at 4°C and reused (see procedure)
Dispose of staining solutions according to chemical waste protocols

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Background
DASPEI (2-(4-dimethylaminostyryl)-N-ethylpyridinium iodide) is a vital mitochondrial dye that selectively labels metabolically active cells. In fish, it is particularly useful for visualizing neuromast hair cells of the lateral line system. The lateral line is a mechanosensory system that detects water movement and vibrations, consisting of clusters of sensory hair cells (neuromasts) distributed across the fish body surface.
DASPEI enters active mitochondria in living cells and fluoresces yellow-green when excited with blue light (excitation ~475nm, emission ~605nm). The staining is specific to functional hair cells, making it an excellent tool for assessing lateral line development, damage, and regeneration. Unlike bone stains, DASPEI staining is relatively rapid (5-75 minutes) but also fades more quickly, requiring immediate imaging after staining.
DASPEI can be combined with bone staining protocols (calcein or alizarin) for multi-marker visualization.

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Materials

Petri dishes (for larvae) and/or 1L tanks (for juveniles/adults)
Darkened containers or aluminum foil
Transfer pipettes
DASPEI powder (Sigma Aldrich; cat# D3418)
Sterile water or appropriate base medium
4°C refrigerator for solution storage

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Solutions

DASPEI Stock Solution

0.1% Stock: 100mg DASPEI in 100ml sterile water
Store in dark bottle at 4°C
Can be stored for extended periods (several months)
Make fresh if precipitation occurs



Staining Solutions
Preparation varies by species due to different osmotic requirements:

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Working Solution:

0.005% DASPEI in embryo medium (see ?sec-recipe-embryo_medium)
For 100ml: Add 5ml of 0.1% stock to 95ml embryo medium
Make fresh or use refrigerated solution within 1 week
Keep in dark container

Volume recommendations:

Larvae: 50-100ml in Petri dishes
Juveniles/Adults: 500ml-1L in tanks



Working Solution:

0.005% DASPEI in artificial seawater
Use 25 ppt Instant Ocean or natural seawater
For 100ml: Add 5ml of 0.1% stock to 95ml seawater
Make fresh or use refrigerated solution within 1 week
Keep in dark container

Volume recommendations:

Larvae: 50-100ml in Petri dishes
Juveniles/Adults: 500ml-1L in tanks






Additional Solutions

MESAB anesthesia strength (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_stickleback for stickleback, ?sec-husbandry_anesth_pipefish for pipefish)
MESAB euthanasia strength (see Chapter 54 for stickleback, Chapter 38 for pipefish)
Fresh system water or medium for rinsing (appropriate for species)

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Procedure

Preparation

Prepare staining solution fresh or retrieve from 4°C storage
Allow refrigerated solution to come to room temperature
Cover container with aluminum foil to protect from light
Pre-label all containers with fish ID, date, and treatment







Batch Processing



If imaging multiple fish, stagger the staining start times (e.g., 15-minute intervals) to ensure no fish stains longer than 75 minutes before imaging. This prevents over-staining and ensures consistent results.




Staining Protocol






Staining Duration Guidelines




Minimum: 5 minutes (visible staining in larvae)
Optimal: 15-30 minutes for most applications
Maximum: 75 minutes (do not exceed to prevent background staining)
DASPEI staining is much faster than bone stains
Monitor timing carefully as fluorescence intensity plateaus and background increases with longer exposure




Transfer fish to staining container

Larvae: Use Petri dishes with 50-100ml staining solution
Juveniles/Adults: Use 1L tanks with appropriate volume
Ensure adequate volume for fish size and number
Start timer immediately upon transfer

Incubate in darkness

Cover container with aluminum foil or place in dark location
Maintain appropriate temperature:

Stickleback: 16-20°C
Pipefish: 18-22°C

Keep fish in dark during entire staining period

Monitor fish during staining

Check every 15-30 minutes
Ensure fish are swimming normally and not stressed
Note exact staining duration for each fish
If imaging multiple individuals, remove them sequentially based on stagger times




De-staining and Rinsing

Rinse fish to reduce background staining

Transfer fish to container with fresh medium/seawater (appropriate for species)
Rinse for 20-60 minutes
Background fluorescence decreases with longer rinse times
Keep in dark during rinse period
Can do 2 rinses of 30 minutes each for better signal-to-background ratio








Critical Timing



Unlike bone stains, DASPEI fluorescence in neuromasts is relatively stable for several hours after staining, but plan to image as soon as possible after rinsing for best results. Background fluorescence will continue to fade during the rinse period while neuromast signal remains strong.




Imaging

Anesthetize for imaging

Place fish in anesthesia solution (appropriate strength for species)
Wait until fish reaches a light plane of anesthesia
Aim for reduced gill movement and loss of equilibrium

Observe and image fluorescence immediately

DASPEI fluorescence: Excitation ~475nm, Emission ~605nm (yellow-green/orange)
Image as soon as possible after anesthesia
Use minimal exposure to excitation light to prevent photobleaching
Neuromast hair cells should appear as bright spots along lateral line
Keep fish in dark between imaging sessions








Imaging Tips




Use appropriate filters for yellow-green to orange fluorescence
Compatible with GFP filter sets in many cases
Can be imaged alongside calcein (green) or alizarin (red) with appropriate filter sets
Z-stack imaging may be helpful to capture all neuromasts in focus





Recovery

Transfer fish to recovery container

Use clean system water or fresh medium at appropriate temperature
Place in container of fish water with adequate oxygenation

Monitor recovery

Check fish every 5-10 minutes until revived
Look for return of normal swimming behavior and equilibrium
Typical recovery time: 5-20 minutes depending on anesthesia depth

Return to system or proceed to next step

Once fish is revived and swimming upright: return to fish system
Monitor during daily health checks
If proceeding to fixation: transfer to euthanasia solution (see appropriate euthanasia SOP for species)




Solution Storage and Reuse

Store staining solution (optional)

DASPEI staining solution can be stored at 4°C in dark bottle
Label with date prepared and date last used
Can be reused multiple times (up to 1-2 weeks)
Discard if precipitation occurs or staining intensity decreases
Allow to warm to room temperature before reuse

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




Weak or no staining
Staining time too short
Increase staining duration to 30-60 minutes



Old DASPEI stock
Make fresh stock solution



Damaged/absent neuromasts
Verify fish health and age; neuromast number varies by developmental stage


High background fluorescence
Staining time too long
Reduce to 15-30 minutes



Insufficient rinsing
Extend rinse period to 60 minutes or do multiple rinses



Imaging too soon after staining
Allow longer rinse time for background to clear


Fish stress/mortality
Staining solution too concentrated
Verify concentration is 0.005%



Inadequate oxygenation
Add gentle aeration or use fresh solution



Prolonged staining
Do not exceed 75 minutes


Inconsistent staining
Variable staining times
Use timer and stagger fish carefully



Temperature fluctuations
Maintain consistent temperature during staining


Rapid fluorescence loss
Excessive light exposure
Keep fish in dark; minimize excitation light



Photobleaching during imaging
Reduce excitation intensity or exposure time


No visible neuromasts
Wrong developmental stage
Check that fish have developed lateral line (varies by species/age)



Wrong filter set
Verify using yellow-green/orange emission filters

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Notes on Neuromast Biology






Understanding Neuromast Distribution




Stickleback: Lateral line neuromasts appear along body flanks, head, and around eyes
Pipefish: Neuromasts distributed along elongated body, density varies by species and age
Development: Neuromast number and position change during development
Function: Neuromasts detect water movement, pressure changes, and vibrations
Research applications: Useful for studying sensory system development, damage, and regeneration

title: 65  Live DASPEI Staining
text:
Associated Papers

Harris, J. A., Cheng, A. G., Cunningham, L. L., MacDonald, G., Raible, D. W., & Rubel, E. W. (2003). Neomycin-induced hair cell death and rapid regeneration in the lateral line of zebrafish (Danio rerio). Journal of the Association for Research in Otolaryngology, 4(2), 219-234. doi:10.1007/s10162-002-3022-x
Raible, D. W., & Kruse, G. J. (2000). Organization of the lateral line system in embryonic zebrafish. Journal of Comparative Neurology, 421(2), 189-198.
xxx (add lab-specific publications)

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text: Introduction

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to take live fin clips from fish for genetic sampling or marking
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark C. Currey
Date Created: April 06, 2010, updated November 22, 2025
IACUC Protocol: Required for live animal procedures involving tissue sampling







Safety and Animal Welfare




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
Use sharp, sterilized scissors and forceps to ensure clean cuts
Minimize fish exposure to anesthesia
Never clip into the caudal peduncle (base of tail) - this can be fatal
Use antibacterial/antifungal treatment post-procedure to prevent infection
Do not fin clip fish that are already stressed or showing signs of disease

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Background
Fin clipping is a common procedure in fish research for obtaining tissue samples for genetic analysis (DNA extraction, genotyping, parentage analysis) or for individual identification (mark-recapture studies). The caudal fin (tail fin) is typically used because it:

Contains sufficient tissue for DNA extraction
Regenerates completely in most fish species
Has minimal impact on swimming ability when clipped properly
Is easily accessible and visible

Proper technique is essential to minimize stress, prevent infection, and ensure fish welfare. The procedure involves brief anesthesia, quick removal of a small portion of the caudal fin blade (avoiding the peduncle), and recovery in clean water with antibacterial treatment.

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Materials

Beakers or small containers for anesthesia and recovery (200-500ml)
Fine-tipped scissors (sterilized)
Fine-tipped forceps (sterilized)
Bucket of ice
1.5ml microcentrifuge tubes (pre-labeled)
Transfer pipettes
Paper towels or kimwipes
Waste container

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Solutions

Anesthesia Solutions

MESAB (MS-222) anesthesia strength for stickleback (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_stickleback)
MESAB (MS-222) anesthesia strength for pipefish (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_pipefish)
Concentration typically 168 mg/L for pipefish



Recovery and Treatment Solutions

Clean system water (temperature-appropriate for species)
Melafix (antifungal and antibacterial agent)

Dilute according to manufacturer’s recommendations (typically 5ml per 10 gallons)
Prepare fresh for each use




Euthanasia Solutions (if needed)

MESAB euthanasia strength for stickleback (see Chapter 54)
MESAB euthanasia strength for pipefish (see Chapter 38)

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Procedure

Preparation (Critical for Minimizing Anesthesia Exposure)






Preparation is Key



Complete ALL labeling and setup before anesthetizing fish to minimize their exposure to MS-222. Fish should spend the minimum time necessary under anesthesia.



Label all materials before starting

Label 1.5ml tubes with fish ID, date, and project code
Arrange tubes in rack on ice
Prepare data sheet for recording fish IDs and clip times

Prepare solutions

Anesthesia beaker: 200-500ml MS-222 at appropriate concentration
Recovery beaker 1: 200-500ml clean system water
Recovery beaker 2: 200-500ml system water with Melafix
Label each beaker clearly

Sterilize instruments

Wipe scissors and forceps with 70% ethanol
Allow to air dry or wipe with sterile gauze
Re-sterilize between fish or when switching between family groups to prevent cross-contamination




Anesthesia and Fin Clipping

Transfer fish to anesthesia solution

Use transfer pipette or small net
Start timer to monitor anesthesia duration
Target: minimum time necessary for safe handling

Monitor anesthesia progression

Watch operculum (gill cover) movement - it will slow
Fish will lose equilibrium and turn on side
Wait for light plane of anesthesia (reduced movement, slowed breathing)
Typical time: 1-3 minutes depending on fish size and temperature








Signs of Appropriate Anesthesia




Reduced opercular movement (slowed breathing)
Loss of equilibrium (fish turns on side)
Reduced response to stimuli
Fish should still show gill movement (NOT complete cessation of breathing)




Remove fish from anesthesia and clip fin

Use forceps to gently lift fish from beaker
Place on clean, damp paper towel or kimwipe
Keep fish moist during procedure
Use scissors and forceps to remove portion of caudal fin blade
CRITICAL: Avoid the caudal peduncle (base of tail where it meets body)
Remove approximately 2-5mm of fin depending on fish size
Make clean, quick cuts to minimize tissue damage








Critical Anatomical Landmark



The caudal peduncle is the narrow base of the tail where it connects to the body. NEVER clip into this region as it contains major blood vessels and nerve cords. Cutting this area can cause:

Severe bleeding
Permanent swimming impairment
Death

Always clip only the fin blade (the thin, flexible part of the tail fin).



Preserve tissue sample

Immediately place fin clip into pre-labeled 1.5ml tube on ice
Ensure tube is properly labeled and sealed
Note any observations (fish ID, clip size, anomalies)




Recovery and Post-Procedure Care

Initiate recovery

Immediately place fish into recovery beaker with clean system water
Gently move fish back and forth to force water over gills
This helps restore normal respiration

Monitor recovery

Watch for return of opercular movement (gill beating)
Look for fish to right itself (regain equilibrium)
Continue gentle agitation until fish begins swimming
Typical recovery time: 30 seconds to 3 minutes

Antibacterial/antifungal treatment

Once fish is swimming upright, transfer to beaker with Melafix solution
Leave fish in Melafix for 15 minutes
This prevents infection at the wound site
Continue monitoring during treatment

Return to system

After Melafix treatment, return fish to home tank or appropriate system location
Monitor fish for at least 5 minutes after return
Check that fish swims normally and shows no signs of distress
Flag tank/container for daily health monitoring over next 3-5 days




Sample Storage

Process tissue samples

Keep samples on ice during procedure
Transfer to -20°C or -80°C freezer for long-term storage
Alternatively, preserve in 95-100% ethanol for DNA extraction
Record sample locations in lab database

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Post-Procedure Monitoring






Health Monitoring Schedule



Monitor clipped fish daily for at least 3-5 days post-procedure:

Day 1-2: Check 2x daily for signs of stress, infection, or behavioral changes
Day 3-5: Check 1x daily during normal health checks
Signs of concern: Lethargy, rapid breathing, refusal to eat, white/fuzzy growth on fin (fungal infection), erratic swimming
Document any issues and consult with IACUC/veterinarian if problems arise




Expected Recovery Timeline

Hours 0-4: Fish may be slightly less active, fin regeneration begins
Days 1-3: Transparent tissue forms at wound edge, fish returns to normal behavior
Weeks 1-2: Fin begins to regenerate ray structure
Weeks 4-8: Complete regeneration (varies by species, age, and fin size removed)

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




Excessive bleeding
Cut into caudal peduncle
Apply pressure with damp gauze; monitor closely; consult veterinarian if bleeding continues >2 min



Cut too large for fish size
Use smaller clips; ensure scissors are sharp


Slow or no recovery
Over-anesthetized
Increase water flow over gills; ensure fresh water; continue monitoring; most fish recover with time



Water temperature too different
Ensure anesthesia and recovery water are same temperature as home tank


Infection/fungal growth
Contaminated instruments
Sterilize instruments between fish; ensure Melafix treatment



Stressed/immunocompromised fish
Do not clip fish showing prior signs of disease; ensure water quality is optimal


Fish dies during/after procedure
Anesthesia overdose
Reduce anesthesia time; check MS-222 concentration



Cut into peduncle
Review anatomy; practice technique on euthanized fish first


Difficulty handling fish
Fish too small
Consider postponing until fish is larger (minimum ~20mm for most species)



Fish too active
Ensure adequate anesthesia depth before removing from water


Fin doesn’t regenerate
Damage to fin base
Ensure future clips avoid the very base of fin rays



Fish health issues
Monitor overall fish health and water quality

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Species-Specific Considerations

SticklebackPipefish



Size recommendations: Can clip fish as small as 20-25mm total length
Anesthesia: Use stickleback-specific MS-222 concentration
Recovery temperature: 16-20°C
Regeneration time: 4-6 weeks for complete regeneration
Notes: Hardy species, generally tolerate procedure well
Pectoral or pelvic spines may prick handler - use care




Size recommendations: Clip fish >30mm total length (pipefish are more delicate)
Anesthesia: Use pipefish-specific MS-222 concentration (typically 168 mg/L)
Recovery temperature: 18-22°C
Regeneration time: 6-8 weeks (slower than stickleback)
Notes: More delicate than stickleback; handle gently
Elongated body shape requires careful positioning during procedure
Monitor more closely post-procedure

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Alternative Methods

Non-Invasive Sampling (Future Consideration)
For some applications, consider non-lethal alternatives:

Scale sampling: For species with large scales (not applicable to most stickleback/pipefish)
Mucus sampling: Emerging technique for eDNA analysis
Buccal swabs: Less invasive but yields less DNA
Visual marking: PIT tags or visible implant elastomer for identification without sampling



Lethal Sampling
If fish will be euthanized for other purposes, collect tissue then rather than fin clipping:

Larger tissue sample available
No recovery period needed
No infection risk
See species-specific euthanasia SOPs

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Associated Papers

Östlund-Nilsson, S., Mayer, I., & Huntingford, F. A. (2007). Biology of the Three-Spined Stickleback. CRC Press. (Chapter on experimental methods)
Bergstrom, C. A., & Reimchen, T. E. (2005). Habitat-dependent associations between parasitism and susceptibility to predation in threespine stickleback. Oikos, 108(2), 321-332. (Fin clipping methodology)
xxx (add lab-specific publications)

title: 66  Live Fin Clipping
text:
Appendix: Genetics Lab Information
For tissue samples intended for genetic analysis, coordinate with genetics lab regarding:

Preferred storage method (frozen vs. ethanol)
Required tissue amount
Labeling conventions
Chain of custody documentation

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text: Introduction

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to perform retrograde backfill labeling of hindbrain neurons using lipophilic dyes, allowing visualization of neural projections and cell body locations
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Susie Bassham
Date Created: January 01, 2020, updated November 22, 2025
IACUC Protocol: Required for live animal procedures and surgical interventions







Safety and Handling




Wear appropriate PPE (lab coat, gloves, safety glasses)
Work in sterile conditions to prevent infection post-surgery
Handle sharp instruments (obsidian flakes, scalpels) with extreme care
Lipophilic dyes may be toxic - handle according to MSDS
Dispose of all materials according to biohazard and chemical waste protocols









IACUC Compliance



This procedure involves surgical intervention on live fish. Ensure:

Current IACUC protocol approval is in place
All personnel are trained in microsurgical techniques
Proper anesthesia and analgesia protocols are followed
Post-operative monitoring is documented
Endpoints are clearly defined and followed

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Background
Retrograde backfill labeling uses lipophilic dyes that are taken up by severed axons and transported retrogradely to the cell bodies of neurons. This technique allows researchers to identify the location and morphology of neurons that project to specific regions of the nervous system. Common applications include:

Mapping hindbrain motor neuron populations
Identifying sensory neuron projections
Studying neural circuit organization during development
Comparing neural architecture across species

The procedure involves making a precise transection of the spinal cord and applying lipophilic dyes (such as rhodamine dextran or DiO) to the cut surface. The dye crystals are taken up by the severed axons and transported back to the cell bodies over several hours, where they can be visualized by fluorescence microscopy.

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Materials

Surgical Equipment

Stereomicroscope with good working distance
Fine tungsten needles or insect pins (size 000 or smaller)
Obsidian glass flakes (extremely sharp cutting edge)
Fine scalpel (size 11 blade) or microsurgical scissors
Fine forceps (Dumont #5 or finer)
Petri dishes (35mm or 60mm)
Sterile transfer pipettes
Dissection platform (agar-coated dish or similar)



Dyes and Reagents

Rhodamine dextran (tetramethylrhodamine dextran, 3,000 MW or 10,000 MW)
DiO lipophilic carbocyanine dye (DiOC18(3))
DiI lipophilic carbocyanine dye (optional alternative)
Cell culture grade antibiotic/antimycotic solution (Gibco-BRL cat# 15240-096, 100x concentration)

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Solutions

Base Media/Water

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid



Stickleback embryo medium (see ?sec-recipe-embryo_medium)
Sterile filtered and supplemented with antibiotic/antimycotic (1x final concentration)




Sterile filtered seawater (25-30 ppt)
Supplemented with antibiotic/antimycotic (1x final concentration)






Anesthesia Solutions

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid



MS-222 anesthesia solution (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_stickleback)
MS-222 euthanasia solution (see Chapter 54)
Working concentration: 168 mg/L for anesthesia




MS-222 anesthesia solution (see ?sec-husbandry_anesth_pipefish)
MS-222 euthanasia solution (see Chapter 38)
Working concentration: 168 mg/L for anesthesia






Dye Preparation
Rhodamine Dextran Stock

Dissolve 10 mg rhodamine dextran in 100 µl sterile water
Store in small aliquots at -20°C
Thaw only once - discard after use

DiO Working Solution

DiO comes as crystals or oil
Can be used directly as dried crystals or dissolved in DMSO (10 mg/ml)
Store protected from light at -20°C

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Procedure

Pre-operative Preparation






Timing Considerations




Plan surgery during morning hours to allow maximum recovery time during work hours
Backfill period is 5-16 hours, so timing affects when you euthanize/fix
Consider starting in afternoon if you plan to fix the next morning




Prepare workspace

Set up stereomicroscope with adequate lighting
Prepare all instruments and materials before beginning
Have sterile medium + antibiotic ready in labeled petri dishes
Prepare fresh anesthesia solution

Prepare animals

Select healthy larvae or juveniles (typically 5-20 days post-fertilization)
Transfer 5-10 fish to holding container with antibiotic-supplemented medium
Allow to acclimate for 30 minutes
Label all containers with fish ID, procedure, date, and time




Surgical Procedure

Anesthetize larvae

Transfer fish to MS-222 anesthesia solution
Wait until opercular movements slow significantly (1-3 minutes)
Fish should not respond to gentle touch with pipette
Do not over-anesthetize - maintain light anesthesia plane








Anesthesia Monitoring



Monitor opercular (gill cover) movements throughout the procedure. If movements stop completely, immediately transfer fish to fresh medium. The fish should be sedated but still maintaining respiratory movements.



Position larvae for surgery

Transfer anesthetized larva to dissection platform
Can use agar-coated dish (1-2% agar) or petri dish with minimal liquid
Position larva lateral side up or dorsal side up (depending on approach)
Use fine forceps or pipette to adjust position

Make spinal cord transection

Using obsidian glass flake or extremely sharp scalpel, make a clean dorsal-to-ventral incision
Cut location: typically just caudal to the hindbrain (at rostral trunk region)
Extend incision ventrally to completely sever the spinal cord
Goal: clean transection without excessive tissue damage
Minimize bleeding by working quickly and precisely








Transection Technique




Obsidian flakes are sharper than steel and create cleaner cuts with less tissue damage
Make a single decisive cut rather than multiple small cuts
The spinal cord is small - ensure you cut deep enough to sever it completely
Practice on euthanized larvae first to develop technique




Apply dye crystals

Use a fine insect pin or tungsten needle to pick up small dye crystals
For rhodamine dextran: use dried crystals from stock solution
For DiO: use small amount of crystal or concentrated solution
Apply dye directly to the cut surface of the spinal cord
Use minimal amount - a few crystals are sufficient








Dye Application Tips




Too much dye can cause excessive background fluorescence
Focus dye application on the cut spinal cord surface, not surrounding tissue
Work quickly to minimize anesthesia time (total surgical time: 2-5 minutes per fish)





Post-operative Care

Transfer to recovery medium

Immediately transfer operated larvae to sterile medium + antibiotic
Ensure fish is fully submerged with adequate oxygenation
Place in dark or low-light conditions
Maintain at appropriate temperature (16-20°C for stickleback, 18-22°C for pipefish)

Maintain continuous anesthesia (Optional but recommended)

Keep fish in very low concentration of MS-222 (10-20% of anesthesia concentration)
OR: refresh with anesthesia solution periodically to keep fish calm
This minimizes stress and movement that could disrupt dye uptake
Alternative: use only antibiotic-supplemented medium without anesthesia

Monitor during backfill period

Check fish every 1-2 hours
Look for normal opercular movements and posture
Remove any fish showing signs of distress or mortality
Backfill period: 5 to 16 hours (typically overnight)








Backfill Duration




5-8 hours: Minimal backfill, good for proximal neurons
8-12 hours: Optimal for most hindbrain neurons
12-16 hours: Maximum backfill, best labeling but higher risk of stress





Fixation and Imaging

Euthanize and fix

After backfill period, euthanize larvae using MS-222 euthanasia solution
Transfer to fixative immediately (4% PFA in PBS is standard)
Fix for 2-4 hours at room temperature or overnight at 4°C
Wash 3x in PBS before imaging

Image labeled neurons

Mount in glycerol or other clearing agent
Image on fluorescence microscope or confocal microscope
Rhodamine: Excitation ~550nm, Emission ~570nm (red)
DiO: Excitation ~484nm, Emission ~501nm (green)
Can be stored in PBS + 0.05% sodium azide at 4°C for weeks








Imaging Notes




Use confocal microscopy for best resolution of individual neurons
Z-stack through entire hindbrain region to capture all labeled cells
DiO and rhodamine can be used together for double-labeling experiments
Background fluorescence typically decreases after washing

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




No labeled neurons
Incomplete spinal cord transection
Ensure cut severs cord completely; verify under microscope



Dye not applied to cut surface
Apply dye directly to exposed spinal cord tissue



Insufficient backfill time
Extend backfill period to 12-16 hours



Dye degraded or old
Use fresh dye stocks


High mortality during surgery
Over-anesthetization
Reduce anesthesia concentration or time



Excessive tissue damage
Use sharper instruments; practice technique



Infection
Ensure sterile conditions; verify antibiotic concentration


Post-operative mortality
Inadequate oxygenation
Provide gentle aeration or larger volume



Temperature stress
Maintain appropriate species-specific temperature



Surgical stress
Minimize surgery time; use lighter anesthesia


High background fluorescence
Too much dye applied
Use smaller amount of dye crystals



Short wash period
Extend PBS washing after fixation


Weak or spotty labeling
Dye washed away during surgery
Apply dye to dry or barely moist tissue



Dye not taken up by axons
Ensure fresh transection; apply dye immediately



Fixation too soon
Allow longer backfill period before fixation


Tissue autofluorescence
Common in some tissues
Use appropriate filter sets; image unfilled control



Pigmentation interference
May need to bleach pigment post-fixation

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Species-Specific Considerations

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Advantages: - Well-established developmental staging - Transparent larvae ideal for imaging - Robust to surgical manipulation
Considerations: - Armor plates in adults complicate surgery (use larvae/juveniles) - Optimal age: 7-15 days post-fertilization - Temperature: 16-20°C


Advantages: - Elongated body makes spinal cord more accessible - Unique neural organization interesting for comparative studies
Considerations: - More delicate than stickleback - use extra care - May require higher concentration of antibiotic - Optimal age: 10-20 days post-fertilization - Temperature: 18-22°C - Salinity: Use full-strength seawater (25-30 ppt)

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Quality Control

Run positive controls (known working dye batches) with each experiment
Document surgery time and anesthesia depth for each fish
Image at least 5 successfully labeled specimens per condition
Include negative controls (no dye application) for background assessment
Photograph larvae before and after surgery to document condition

title: 67  Hindbrain Neuron Backfill Labeling
text:
Associated Papers

Metcalfe, W. K., Mendelson, B., & Kimmel, C. B. (1986). Segmental homologies among reticulospinal neurons in the hindbrain of the zebrafish larva. Journal of Comparative Neurology, 251(2), 147-159.
Higashijima, S., Hotta, Y., & Okamoto, H. (2000). Visualization of cranial motor neurons in live transgenic zebrafish expressing green fluorescent protein under the control of the islet-1 promoter/enhancer. Journal of Neuroscience, 20(1), 206-218.
McLean, D. L., & Fetcho, J. R. (2004). Ontogeny and innervation patterns of dopaminergic, noradrenergic, and serotonergic neurons in larval zebrafish. Journal of Comparative Neurology, 480(1), 38-56.

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text: Introduction

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to collect wild fish populations from natural habitats for research purposes
Procedure Type: Field Collection
Species:

Threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: September 10, 2012, updated November 22, 2025
Permit Requirements: ODFW Scientific Taking Permit required (see below)







Permits and Legal Requirements



REQUIRED before any field collection:

Valid ODFW (Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife) Scientific Taking Permit
All collectors listed on permit or supervised by listed collector
Collect only authorized species at authorized locations
Adhere to all permit conditions (bag limits, methods, reporting)
Carry permit copy in field at all times
Annual reporting required (species counts, locations, dates)
Check for additional local, state, or federal permits depending on location









Safety in the Field



Environmental Hazards:

Tide tables and water level fluctuations
Slippery rocks and unstable substrates
Cold water temperatures - risk of hypothermia
Wildlife (snakes, wasps, aggressive waterfowl)
Sun exposure and dehydration
Poison oak/ivy in riparian areas

Safety Equipment:

Cell phone or communication device
First aid kit
Drinking water
Sun protection (hat, sunscreen)
Appropriate footwear (waders or water shoes)
Personal flotation device (PFD) if using kayak or in deep water
Always work with a field partner - never collect alone









New Collectors



New collectors should accompany an experienced collector for at least one field trip before collecting independently. This ensures:

Proper handling techniques for target species
Recognition of by-catch species (especially protected species)
Understanding of equipment deployment and retrieval
Familiarity with permit requirements and data recording

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Background
Field collections of wild populations are essential for:

Establishing lab populations from diverse genetic backgrounds
Comparative studies of local adaptation
Understanding phenotypic variation in natural populations
Genetic mapping and QTL studies
Collecting tissue for molecular analyses

Both stickleback and pipefish inhabit coastal and estuarine environments but have different microhabitat preferences. Successful collecting requires understanding species-specific ecology and using appropriate methods for each species.

Habitat and Ecology

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Preferred Habitats: - Shallow vegetated margins of lakes, ponds, and streams - Estuarine environments with emergent vegetation - Tidal pools and channels - Areas with cover (vegetation, woody debris, undercut banks)
Seasonal Considerations: - Spring (March-June): Breeding season, easiest to collect, males in breeding coloration - Summer: Juveniles abundant, adults post-breeding - Fall/Winter: More difficult to collect, fish in deeper water
Collection Methods: - Minnow traps (most effective) - Seining (effective in open areas) - Dip nets (for targeted collection)


Preferred Habitats: - Eelgrass (Zostera marina) beds - Floating algae mats - Shallow protected bays and estuaries - Dock pilings with algae growth - Salt marsh edges
Seasonal Considerations: - Late spring through fall: Most active, easier to collect - Breeding season varies by species and location - Winter: Less active, found in deeper water
Collection Methods: - Seining through eelgrass (most effective) - Dip nets in algae mats - Minnow traps (less effective than for stickleback)

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Materials

Field Equipment
Collection Devices: - Minnow traps (collapsible wire mesh, 2-4 traps recommended) - Seine net (4-6 feet tall, 10-30 feet long, 1/8 to 1/4 inch mesh) - Dip nets (various sizes, fine mesh) - Trap tethers (rope, carabiners, anchors)
Containers and Transport: - 5-gallon buckets (2-4) - 500ml and 1000ml Nalgene bottles (for preserved specimens) - Small mouse cages or ventilated containers (for live transport) - Portable aerator (battery powered, for live transport) - Cooler with ice packs (for temperature control during transport)
Data Recording: - Waterproof field notebook - Pencils (not pens - may run when wet) - GPS unit or smartphone with GPS - Camera (waterproof or in protective case) - Thermometer - pH meter/strips (optional) - Dissolved oxygen meter (optional) - Salinity refractometer
Personal Safety: - Waders or waterproof boots - Gloves (nitrile or rubber) - Personal flotation device (if working in deep water) - Kayak or small boat (optional, for accessing some sites) - First aid kit - Sun protection
Optional Equipment: - Crossing materials (if breeding fish in field - see stickleback crossing SOP) - Liquid nitrogen dewar (for flash freezing high-quality tissue samples) - Portable shade structure

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Solutions

Euthanasia and Preservation

95% Ethanol (for tissue preservation)

Bring 1-2 liters for full day of collecting
Store in labeled, sealed containers
Must be fresh (not recycled) for DNA preservation

MS-222 (Tricaine) (for euthanasia)

See euthanasia SOPs: Chapter 54 and Chapter 38
Prepare working solution before field trip
Store in dark bottles
Bring 500ml-1L of euthanasia strength solution

Liquid Nitrogen (optional, for flash freezing)

Required for high-quality DNA/RNA preservation
Transport in appropriate dewar
Follow institutional safety protocols

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Procedure

Pre-Collection Planning

Check permits and regulations

Verify current ODFW permit is valid and covers collection site
Review permit conditions (species, numbers, methods, dates)
Check for any site-specific restrictions
Ensure all collectors are authorized

Check environmental conditions

Review weather forecast
Check tide tables (for estuarine/coastal sites)
Verify water body is accessible (not closed due to flooding, fire, etc.)
Contact land manager if collecting on private or restricted land

Prepare equipment

Clean and inspect all collection gear
Ensure traps and nets are in good repair
Charge batteries for aerators and electronics
Pack all materials on checklist




Collection Methods






Collection Strategy




Scout the site first before deploying equipment
Start with least invasive methods (observation, trapping)
Use active collection (seining, dip netting) if passive methods unsuccessful
Target areas with appropriate habitat for your species
Rotate through multiple sites if permitted to avoid over-collection from one location




Minnow Trap Collection

Deploy traps

Place traps in areas with cover (vegetation, woody debris, structure)
Ensure traps are fully submerged
Tether each trap securely to shore or non-movable object
Mark trap locations clearly
Record GPS coordinates and deployment time in field notebook








TIDAL AREAS



CRITICAL for tidal waters: Check tide tables and ensure traps remain below low tide line. Traps placed above the low water mark will be left dry during low tide, resulting in fish mortality and permit violations.

Deploy traps 1-2 hours before low tide
Check water depth at predicted low tide
Place traps in subtidal channels or pools
Consider using shorter trap deployment times (2-6 hours instead of 24 hours)




Check traps regularly

Maximum trap deployment: 24 hours (often less in tidal areas)
Check every 2-6 hours if possible to minimize stress on captured fish
More frequent checks in warm weather (lower oxygen capacity)

Retrieve and process catch

FIRST: Check for protected species

Salmonids (salmon, trout)
Oregon chub (endemic to Willamette Basin)
Bull trout
Coho salmon
Any other ESA-listed species

If protected species present:

Open trap underwater
Release all fish immediately
Do not handle protected species unless absolutely necessary
Move trap to different location

If no protected species:

Remove trap from water
Empty contents into bucket filled 1/3 with water from collection site
Proceed to sorting and counting





Active Collection (Seine/Dip Net)

Seine net collection

Two-person operation: one person on each end of seine
Wade into appropriate depth (knee to waist deep)
Keep bottom of net on substrate
Pull seine steadily through habitat
For pipefish: Seine slowly through eelgrass beds
Bring net to shore or shallow water
Carefully remove fish and place in bucket

Dip net collection

Effective for targeted collection in algae mats or vegetation
Approach slowly to avoid disturbing fish
Use quick, decisive net movement
Immediately transfer catch to bucket





Data Recording

Count and identify all fish

Separate by species
Count target species (record in field notebook)
Count all by-catch species (required for permit reporting)
Photograph any unusual species or observations
Take photos of target species if desired








Data to Record



Required for each collection event:

Date and time
Location (GPS coordinates, site name)
Collection method
Number of each species collected
Number of each species released
Water temperature
Water type (fresh, brackish, marine)
Salinity (if applicable)

Recommended additional data:

Water condition (clear, turbid, stained)
Substrate type (sand, mud, gravel, rock)
Vegetation type and density
Weather conditions
pH (if possible)
Dissolved oxygen (if possible)
Tidal stage (if applicable)
Photos of habitat




Release by-catch

Immediately release any non-target species
Release protected species first
Handle fish gently and minimize air exposure
Release in same location collected
Record number released for each species




Processing Collected Fish

For Preserved Specimens

Euthanize fish

Transfer fish to MS-222 euthanasia solution
Wait until opercular movements cease (5-10 minutes)
Verify death (no gill movement, no response to stimuli)

Preserve in ethanol

Collect fish from MS-222 using fine mesh net
Blot excess liquid
Place fish into Nalgene bottle with 95% ethanol
IMPORTANT: Do not overfill bottles

Fill bottle maximum 1/3 to 1/2 with fish
Body fluids dilute ethanol, leading to tissue degradation
Use multiple bottles rather than overfilling

Label with: Species, location, date, collector, stock number (assign upon return)

Alternative: Flash freezing (for high-quality DNA/RNA)

Euthanize as above
Blot excess liquid
Place individual fish in cryovials or small bags
Immediately place in liquid nitrogen
Transfer to dry ice for transport
Store at -80°C in lab
Label with complete collection information




For Live Introduction to Lab






Biosecurity and Disease Prevention



Never introduce wild fish directly to lab system:

Wild fish may carry pathogens, parasites, or invasive species
All wild fish must be quarantined
For breeding: use embryos only (see embryo bleaching SOP)
For live experiments: maintain separate from colony fish




Transport live fish

Transfer fish to aerated containers
Use water from collection site
Keep cool but not cold (use ice packs outside container)
Minimize transport time (ideally <4 hours)
Avoid overcrowding (max 10-20 fish per 5-gallon bucket with aeration)
Monitor during transport

Wild crosses for lab introduction (See specific crossing SOPs)

Perform crosses immediately upon return to lab or within 24 hours
See stickleback crossing SOP for detailed protocol
Bleach embryos to remove surface pathogens (see embryo bleaching SOP)
Only introduce bleached embryos to fish system
OR: Fix embryos for morphological/developmental studies

Return to lab and catalog

Assign stock numbers to all preserved specimens
Enter data into lab database/spreadsheet
Store preserved specimens in designated location
Label all containers clearly
Update permit records (running total of collections)





Trap and Equipment Disinfection






TRAP DISINFECTION - CRITICAL FOR BIOSECURITY



Required disinfection situations:

Collecting between different watersheds
Collecting between different water bodies within a watershed (when specified by ODFW)
After encountering invasive species (New Zealand mudsnails, etc.)
Check current ODFW permit comments for specific requirements




Standard disinfection protocol

Rinse all equipment thoroughly with clean water to remove organic matter
Air dry equipment for minimum 1 week between collection sites
Dry time kills many pathogens and invertebrates
Store in dry, protected location

Enhanced disinfection (when required)

Rinse equipment to remove organic matter
Soak in 10% bleach solution for 10 minutes
OR: Soak in Virkon solution (follow manufacturer’s instructions)
Rinse thoroughly with clean water
Air dry completely before next use
Additional protocols may be needed for specific invasive species - consult with ODFW

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Troubleshooting








Problem
Possible Cause
Solution




No or few target species caught
Wrong habitat selection
Move to areas with more cover/appropriate vegetation



Wrong time of year
Consult literature on seasonal patterns



Wrong collection method
Try different methods (seine vs. trap)



Low population density
Try different site


High by-catch of protected species
Trap placement in migration corridor
Move traps to different microhabitat



Wrong site selection
Consider alternative collection sites


Fish mortality in traps
Traps left too long
Check more frequently; reduce deployment time



High water temperature
Collect in cooler parts of day; use shade



Low oxygen
Use traps with larger openings; check more frequently



Tidal exposure
Verify trap depth at low tide; move to subtidal areas


Fish mortality during transport
Overcrowding
Use more containers; reduce density



Temperature stress
Use ice packs; insulate containers



Inadequate oxygenation
Check aerator function; add airstones


Ethanol preservation poor quality
Bottles overfilled with fish
Use more bottles; maximum 1/3 to 1/2 full



Old ethanol
Use fresh 95% ethanol only



Contamination
Ensure fish fully euthanized before preservation


Equipment loss
Inadequate tethering
Use secure knots; check tether strength



Theft or vandalism
Place traps in less visible locations; check frequently

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Species-Specific Tips

SticklebackPipefish/Syngnathid


Best Practices: - Spring collections during breeding season are most productive - Males in breeding coloration are easily spotted - Traps work extremely well - place in vegetated areas - Seining effective in open shallow water - Can be abundant - easy to over-collect (respect permit limits)
Handling: - Spines can puncture skin - use gloves or careful handling - Generally hardy during transport - Tolerate range of salinities (freshwater to full seawater)
Locations: - Oregon coast: estuaries, tidal creeks, freshwater streams - Willamette Valley: ponds, sloughs, slow-moving streams - Check ODFW permit for authorized locations


Best Practices: - Focus on eelgrass beds and floating algae - Seining is most effective method - Dip nets good for algae mats along docks - Traps less effective than for stickleback - Look for characteristic “S” posture when swimming
Handling: - Very delicate - minimize handling - Can be stressed by air exposure - Keep in species-appropriate salinity (full seawater, 25-30 ppt) - Pregnant males: handle with extra care to avoid embryo loss
Bay Pipefish (S. leptorhyncus): - Oregon and Washington estuaries and protected bays - Associated with eelgrass beds - Year-round but more abundant late spring through fall
Gulf Pipefish (S. scovelli): - Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic coast - More tolerant of variable salinity than bay pipefish - Found in seagrass beds, algae, and estuarine vegetation

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Post-Collection Tasks

Within 24 Hours

Process all fish (preserve or cross)
Enter data into field notebook and lab database
Assign stock numbers
Clean and store equipment
Update permit tracking spreadsheet



Within 1 Week

Back up field data digitally
Organize and label preserved specimens
Begin any planned crosses or experiments
Disinfect equipment if collecting at different site soon



End of Permit Year

Compile annual report for ODFW
Include: all species collected, quantities, locations, dates
Submit by permit deadline (usually December 31 or permit anniversary)
Renew permit if needed for following year

title: 68  Wild Fish Field Collections
text:
Associated Papers

Bell, M. A., & Foster, S. A. (Eds.). (1994). The Evolutionary Biology of the Threespine Stickleback. Oxford University Press.
Ostlund-Nilsson, S., Mayer, I., & Huntingford, F. A. (Eds.). (2007). Biology of the Three-spined Stickleback. CRC Press.
Dawson, C. E. (1985). Indo-Pacific Pipefishes (Red Sea to the Americas). Gulf Coast Research Laboratory.
Wilson, A. B., Vincent, A., Ahnesjo, I., & Meyer, A. (2001). Male pregnancy in seahorses and pipefishes (family Syngnathidae): Rapid diversification of paternal brood pouch morphology inferred from a molecular phylogeny. Journal of Heredity, 92(2), 159-166.
xxx (add lab-specific publications)

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text: Introduction

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to generate cytoplasmic hybrids (cybrids) in threespine stickleback. Cytoplasm Transfer (CT) protocols have been established for a long time in vertebrates with the first human born from cytoplasm transfer in 1997. Methods follow similar protocols to somatic cell nuclear transfer in zebrafish and include the donation of approximately 20% of the donor egg cytoplasm into recipients at the single cell stage.
Procedure Type: Vert Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Emily Beck
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering embryo microinjection and euthanasia. Ensure all personnel are properly trained in microinjection techniques.








Background on Cybrids



Cytoplasmic hybrids (cybrids) allow researchers to study mitochondrial function by transferring mitochondria-containing cytoplasm from one line to another. This technique is useful for:

Studying mitochondrial genome effects
Creating lines with specific mitochondrial-nuclear combinations
Testing for heteroplasmy (presence of multiple mitochondrial genotypes)
Mitochondrial replacement therapy research

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Materials

Petri dish with specialized trough rig for holding embryos
Microinjection rig with micromanipulator
Pulled needles for injection (see Chapter 60)
Transfer pipettes
Dissecting microscope
Microinjector (pneumatic or manual)

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Solutions

Embryo medium - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
MS-222 euthanasia solution (for later stages)

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Procedure






Timing is Critical



Work quickly but carefully. The single-cell stage is brief (~1 hour post fertilization at 20°C). Have all materials prepared before beginning fertilization.



Recipient embryo preparation: Collect eggs and sperm from one mitochondrial line (recipient) and fertilize according to Chapter 49.
Donor egg preparation: Collect eggs from alternate (donor) mitochondrial line. Keep unfertilized for cytoplasm extraction.
Cytoplasm extraction: Use microinjector to draw approximately 20% of cytoplasm from donor egg. See Chapter 70 for general injection techniques.
Cytoplasm transfer: Inject recipient embryo at single-cell stage, approximately 1 hour post fertilization (at 20°C).

Aim to inject into the cytoplasm without disrupting the nucleus.
Inject the 20% volume of donor cytoplasm into recipient.

Embryo rearing: Transfer injected embryos to fresh embryo medium and rear at standard conditions (20°C).
Heteroplasmy testing: Rear animals until 10 days post fertilization, euthanize according to ?sec-vert_husb-euthanasia_syngnathid, and use a restriction digest or sequencing to test for heteroplasmy (presence of both donor and recipient mitochondrial DNA).

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Quality Control






Verifying Success




Monitor survival rates of injected vs. control embryos
Check for normal development at key stages (24 hpf, 48 hpf, hatching)
Molecular confirmation of heteroplasmy is essential
Expected heteroplasmy levels may vary; document and track across generations

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Related Protocols

Stickleback crossing procedures: Chapter 49
Embryo injection techniques: Chapter 70
Needle pulling: Chapter 60
Euthanasia protocols: ?sec-vert_husb-euthanasia_syngnathid

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




High mortality: May indicate too much cytoplasm transferred or needle too large
Low heteroplasmy detection: Donor cytoplasm may have been lost; verify injection volume
Developmental defects: May indicate incompatibility between nuclear and mitochondrial genomes

title: 69  Stickleback Creation of Cybrids
text:
Associated Papers

Cohen, J., et al. 1997. Birth of infant after transfer of anucleate donor oocyte cytoplasm into recipient eggs. Lancet.
Ma, H., et al. 2016. Metabolic rescue in pluripotent cells from patients with mtDNA disease. Nature.
Relevant papers on somatic cell nuclear transfer in zebrafish
Papers on mitochondrial heteroplasmy detection methods

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text: Introduction

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to inject stickleback embryos with CRISPR elements, DNA, mRNA, lineage tracer dyes, or other reagents using a microinjection rig.
Procedure Type: Vert Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering embryo microinjection. Ensure all personnel are properly trained in microinjection techniques and embryo handling.

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Materials

Petri dish with specialized trough rig (agarose mold or plastic insert)
Microinjection rig with micromanipulator
Dissecting microscope with transmitted light
Pulled glass needles (see Chapter 60)
Microinjector (pneumatic or manual)
Fine forceps for embryo manipulation
Transfer pipettes

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Solutions

Embryo medium - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
Phenol red (optional, for visualizing injection volume)

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Background






Method Overview



(Adapted from Zebrafish Book 4th edition, Chapter 5)
This is an easy method for holding embryos while injecting CRISPR elements, DNA, lineage tracer dyes, etc., without removing their chorions. The embryos are held in wedge-shaped troughs. Each trough can hold approximately 35 embryos (with chorions).
Key principles: - Embryos can be aligned by gently tamping them down with forceps. - As the pipette penetrates the chorion, the embryo is forced against the rear vertical wall of the trough. - The exact positioning of the pipette tip within the embryo is achieved by slight movement of the pipette with a micromanipulator or by movement of the stage.
Needle considerations: - If the pipette tip is thin and long enough, it can be withdrawn from the chorion without dragging the embryo out of the trough. - Thin pipettes may lack the tensile strength to penetrate the chorion and bend when forced onto the chorion surface. - Thicker pipettes do not easily slip out of the chorion, although the embryo can be held with forceps as the pipette is slowly withdrawn.

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Procedure

Preparation

Temperature adjustment: Warm the Petri dish to the temperature you prefer for injection.

Embryos can tolerate 18°C for about 1 hour.
The slower division rate at 18°C allows more time to inject at the 1 and 2-cell stages.
Standard development occurs at 20°C.

Setup: Remove the plastic mold from the agarose if applicable.
Microscope positioning: Position the dish on a microscope stage and adjust the angle of the pipette so that you can aim directly into the trough.



Injection

Load embryos: Transfer embryos into the troughs using a transfer pipette.
Align embryos:

Using forceps, align the embryos all in the same orientation.
