Add enough embryo medium so that the level reaches the plastic edges of the slits.
Gently tamp the embryos down into the trough with forceps.

Penetrate chorion: Using controls on the micromanipulator, force the pipette through the chorion and the yolk cell, entering the embryonic cell(s) from the yolk cell.

Alternative: You might prefer to enter the embryonic cell directly; in this case, you would choose a different orientation of the embryo in the trough.

Position needle: As the pipette goes through the yolk, move the Petri dish slightly so that the pipette is close to the plastic cover.
Inject: Inject the desired volume of solution (typically 1-2 nl) and then withdraw the pipette with a slow steady motion.

The embryo will catch on the plastic cover and drop back into the trough.

Transfer and incubate: Transfer the embryos into a dish with fresh embryo medium and maintain at 20°C for further development.

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Post-Injection Care






Monitoring Embryos




Monitor embryo development at regular intervals (4, 8, 24, 48 hours post-injection)
Remove dead or severely abnormal embryos
Expect some mortality from the injection procedure itself
Document survival rates and phenotypes

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Related Protocols

Needle pulling for injections: Chapter 60
CRISPR/Cas9 injections: Chapter 76
Stickleback crossing and embryo collection: Chapter 49
Cybrid creation: Chapter 69

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Embryos roll out of trough: Trough may be too shallow or wide; adjust mold or use different size.
Chorion doesn’t penetrate: Needle may be too dull; pull fresh needles.
High mortality: May indicate needle too large, injection volume too high, or contaminated injection solution.
Embryos stick to needle: Needle may be too thick or injection too forceful.

title: 70  Stickleback Embryo Injections
text:
Associated Papers

Westerfield, M. The Zebrafish Book. A guide for the laboratory use of zebrafish (Danio rerio), 4th Edition. University of Oregon Press, Eugene.
Bell, M.A. & Foster, S.A. (Eds.) 1994. The Evolutionary Biology of the Threespine Stickleback. Oxford University Press.
Papers on CRISPR/Cas9 injection in stickleback
Papers on transgenic stickleback generation

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text: Introduction

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes the creation of germ-free threespine stickleback for microbiome research and controlled colonization experiments.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering embryo sterilization and germ-free rearing. Ensure all personnel are properly trained in aseptic technique.








Sterile Technique Critical



Maintaining sterility is essential for successful germ-free fish production. All work must be performed in a tissue culture hood using sterile technique. Any break in sterility can compromise the entire experiment.

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Materials

Filter sterilizer (0.22 μm)
3 sterile 50 ml beakers with foil tops
Tissue culture hood
Individually wrapped, sterile transfer pipettes
Sterile 250 cm² or 500 cm² cell culture flasks with screw-top caps
Sterile 25 ml or 50 ml serological pipettes
Pipette aid
Latex laboratory gloves
Large beaker for liquid waste collection

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Solutions

Stock Solutions

Embryo medium (stickleback medium) - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
100 mg/ml Ampicillin (store at -20°C)
50 mg/ml Kanamycin (store at -20°C)
8 mg/ml Amphotericin B (store at -20°C)







Fresh Solutions Required



Make the following solutions fresh for each use (do not store pre-made antibiotic medium or sterilization solutions).




Antibiotic Stickleback Medium
To make 250 ml: - 250 μl Ampicillin 100 mg/ml (final: 100 μg/ml) - 25 μl Kanamycin 50 mg/ml (final: 5 μg/ml) - 7.8 μl Amphotericin B 8 mg/ml (final: 250 ng/ml) - 250 ml Stickleback medium - Filter sterilize through 0.22 μm filter


0.003% Bleach Solution
To make 250 ml: - 125 μl of 6.0% bleach solution - 250 ml Stickleback medium - Filter sterilize through 0.22 μm filter


0.2% PVP-I Solution
(Polyvinylpyrrolidone-iodine [0.01% free iodine], Western Chemical Inc.)
To make 250 ml: - 5 ml of 10% PVP-I stock - 245 ml Stickleback medium - Filter sterilize through 0.22 μm filter

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Procedure

Day 0: Embryo Collection and Initial Sterilization

Collect embryos: Make crosses according to Chapter 49, except spray the outside of the euthanized male with 95% ethanol prior to dissection.
Initial incubation: Incubate eggs at 20°C until eggs reach 2-cell stage (~2 hours post fertilization).

Remove non-viable embryos from 2-cell stage eggs.
Rinse viable embryos with fresh antibiotic stickleback medium 2X. ### Sterilization (6 hours post fertilization)

Prepare for hood work: About 6 hours post fertilization, transfer viable embryos into 50 ml beakers.







Sterile Technique



Wear standard latex laboratory gloves for all subsequent steps to increase the probability of maintaining sterility.



Transfer materials to hood: Move the following into the tissue culture hood to minimize entry/exit (materials listed are per 100 embryos cleaned):

3 sterile 50 ml beakers with foil tops
Individually wrapped, sterile transfer pipettes
1 L filter-sterilized stickleback medium
0.003% bleach solution
0.2-0.4% PVP-I solution (Note: some flasks may be contaminated with 0.2% PVP-I, but more fish are likely to die in 0.4% PVP-I)
10 sterile flasks (250 or 500 cm²) with screw-top caps

In hood, add 48 ml sterile stickleback medium per 250 cm² flask OR 98 ml per 500 cm² flask before adding embryos

25 ml or 50 ml sterile serological pipettes, individually wrapped
Pipette aid
Embryos in 50 ml covered beaker
Large beaker for collecting liquid waste




Embryo Washing and Sterilization

First transfer: Transfer embryos to clean beaker.
Remove medium: Pour off all but ~10 ml SM carefully into waste container.
Transfer: Transfer remaining 10 ml SM with eggs into clean 50 ml beaker.
Collect remaining embryos: Add ~20 ml sterile SM to old beaker to collect remaining eggs.
Combine: Transfer remaining eggs to beaker.
Adjust volume: Bring volume in new beaker up to 50 ml with sterile SM.
Rinse: Rinse embryos 3X with 50 ml filter-sterilized SM.
PVP-I treatment: Immerse embryos in ~50 ml of 0.2-0.4% PVP-I solution for 10 minutes.
Rinse: Rinse embryos with sterile SM 1X.
Transfer to fresh beaker: Transfer embryos to fresh beaker (as in step 5).
Additional rinses: Rinse embryos in sterile SM additional 2X.
Bleach treatment: Immerse embryos in 0.003% bleach for 10 minutes.
Rinse: Rinse embryos in sterile SM 1X.
Final transfer: Transfer embryos to fresh beaker.
Final rinses: Rinse embryos additional 2X in sterile SM.
Flask loading: Transfer 20-40 embryos to each flask containing sterile SM using sterile, individually wrapped pipettes.
Incubation: Incubate embryos at 20°C in incubator.



Post-Sterilization Care

Feeding (9 dpf): At 9 days post fertilization, upon yolk absorption:

Feed larvae with irradiated food
Change water
Test water for bacterial contamination

Daily monitoring:

Record the number of fish dead or not moving in response to external stimuli on the daily checklist.
In tissue culture hood, remove dead or non-responsive (sick) fish.
Euthanize sick fish with tricaine - see Chapter 54

Water changes: In tissue culture hood, remove 70% of fish water with sterile pipette.
Replace medium: Replace water with sterile stickleback medium.
Feeding: Add one scoop of irradiated Ziegler dry food to flask.
Contamination testing: Plate 50-100 μl of water on TSA plates to check for bacterial contamination.

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Quality Control






Monitoring Sterility




Plate water samples on TSA plates at regular intervals (every 2-3 days)
Any bacterial growth indicates contamination
Remove contaminated flasks immediately
Keep detailed records of contamination rates

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Related Protocols

Stickleback crossing: Chapter 49
Embryo medium preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
Euthanasia: Chapter 54
Monoassociation (next step after germ-free): Chapter 72

title: 71  Germ-Free Stickleback
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




High contamination rates: Check sterile technique, filter integrity, and PVP-I/bleach concentrations.
High mortality: May indicate over-sterilization; try reducing PVP-I concentration to 0.2% or reducing bleach exposure time.
Poor growth: Ensure irradiated food is fresh and feeding amounts are appropriate.

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text: Introduction

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Purpose: This protocol is used to determine whether specific bacterial strains can colonize the gut of germ-free stickleback, and to study host-microbe interactions in a controlled manner. This protocol has been adapted for use in stickleback from established, approved zebrafish protocols.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Adapted from Guillemin laboratory protocols
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC and IBC Protocol Required



This procedure requires: - An active IACUC protocol covering germ-free fish rearing and experimental manipulations - An active IBC (Institutional Biosafety Committee) protocol if using recombinant or pathogenic bacteria - Proper biosafety training for all personnel

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Materials

Sterile tissue culture hood
Germ-free stickleback larvae (9-13 dpf) in sterile flasks
250 ml Erlenmeyer flasks for bacterial culture
Shaking incubator (25°C, 200 RPM)
Spectrophotometer for OD600 measurements
Sterile serological pipettes and pipette aid
Bacterial culture plates (TSA or appropriate medium)
Sterile spreaders or glass beads for plating

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Solutions

Sterile stickleback medium (filter sterilized) - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
Appropriate bacterial growth medium (e.g., LB, TSB, or specialized medium)
MS-222 euthanasia solution for endpoint - see ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Background






Bacterial Inoculum Optimization



The bacterial inoculum should be determined empirically for each species used. For many bacteria, 10⁴ Colony Forming Units (CFUs) per milliliter of stickleback medium will suffice for full colonization of the intestine and minimal toxicity to the fish.
Important considerations: - Dead larvae in the flask will be removed promptly as this will often result in increased bacterial growth that can ultimately be fatal to the remaining larvae. - The method below is optimized for several proteobacteria strains. - Different bacterial species may require different concentrations (typically ranging from 10³ to 10⁶ CFU/ml).

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Procedure

Preparation

Prepare germ-free fish: Raise fish in a germ-free environment as described in Chapter 71.

Fish should be 9-13 days post fertilization (when digestive system is open and fish are feeding).




Bacterial Culture Preparation

Bacterial culture: Incubate bacteria for 16 hours in 50 ml of growth medium in a 250 ml Erlenmeyer flask at 25°C, 200 RPM.

Note: These bacteria should originate from the intestine of a healthy stickleback to ensure that the bacteria are not pathogens (or use well-characterized laboratory strains).

Measure density: Measure the Optical Density at 600 nm (OD600) of the culture using a spectrophotometer.
Calculate CFU/ml: Calculate the original culture density, assuming 1 OD600 = 10⁹ CFU/ml.

Note: This conversion factor may vary by bacterial species; verify for your specific strain if possible.




Monoassociation

Prepare inoculum:

Dilute the culture to predetermined concentration (typically 10⁴ CFU/ml) in filter-sterilized stickleback medium.
Work in a tissue culture hood to maintain sterility.
Inoculate the flask containing germ-free larvae.
The fish will be exposed to bacteria in the water after their digestive system is open and they have been shown to consume food (9-13 dpf).








Concentration Range



Germ-free fish water is typically inoculated between 10³ and 10⁶ bacteria per milliliter. Choose a concentration that results in healthy fish surviving to at least three days post-exposure.



Verify inoculum: Plate serial dilutions of the original bacterial culture on appropriate agar plates to verify the actual CFU/ml of the inoculum.



Monitoring

Daily monitoring: Monitor fish daily for signs of illness, including:

Lack of motility or response to external stimuli
Rapid or irregular movement of opercular (gill) cover
Changes in swimming behavior
Loss of balance or orientation
Any other signs of abnormal behavior
Remove dead fish immediately

Water quality: Every 2-3 days, plate water samples on agar to verify monoassociation (only the introduced bacterial species should be present).



Termination

Endpoint: At the end of the experiment, euthanize fish using established and approved protocols - see ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia.
Verification: Dissect fish and plate gut contents to verify colonization and confirm monoassociation status.

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Related Protocols

Germ-free stickleback production: Chapter 71
Stickleback euthanasia: ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia
Embryo medium preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




High mortality: Bacterial concentration may be too high; reduce inoculum in next trial.
No colonization: Bacterial concentration may be too low or bacteria not viable; verify CFU counts by plating.
Contamination: If other bacterial species appear, sterile technique was compromised; discard and restart.
Inconsistent colonization: Ensure fish are at proper developmental stage (digestive system must be open).

title: 72  Stickleback Bacterial Monoassociation
text:
Associated Papers

Papers on zebrafish monoassociation protocols
Guillemin laboratory publications on host-microbe interactions
Papers on gnotobiotic fish models

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text: Introduction

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Purpose: Protocols for treating threespine stickleback with salinities that mimic natural freshwater, brackish, and oceanic conditions to study osmoregulatory adaptation and gene expression.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Cresko Laboratory
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering salinity treatments and environmental manipulations. Ensure all personnel are properly trained in fish husbandry and water quality management.

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Materials

Glass containers of fish water of varying salinity ranging from 2-32 ppt
Glass 4 L fish containers (use glass, not plastic, due to potential endocrine-disrupting properties of some plastics)
Instant Ocean sea salt mix
Nanopure or distilled water
Water quality test kits (ammonia, nitrite, pH, salinity refractometer)
Artemia (brine shrimp) for feeding
Thermometer

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Solutions

Anesthesia and Euthanasia

MS-222 Anesthesia solution - see ?sec-sb_adult_anesthisia
MS-222 Euthanasia solution - see ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia



Salinity Solutions






Instant Ocean Concentrations



Different concentrations of Instant Ocean sea salt mix will be used to create three salinity environments that mimic natural conditions where threespine stickleback are found.


Instant Ocean saltwater mix at the following concentrations:

2 ppt “Freshwater” environment: 40 g Instant Ocean per 20 L Nanopure H2O
15 ppt “Brackish” environment: 300 g Instant Ocean per 20 L Nanopure H2O
30 ppt “Ocean/Seawater” environment: 600 g Instant Ocean per 20 L Nanopure H2O

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Procedure

Embryo Collection and Initial Rearing

Generate embryos: Follow stickleback crossing and rearing SOP (see Chapter 49) to generate 100-200 fertilized embryos.
Incubate embryos: Raise fish in incubator until hatching as described in ?sec-vert_husbandry_incubator_use.



Salinity Treatment

Assign to salinity treatments: At hatching, move 20 larval fish to each 10.5 L static tank containing the appropriate salinity water (2, 15, or 30 ppt) as prepared above.

Replicate tanks: Set up at least 3 replicate tanks per salinity treatment.
Acclimation: Fish hatched in freshwater can be directly transferred to treatment salinities.

Initial feeding: On 9 dpf, begin feeding with freshly hatched artemia (brine shrimp).

Feed enough so that artemia are consumed within 15-30 minutes.

Daily maintenance:

Feed and change water every other day.
Check on fish at least twice EVERY DAY.
Use the care checklist to record:

Daily health checks
Feeding
Water changes

Look for signs of sick or stressed fish:

Low rate of opercular (gill) fluttering
Abnormal coloration
Floating upside down or sideways
Lethargy or hyperactivity
Remove dead fish immediately


Water quality monitoring:

Check water quality on two random tanks in each treatment once every two days before water has been changed.
Test for: ammonia, nitrite, pH, salinity
If ammonia and/or nitrite are detected: change water more frequently, check water quality daily, and denote this on checklist.
Ideal levels: Ammonia and nitrite should be 0 ppm.




Sample Collection

Endpoint: At designated time of interest (up to 40 days post-fertilization), euthanize fish with MS-222.
Tissue fixation: Fix appropriately based on downstream application:

For RNA: Liquid nitrogen or RNAlater
For immunohistochemistry: 4% PFA
For histology: Bouin’s fixative








Anesthesia, N2 Freezing, and Fixation in RNAlater



For RNA preservation:

Anesthetize using appropriate concentration of MS-222 and allow fish to lay motionless with only slight opercle movement. This should take approximately 10 minutes.
Place fish in liquid N2 for 2 minutes. This instantaneously freezes the fish.
Transfer frozen fish to RNAlater-ICE and thaw.

Alternative for stress-sensitive applications: If downstream application requires instantaneous, non-stressed measurement of gene transcription, remove fish from water, rapidly blot, and sacrifice directly into liquid nitrogen or RNAlater without anesthesia.

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Data Collection






Recommended Measurements




Growth (length and weight)
Survival rates across treatments
Gene expression (osmoregulatory genes, stress markers)
Morphological measurements (gill surface area, kidney structure)
Behavior (activity levels, feeding rates)

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Related Protocols

Stickleback crossing: Chapter 49
Incubator use: ?sec-vert_husbandry_incubator_use
Anesthesia: ?sec-sb_adult_anesthisia
Euthanasia: ?sec-husb-adutl_sb_euthanasia

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




High mortality in high salinity: May indicate rapid transition; consider gradual acclimation.
Poor water quality: Increase water change frequency; reduce feeding amounts.
Variable growth: Ensure consistent feeding and water quality across all tanks.
Salinity drift: Monitor salinity regularly, especially after water changes; evaporation increases salinity.

title: 73  Stickleback Salinity Treatment
text:
Associated Papers

Papers on stickleback osmoregulation and salinity adaptation
Studies on freshwater-marine transitions in threespine stickleback

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text: Introduction
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Purpose: This protocol describes how to determine the genotypic sex of threespine stickleback using PCR amplification of sex-linked markers.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Cresko Laboratory
Date Created: January 01, 2024
IACUC Approved: Not applicable (molecular procedure only)
IBC Approved: Not applicable







Background



Threespine stickleback have an XY sex determination system. The GA1 primers amplify a Y-chromosome specific region (~371 bp) that is present only in males. They also amplify a non-sex-linked control band (~600 bp) present in all individuals, which serves as an internal positive control for the PCR reaction.
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Materials

PCR machine/thermocycler
2X Turbo mix (or equivalent PCR master mix)
GA1 F primer (10 µM concentration)
GA1 R primer (10 µM concentration)
Taq polymerase
Nuclease-free water (npH2O)
DNA template (extracted from fin clip or tissue)
PCR tubes (0.2 ml)
Mineral oil (if using non-heated lid thermocycler)
2% agarose gel materials
DNA ladder (100 bp or similar)







Other Primer Pairs



This procedure also works with GA2 and IDH primers, although PCR parameters may be different. GA1 primers are recommended for standard use.
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Procedure

DNA Extraction

Extract DNA from fin clip or tissue sample into 250 µl final volume.

Standard DNA extraction protocols can be used (e.g., HotSHOT method, commercial kits).




PCR Setup

Prepare PCR master mix (volumes shown for 1X reaction, scale up as needed):




Reagent
Concentration
Volume




2X turbo mix

10 µl


GA1 F primer
10 µM
0.25 µl


GA1 R primer
10 µM
0.25 µl


Taq

0.25 µl


npH2O

7.25 µl


DNA

2.0 µl


TOTAL

20 µl




Add mineral oil (if needed): After all ingredients are added to a PCR tube, add a 10 µl drop of mineral oil on top.

Note: Only necessary if using a thermocycler without a heated lid.




PCR Cycling

Run PCR program:




Step
Temperature
Time
Cycles




Initial denaturation
94°C
5 minutes
1


Denaturation
94°C
50 seconds
44


Annealing
44°C
50 seconds
44


Extension
72°C
1:20 min
44


Final extension
72°C
10 minutes
1


Hold
4°C
∞
–





Gel Electrophoresis

Prepare 2% agarose gel in TAE or TBE buffer with ethidium bromide or other DNA stain.
Load samples:

Load 5-10 µl of PCR product per well.
Include a DNA ladder (100 bp or similar) for size reference.

Run gel: Electrophorese at 100-120V for 30-45 minutes or until adequate separation is achieved.
Visualize and interpret:







Banding Patterns for Sex Determination



The GA1F/R primer pair amplifies: - 371 bp band: Y-chromosome specific, present only in males (XY) - 600 bp band: Non-sex-linked control, present in all fish (XX and XY)
Interpretation: - Male (XY): Two bands visible (371 bp bright, 600 bp dim) - Female (XX): One band visible (600 bp only) - Failed PCR: No bands visible
The 600 bp control band helps distinguish a female genotype from a failed PCR reaction. Because of amplification efficiency differences, the 600 bp band will usually be significantly dimmer than the 371 bp band in males.





Illustration of gel with female and male specific banding patterns
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Quality Control






Controls




Positive control (male): Include a known male sample
Positive control (female): Include a known female sample
Negative control: Include a no-template control (water instead of DNA)
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Related Protocols

DNA extraction protocols
Fin clipping for DNA: ?sec-vert_exp-fin_clipping
Stickleback crossing: Chapter 49
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




No bands in any samples: Check PCR reagents, verify thermocycler program, check DNA quality.
No 371 bp band in known male: Primers may have degraded; check primer stocks.
Weak 600 bp band: Normal - this band is typically dimmer; if too weak, increase DNA template amount.
Non-specific bands: Verify primer sequences, check for contamination, optimize annealing temperature.
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR
text: Background and Associated Papers
crumbs: 74  Stickleback Sex Determination with PCR

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text: Introduction
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes the technique for measuring steroids in water that has been occupied by fish (conditioned water). This non-invasive method allows measurement of reproductive hormones without sacrificing the animal.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)
Zebrafish, (Danio rerio)

Author: Adapted from Scott et al. protocols
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol. While non-invasive, the temporary isolation of fish in collection beakers constitutes an experimental manipulation.








Background



Fish continuously release steroids into their surrounding water. By collecting and concentrating steroids from conditioned water, hormone levels can be measured using radioimmunoassay (RIA) without blood collection. This method is particularly useful for: - Repeated measurements from the same individual - Small fish where blood volume is limiting - Studies requiring non-lethal sampling
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Materials

150 ml glass beakers (one per fish)
C18 solid phase extraction (SPE) cartridges containing octadecylsilane (Sep-pak Plus, Waters Ltd., Watford, UK)
60 ml syringes (BD Plastipak) for pushing water through SPE cartridges
Vacuum manifold (optional, for SPE processing)
Nitrogen gas source with regulator (for drying samples)
Heating block or water bath (45°C)
Scintillation vials
Polypropylene centrifuge tubes (50 ml)
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Solutions

100% methanol (5 ml per sample)
Distilled water (5 ml per sample)
Ethyl acetate (5 ml per sample)
RIA buffer: 0.5 M phosphate buffer containing 0.2% bovine serum albumin, 0.8% sodium chloride, 0.03% EDTA and 0.01% sodium azide (1 ml per sample)
3H-labeled steroids for 11-KT (purchased from Amersham Biosciences, UK - Scott et al., 2005)
Dextran-coated charcoal (for separating free and bound steroids)
Scintillation fluid (7 ml per tube)







Chemical Safety




Methanol and ethyl acetate are flammable - keep away from ignition sources.
Work in a fume hood when using organic solvents.
Sodium azide is toxic - handle with care.
Follow radiation safety protocols when working with 3H-labeled compounds.
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Procedure

Water Collection

Place the fish in a 150 ml glass beaker with 50 ml of fresh water (the same source as used for home aquaria) for 30 minutes.
Minimize stress: In the case of male sticklebacks in individual tanks, the beaker can be placed on a support within the home tank to minimize potential confinement stress.
Return fish: After the 30-minute collection period, return the fish to its tank.
Store water sample: If not able to process the water sample immediately:

Pour the conditioned water into a 50 ml polypropylene centrifuge tube.
Store at 4°C (for up to 1 hour) or -20°C (for longer storage).




Steroid Extraction via Solid Phase Extraction (SPE)

Prepare SPE cartridges:

Wash C18 SPE cartridges (Sep-pak Plus) with 5 ml of 100% methanol.
Follow with 5 ml of distilled water.
Do not allow cartridges to dry between steps.

Load water samples:

As the volume of water is small (50 ml), no filtration is needed.
Transfer water samples into 60 ml syringes (BD Plastipak).
Pass water through the SPE cartridges using gentle vacuum or manual pressure.

Wash cartridges:

Push 5 ml of distilled water through the cartridges.
Blow out excess water.

Elute steroids:

Elute steroids with 5 ml ethyl acetate.
Collect eluate in glass tubes.

Dry samples:

Dry down ethyl acetate to dryness under a stream of nitrogen gas at 45°C.
Be patient - complete drying is essential.

Reconstitute:

Add 1 ml of RIA buffer to the dried residue.
Vortex to resuspend.
Store at -20°C until radioimmunoassays are performed.




Radioimmunoassay (RIA)






RIA Protocol Overview



The RIA procedure has been described in detail previously (Scott et al., 1980; Scott et al., 1984; Scott et al., 1982). The following is a brief overview:



Obtain reagents:

3H-labeled steroids for 11-KT (Amersham Biosciences, UK).
Antisera from established sources (see Lower et al., 2004 for validated sources).

Set up assay:

Transfer 100 μl aliquots from the water sample extract or standards into assay tubes.
Add labeled steroids and antisera in a further 100 μl of assay buffer.

Incubate:

Incubate tubes overnight at 4°C to allow antibody-antigen binding.

Separate free and bound steroids:

Add dextran-coated charcoal to bind free (unbound) steroids.
Centrifuge at 2,500 rpm for 12 minutes at 4°C.
Charcoal pellet contains free steroids; supernatant contains antibody-bound steroids.

Count radioactivity:

Pour supernatant into scintillation vials.
Add 7 ml of scintillation fluid to each vial.
Count each tube for 5 minutes in a scintillation counter (e.g., Beckman LS 6500).

Calculate steroid concentrations:

Use standard curves to determine steroid concentrations.
Detection limit: 1-10 pg per assay tube (10 pg per 100 μl assay buffer).
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Quality Control






Important Considerations




Include standard curves with each assay run
Run samples in duplicate or triplicate
Include quality control samples at known concentrations
Verify antibody specificity and cross-reactivity
Document extraction efficiency for each steroid of interest
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Related Protocols

Fish blood collection (alternative method): Chapter 59
Fish husbandry and handling protocols
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Low/undetectable steroids: Ensure fish are in breeding condition; verify SPE extraction efficiency.
High variability: Standardize collection time, water volume, and fish handling; reduce stress.
Poor RIA performance: Check antibody storage and dilutions; verify scintillation counter calibration.
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water
text:
Associated Papers

Lower, N., Scott, A.P. & Moore, A. (2004). Release of sex steroids into the water by roach. Journal of Fish Biology 64, 16-33.
Scott, A.P., Bye, V.J., Baynes, S.M. & Springate, J.R.C. (1980). Seasonal variations in plasma concentrations of 11-ketotestosterone and testosterone in male rainbow trout, Salmo gairdnerii Richardson. Journal of Fish Biology 17, 495-505.
Scott, A.P., Sheldrick, E.L. & Flint, A.P.F. (1982). Measurement of 17α,20β-dihydroxy-4-pregnen-3-one in plasma of trout (Salmo gairdneri Richardson): seasonal changes and response to salmon pituitary extract. General and Comparative Endocrinology 46, 444-451.
Scott, A.P., Mackenzie, D.S. & Stacey, N.E. (1984). Endocrine changes during natural spawning in the white sucker, Catostomus commersoni. II. Steroid hormones. General and Comparative Endocrinology 56, 349-359.
Scott, A.P., Pinillos, M.L. & Huertas, M. (2005). The rate of uptake of sex steroids from water by Tinca tinca is influenced by their affinity for sex steroid binding protein in plasma. Journal of Fish Biology 67, 182-200.
crumbs: 75  Steroid Measurement in Conditioned Water

title: 76  CRISPR/Cas9 Technology
text: Introduction

title: 76  CRISPR/Cas9 Technology
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes CRISPR/Cas9 Technologies used in Threespine Stickleback.
Procedure Type: Vert Experiment
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Sam Peterson and John H. Postlethwait, 2014, Modified by Susie 2/29/2024
Date Created: 2014







CRISPR/Cas9 Technology



This guide describes using the CRISPR/Cas9 system to induce small indels or larger deletions in fish genomes. It includes descriptions of target selection tools, generation and preparation of reagents, and mutation screening approaches. Background information can be found in the publications at the end of this protocol.
Introducing Cas9 enzyme and a guide RNA is used to cause double-stranded breaks at a desired target locus in the genome. DNA repair machinery of the cell seals the break, leaving a small insertion/deletion (indel) in its place. In a coding region, this indel might result in a frame shift that causes the remaining part of the mRNA to be translated incorrectly, such as by generating an early stop codon, and this breaks the function of the protein.
There are two ways to get Cas9 protein into cells. mRNA encoding Cas9 (particularly a version that has been codon adjusted to be translated well in fish) can be injected. In that case, the cell’s own translation machinery uses this RNA to make Cas9 protein. It is economical to generate large amounts of Cas9 RNA in vitro by using a plasmid carrying the Cas9 gene driven by an RNA polymerase promoter (like the T3 promoter). The mRNA is then cleaned, quantified, aliquoted, and stored at -80C until use. (This process is described below).
Alternatively, commercially purified Cas9 protein can be purchased in lyophilized form and reconstituted into a liquid, aliquoted, and stored at -80C until use. We have been using protein from PNA Bio Inc. (CP01-200 200 µg, that comes in four 50 µg aliquots). It arrives lyophilized along with HEPES, KCl and sucrose so that adding 50 µl of water to one of these aliquots reconstitutes the buffer at 1x and the Cas9 at 1 mg/ml. Because we also sometimes co-inject guide RNAs with plasmid knock-in constructs, we have adopted reconstituting in 50 µl of 1 mM DTT instead of pure water, to help prevent needle clogging. 1 µl aliquots are frozen at -80C. For knock-in experiments, Cas9 protein should be preferred over Cas9 mRNA, as it is believed maternal homologous recombination machinery has a short window of opportunity, during the one-cell stage (in other words, a delay due to Cas9 mRNA needing to be translated can be avoided).

title: 76  CRISPR/Cas9 Technology
text:
Materials

Injection rig
Needle puller

xxx

title: 76  CRISPR/Cas9 Technology
text:
Solutions

xxx
xxx
xxx
xxx

title: 76  CRISPR/Cas9 Technology
text:
Procedure

Generation of Cas9 mRNA (if not using Cas9 protein)







Note



There are different plasmids available that can be used to transcribe the Cas9 RNA. The one described in the Jao et al. publication works well. It is available from addgene: Plasmid 46757: pT3TS-nCas9n. Cas9 mRNA can be made by following the protocol outlined in their paper. The plasmid is linearized with XbaI and used as a template after the reaction is purified. mRNA is then synthesized with the T3 mMESSAGE kit (Invitrogen) and cleaned with column purification.
Note: we should have aliquots frozen in strip tubes in the -80C, so it is likely you will not need to make this yourself.


1.  Grow 5ml of bacterial culture containing the pT3TS-nCas9n plasmid (stock located in -80° freezer box “CRISPR Reagents” in ampicillin overnight at 37°.  

2.  Extract plasmid DNA with the QIAprep Spin Miniprep Kit following manufacturer’s instructions. Measure concentration with the Qubit. 

3.  Linearize ~ 10 µg of plasmid with XbaI: 
                43 µl of plasmid DNA and water 
                5 µl NEB 10x buffer 
                2 µl XbaI 
                          
                Incubate overnight at 37C 

4. Clean the restriction reaction with Zymogen DNA Clean and Concentrator 5. At this point you can check the concentration with the Qubit and confirm complete linearization by running a small amount on a 1% agarose gel. There should be a single band at around 7 kb (7,330 bp). 

5. Make capped Cas9 mRNA with the mMESSAGE mMACHINE® T3 Transcription Kit following manufacturer’s instructions. Use about 1 µg of linearized plasmid DNA.  Note: unlike the original CRISPR/Cas9 zebrafish paper, the mRNA is not poly-adenylated with a separate step. Let the reaction go for 2 hours at 37° followed by the 15 minute optional DNAse step. 

6. Clean the reaction with Zymogen RNA Clean and Concentrator 25 and elute in 15-20 µl of nuclease free water. Check the size with 1µl on an agarose gel and measure the concentration with the nanodrop or with Qubit Broad Range RNA kit. 

7. Based on the measured concentration, dilute the remaining product to 200 ng/µl and store 3-4 µl aliquots at -80°C in the box labeled CRISPR reagents.  
Identify Target Sequence






Note



The CRISPR/Cas9 system uses the injection of a guide RNA (gRNA) in conjunction with Cas9 mRNA to create double-strand DNA breaks. Repair of these dsDNA breaks with non-homologous end joining can result in indel mutations or larger deletions spanning two simultaneously targeted sites. The recognition sequence is specified by the gRNA and can be any 20 base pairs that are upstream from NGG. Efficient transcription using a T7 promoter requires the transcript start with GG. This limits the possible recognition sites to GG-(N)18-NGG. This can be relaxed to G-(N)19-NGG if necessary and transcription of these are usually not problematic. The orientation of the target sequence relative to a target gene is not important so sense and anti-sense strands can be searched. Please note that the NGG at the end of the recognition sequence is not considered part of the target site and will not be incorporated into the transcribed gRNA.
Online tools for designing CRISPR targets come and go. Their criteria for scoring prospective targets differ and the different platforms will often identify non-overlapping sets of targets, or they may rank the same sites very differently. Some tools are able to take into account potential off-target sites in the stickleback genome.
These two sites support many species including stickleback (i.e., includes a search of off-target sites). CCtop: https://cctop.cos.uni-heidelberg.de/species.html and ChopChop: http://chopchop.cbu.uib.no
CrisprScan currently supports zebrafish, medaka and killifish but not stickleback, however its algorithm is based on significant empirical testing and appears to perform well: https://www.crisprscan.org/sequence/


1. To use these tools, paste in a DNA sequence that you want to search for potential target sites (e.g., an early exon or flanking region).   

2. Select the T7 promoter to identify target sequences starting with GG. Select the stickleback genome (this is used to check for off-target regions), or in CrisprScan select “No search” (because otherwise the default is zebrafish). 

Tools like CrisprScan will also select targets that might start with GN or NG, in which case it will suggest changing the N to a G. This mismatch will be OK for targeting, and will allow better guide synthesis using T7 RNA polymerase. When generating annotations of your chosen targets in your reference sequence file of the genomic region, it is helpful to designate the orientation of the annotated target (either + or -). 

3. Using target sequences with multiple alignments to the genome or close matches may result in unwanted off-target effects. Use BLAT at https://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgBlat to compare your selected 20 base pair target sequence/s to the stickleback genome to confirm it matches only a single time and BLAT to the human genome to check that there are no matches (relevant to biosafety concerns). If the design tool recommended changing one of the start nucleotides to a G, BLAT the sequence that includes that change in addition to the original genomic target sequence.  

4. If you are using an Oregon stickleback source population, you can and should blast and compare the region of interest against an Oregon reference genome (like Cushman Slough) to confirm there are no polymorphisms in the targets you have selected, as these can reduce obliterate their efficacy. Alternatively, you could amplify the region of interest in the line /source population you are using and Sanger sequence it to ensure your designed target is identical. 






Important Consideration



Important consideration: even when single guide RNAs work well, a functional protein might still be produced. For example, if an indel generated is a multiple of 3 bp, it could delete or add a small number of codons (and therefore amino acids) while not disrupting the reading frame for the rest of the coding region. Such mutations might not abolish or possibly even affect the function of the protein. In order to help circumvent this and also to make it easier to screen indels by size on an electrophoresis gel, design a pair of target sequences that can be injected at the same time to create a larger deletion. Successfully deleted alleles will be easily resolved when PCR products flanking the region are run on a gel. On the other hand, indels produced by a single gRNA might not be discernable from wild type on a gel. Indels will be created around the site of the double-strand break, which will occur three base pairs before the NGG; so, if only a single guide will be used for some reason, you can try to design a single target sequence that would disrupt a restriction enzyme recognition sequence when an indel is created in the expected location. In that case, screening is a two-step process: amplify a fragment around the predicted indel, then try to digest the fragment with the restriction enzyme. Wildtype fragments will be cut, fragments with the indel will not be cut. And, if you’ve designed the positions of your primers well, you can resolve all three fragment sizes on a gel. Alternatively, PCR products can be Sanger sequenced – an expensive way to screen large numbers of prospective CRISPR mutants.


Create gRNA DNA template






Notes



There are multiple methods described for producing gRNA templates. The standard method described in initial publications involves annealing two small oligos and ligating them into a cut vector which is then cloned. I prefer a simpler method which is adapted from one published in Cell Reports (Bassett et al., 2013). It involves using two long oligos in a template-free PCR reaction. The two oligos will partially anneal to each other and the polymerase will fill in the rest yielding a short double-stranded template with a T7 recognition site. One oligo is generic in that it is used in every template production reaction. The other is sequence specific to the target sequence. It should provide essentially the same template as if you were to use the cloning method described in Jao et al., 2013 with the addgene plasmid 46759: pT7-gRNA (the last few nucleotides on the 3 prime end may be different, but these do not seem to matter). This is then used as a template for in vitro transcription. Once the base components are obtained, the only additional thing that needs to be ordered for new targets is the gene specific oligo.


1. Obtain gRNA scaffold oligo (PAGE purified). IDT provides this service for their Ultramer DNA Oligos. A single order should provide enough for at least 100 template synthesis reactions.  






Notes



We have a lab stock of this oligo and you should not need to order it.


5-gatccgcaccgactcggtgccactttttcaagttgataacggactagccttattttaacttgctatttctagctctaaaac-3
2. Order gene-specific oligo. In our hands, this oligo does not need to be PAGE purified. The sequence should be [T7 promoter]-[Target Sequence]-[start of gRNA sequence]. Note: CrisprScan provides a version of this sequence, though it is shorter by a few nucleotides at either end – it probably also works, but the Cresko lab uses the slightly extended sequence below. 
5- aattaatacgactcactata-[20 nt Target Sequence]-gttttagagctagaaatagc-3






Notes



Note: do not include the NGG (the PAM sequence).
Note: if your target is on the minus strand, make sure to reverse complement the target sequence before plugging into this sequence above. In other words, the end facing the NGG should be to the right.
Note: If you haven’t selected a target that already starts with GG, the design software will probably have suggested that targets starting with NG or GN should be changed to GG. Don’t forget to include this suggested change, supporting better T7 transcription.


3. Perform PCR. The two oligos serves both as primers and template. Phusion polymerase is recommended but other polymerases should work as well. 

        - 4µl 5x Buffer 
        - 0.4µl dNTPs (10 mM) 
        - 1 µl of gene specific oligo (10 µM) 
        - 1 µl of gRNA scaffold oligo (10 µM) 
        - 0.2 µl Phusion 
        - 13.4 µl Water 
        
         98° 30 seconds 
         
         40 cycles of:  
         98° 10 seconds 
         60° 10 seconds 
         72° 15 seconds 
         72° 10 mins 

 

4. Clean the PCR reaction with column-based method (e.g., Zymo DNA Clean and Concentrator kit) or at least 2.5x volume of Omega beads (SB). At this point, the concentration can be checked and the product can be analyzed on a gel. It should be a single 125 bp band. [Susie adds: With Zymo columns, eluting in 20 µl, this reaction yields about 25 ng/µl. For short templates, the Megascript kit recommends using 100-200 ng per reaction. So for a half reaction, you would use 2-4 µl of the PCR product]. 

5. Use as template for in vitro transcription with either, MAXIscript® T7 Kit or MEGAscript® T7 Kit, both by Invitrogen. Perform the optional DNAse step and clean with column based method. Both kits should produce enough RNA. However, the MEGAscript T7 Kit will produce much more. I prefer using 4 µl of the template in a half reaction of the MEGAscript T7 Kit. The reaction can be extended for several hours or overnight to increase yield if necessary. After column based purification, it usually provides around 1 µg/µl in a 25µl elution but this can be quite variable. The RNA can be checked on a gel, but the results can be difficult to interpret due to heavy secondary structure. It usually looks like one or two bands around 100 and 200 bp. 

 
Inject Cas9 mRNA and gRNA into one-celled embryos






Notes



Embryos should be injected at the one cell stage according to standard protocols. Briefly, as soon as feasible, separate and clean fertilized embryos and, in filter sterilized embryo medium, load them into the grooves milled into a plastic insert fitting in a square plastic dish. They need to be held securely but do not necessarily have to be pushed to the bottom of the groove. Eggs from different clutches can differ in diameter; choose the width of the milled groove and depth of embryos within the groove to hold them without applying too much compression. The blastomere should be oriented up or slightly tilted toward the direction of the injection needle. A high concentration of Cas9 mRNA (2nl of 300 ng/µl as suggested in early papers) can cause mortality (reported by JHP lab). Lower concentrations (100 ng/µl or lower) seem to be just as effective and cause less developmental defects and death. The gRNA concentration does not seem to matter as much (reported concentrations range greatly, from 1 ng/µl to almost 100 ng/µl). Higher concentrations of gRNA do not seem to cause any additional defects or mortality. I recommend starting at 100 ng/µl Cas9 with 50 ng/µl gRNA. If mutagenesis is not detected with these concentrations than check the RNA prep or consider that there may be a problem with the target location. Some target sites do not work as well as others. Additionally, it is useful to sequence the target region in the fish being used for injections to confirm that the reference genome sequence is accurate. If mutagenesis rates are successful, then the injection concentrations can be changed based on mortality/deformity percentages and mutation efficiency. The gRNA concentration can likely be lowered significantly without affecting efficiency. Checking potential off-targets is advised as well and might influence the ideal injection concentrations. If a positive control is desired, the fh (second target site) gRNA described in Hwang et al. works at a high level of efficiency.


Inject embryos
If using Cas9 mRNA
1. On ice, prepare injection mixture in water with 1/10 volume phenol red*: 
  
  100 ng/µl Cas9 mRNA (range 50 to 100 ng/µl) 
  50 ng/µl gRNA (use 50 ng/µl of each gRNA if targeting multiple sites) 
If using Cas9 protein
2. To preload protein, mix in these final concentrations (according the PNA Bio recommendations for zebrafish**): 
  
  500 ng/µl Cas9 protein (range: about 200-800 ng/µl) 
  250 ng/µl gRNA (range: about 100-400 ng/µl) 
  Incubate for 5’ at 37C then put on ice. 
  Add 1/10 volume phenol red* 






Notes



*Note: before thawing your other reagents, thaw and vortex the phenol red stock. Centrifuge the tube at max speed for 10 minutes to pellet any needle-clogging precipitate before adding some to your other injection reagents.
**Note: the reason for these ranges is that different targets work with different efficiencies. Also, you might be constrained in final concentrations if, for example, you want to use more than one guide in combination, as the volume of each reagent you add dilutes the constituents.


3. Inject into the cell at the one-cell stage (1-2 nl). 
Screen Embryos for Mutations
::: {.callout-note title=“Notes”} Large deletions induced by using multiple gRNAs can be screened for with PCR. Mutagenesis in the form of induced indels can be detected with either the Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) assay, or by Sanger sequencing of amplicons. The RFLP assay detects changes in a restriction enzyme recognition sequence. Sanger sequencing amplicons from injected embryos can detect mosaicism at the target site. Screening 48 hpf embryos that appear to be developmentally normally provides a good measure of whether or not mutations were induced and to what degree. Later stages that are developing abnormally and would not survive anyway can also be euthanized and screened. Uninjected siblings should always be used as negative controls.
:::
Lysis-based DNA prep (this provides DNA that is not clean but accessible enough for PCR)
  1. Collect and euthanize embryos according to standard protocols (individuals or in groups of up to 5). If they are still in chorions, they should be crushed with a blue plastic pestle or chorions can be poked or crushed with sharp foreceps. 
  
  2. Remove water and lyse embryos with HotShot method (Meeker et al. 2007) 
  
  3. Add 100 µl of 50mM NaOH (50 µl for an individual embryo) 
  
  4. Heat at 95° for 20 mins 
  
  5. Chill on ice and neutralize with 10ul of 1 M Tris-HCl, pH 8.0 (5 µl for an individual embryo) 
RFLP Assay
::: {.callout-note title=“Notes”} This assay only works if there is a unique restriction enzyme recognition sequence located around the 3` end of the target sequence. If the recognition sequence is altered by successful mutagenesis, the restriction enzyme will no longer be able to cut the PCR product.
:::
1. Perform PCR (look to amplify a 300-600 bp amplicon surrounding expected mutation site), preferably with the indel location positioned off-center with respect to the expected amplicon so that two different fragment lengths will be produced after cutting 

2. Run 2 µl of reaction on a gel to confirm a single band at the proper length 

3. Clean the PCR reaction with preferred method and cut with the appropriate restriction enzyme. For many restriction enzymes, purification of the reaction is not necessary. 

4. Run the reaction on a gel to determine if the restriction enzyme recognition site was altered. Results from uninjected embryos should show a completely digested product. Successful mutagenesis can be qualitatively estimated by looking at the intensity of the undigested PCR product. 
Sanger Sequencing
1. Perform PCR (look to amplify a 300-600 bp amplicon surrounding expected mutation site). Run some of the reaction on a gel to confirm a correct sized product was amplified. 

2. Clean the rest of the reaction with preferred reaction clean-up method, elute in 50 µl, and send the reaction out for Sanger sequencing. The concentration can be measured at this point (although usually 1 µl is sufficient for Sanger sequencing).     

3. Send the PCR products to Genewiz according to their recommendations. 

4. Analyze results to estimate mutagenesis efficiency. It is not very useful to look at the actual sequence that is returned. It is much more informative to look at the trace file with the actual peaks. 

5. Results from uninjected embryos should be very clean with a single peak at each nucleotide position. Occasionally there will be two peaks for one nucleotide when the individual carried a polymorphism. It is also recommended to confirm that the fish do not carry polymorphisms in the target sequence region as this could drastically lower or abolish mutagenesis efficiency. 

6. Sequencing results from injected embryos should show nice clean peaks until near the target region where the quality should dramatically drop off (see attached trace image). 

7. There are online tools (e.g., https://tide.nki.nl/#about) to try to algorithmically disentangle the alleles present and their predicted frequencies in the mosaic fish from this kind of  sequence trace file (also called a chromatogram). 
Insert image if sequence here

Sequence from successful mutagenesis attempt

F1 Screening
::: {.callout-note title=“Notes”} The goal of using CRISPR/Cas9 is to obtain a stable mutant line. Injected fish should be considered potential mosaic carriers of mutations at the target region. Some cells will contain the unmutated wild-type sequence while other cells will carry mutations. Also to be noted is that different cells will contain different mutations. By outcrossing potential carriers, stable heterozygous mutant carriers can be obtained and identified.
The process of obtaining F1 carriers can be split into a few steps. Below lists the key steps followed by a brief explanation of options and thoughts on how to minimize the time to obtain mutants, cost of screening, number of tanks used and effort required. :::
1. Outcross injected fish to wildtype background. 

2. Screen outcrossed clutches to estimate efficiency of mutation inheritance.  

3. Raise clutch that has decent inheritance efficiency. 

4. Fin clip potential F1 carriers and identify carriers. 

5. Sequence mutation carriers to determine exact molecular nature of mutation. 

6. Select fish who carry a desirable mutation. 






Notes




Usually, 25 injected fish are put into the fry rack and raised to adulthood. Sometimes the injections cause developmental delays or issues that impact initial survival. In these cases, more than 25 fish can be put into the nursery. However, there isn’t a significant advantage raising more than 1 tank of injected fish. Injected fish should carry mutations at reasonable rates. If 25 fish are screened and none of them pass on a mutation the problem is better resolved by re-injecting at a higher concentration or using a different target site. When the fish reach a breedable age, 3 or 4 fish should be pairwise mated with wildtype stocks. These clutches should be kept separate so inheritance efficiency can be measured.
Out-crossed fish will be raised to adulthood before they are IDd and the exact molecular nature of the mutation is determined. This takes several months and takes up tank space. Screening clutches to estimate inheritance efficiency is recommended to avoid 2 things: 1) the need to raise several tanks of different clutches to insure that a mutant carrier is obtained 2) wasting several months waiting for fish to grow to find out that none of them carry a mutation.
Raise 25 fish from 1 or 2 clutches of F1 fish to adulthood. These should be selected based on the initial clutch screening. The F0 fish should be maintained until a stable line is obtained. Inheritance efficiency of individual clutches can be estimated by testing siblings by PCR (to detect a large deletion or via RFLP if there is an appropriate restriction enzyme site. Fish that are not carriers of mutations will give a PCR product that is completely digested by the restriction enzyme while those that carry a mutation will show a prominent undigested band.
Sanger sequencing of amplicons from carriers is used to determine the exact nature of the mutation. This is important for several reasons 1) not all mutations are predicted to cause a loss-of-function (it is important that the mutation causes a frame-shift or early termination codon) 2) knowing the exact nature of the mutation is important for developing a genotyping protocol and reporting results. There are a few options for how to do this. The PCR product from identified carriers can be cloned and then sequenced. This gives an easy to read result but is slightly costly and time consuming. The other option is to directly sequence the PCR products without cloning. This is easier and more cost effective but requires some effort to determine the mutation.

Unlike the results of injected embryos which potentially carry many different alleles, the F1 carriers should be wildtype or should be heterozygous with one wildtype and one mutant allele if they are carriers. If the sequence is clean throughout (or the trace file shows only, e.g., a naturally occurring SNP), then the fish is not a carrier. If the sequence starts clean but then turns into a series of double and sometimes single peaks, then the fish is likely a carrier of an indel mutation. Since the WT sequence is known, the sequence of the mutation can be read by “subtracting” the WT peaks (if at a given nucleotide position the WT sequence is expected to be A and there is a peak for A and T, then the mutant allele has a T at that position – if there is a single peak, then both the mutant and WT sequence has the same nucleotide at that position). See picture. Again, there are online tools to disentangle the WT and mutant allele sequences (https://tide.nki.nl/#about).
insert image here

It is likely that screening 1 or 2 clutches of F1 fish will produce multiple carriers of different mutations. At this point a decision must be made at which fish should be kept. It is advantageous to have multiple alleles of a mutation so that a phenotype can be confirmed. However, saving more than 2 alleles increases tank usage but doesn’t offer that much of an advantage. It is helpful when a male and a female carrier of the same allele are identified so that they can be bred to obtain a homozygous mutant without having to have an additional outcross generation.

Associated Papers
- Efficient genome editing in zebrafish using a CRISPR-Cas system. (Hwang et al., 2013)
- Efficient multiplex biallelic zebrafish genome editing using a CRISPR nuclease system. (Jao et al., 2013).

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text: Introduction
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Purpose: This method allows the production of haploid embryos for screening recessive mutations. Haploid embryos develop fairly normally for the first few days, but eventually develop bent tails and vacuolated body cavities. They are inviable and typically die by 7-10 days post fertilization.
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering UV irradiation of gametes and production of haploid embryos.








Background



This is a general procedure for producing UV-inactivated sperm that can still activate eggs but cannot contribute genetic material. The resulting haploid embryos are useful for: - Screening for recessive lethal mutations - Identifying maternal effect genes - Rapid phenotypic screening
The UV treatment damages the sperm DNA, preventing it from participating in development, while leaving the sperm motile enough to activate the egg.








Safety - UV Radiation




UV light can cause severe eye damage and skin burns
Always wear safety glasses with UV protection
Wear gloves and protective clothing
Never look directly at UV lamp
Ensure proper ventilation
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Materials

Watchglass (sterile)
Large glass Petri dish with cover
Ice
Two Pasteur pipettes (sterile)
Pipette bulb
Stopwatch
UV Stratalinker 1800 (Stratagene) or equivalent UV crosslinker
Latex or nitrile gloves
UV-protective safety glasses
Small test tube with cork, marked “UV sperm”
Beaker for ice bath
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Solutions

Hank’s solution - see ?sec-general_recipe_hanks
Embryo medium for fertilization - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Procedure

Preparation

Prepare ice bath: Fill the bottom of the glass Petri dish with ice.
Set up watchglass: Place watchglass on top of the ice in the dish to keep sperm cool.



Sperm Transfer and UV Treatment

Transfer sperm to watchglass:

Using a clean Pasteur pipette, transfer the sperm from the collection tube onto the chilled watchglass.
Get as much of the sperm into the pipette as possible without taking up any air bubbles.
Do NOT bubble the sperm as you expel them from the pipette.
Expel sperm in a thin, even layer on the watchglass for uniform UV exposure.








Important



DISCARD THIS PIPETTE after use - do not reuse for collecting UV-treated sperm.



Cover sperm: Place the cover on the Petri dish to protect from contamination during setup.
Prepare for UV exposure:

Put on latex/nitrile gloves
Put on UV-protective safety glasses

Position under UV lamp: Place the covered Petri dish under the UV Stratalinker.
UV treatment:

Remove the cover from the Petri dish
Start the stopwatch immediately
Gently move the dish under the lamp in a swirling motion for two minutes
This ensures even UV exposure across all sperm

Complete UV treatment:

After exactly two minutes of UV exposure, replace the cover on the Petri dish
Remove the dish from under the UV lamp




Collection and Storage

Collect UV-treated sperm:

Using a CLEAN (new) Pasteur pipette, remove the UV-treated sperm from the watchglass
Transfer sperm to the small test tube marked “UV sperm”

Store on ice: Place the UV sperm test tube into an ice bath until ready to fertilize eggs.



Fertilization

Use for fertilization: Use UV-treated sperm to fertilize eggs according to standard stickleback crossing protocols (see Chapter 49).

Haploid embryos should be monitored for viability
Expect higher mortality than normal diploid embryos
Screen for phenotypes of interest before embryos become inviable (typically by 7 dpf)
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Quality Control






Verifying UV Treatment Success




Control fertilization: Fertilize a small batch of eggs with untreated sperm as a positive control
Test batch: Fertilize eggs with UV-treated sperm; lack of cleavage or abnormal development indicates successful UV treatment
If normal development occurs, sperm DNA was not sufficiently inactivated; increase UV exposure time
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Related Protocols

Stickleback crossing: Chapter 49
Hank’s solution preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_hanks
Embryo medium: ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Normal diploid development: UV exposure was insufficient; increase exposure time in 30-second increments
No activation of eggs: UV exposure was too long or sperm were damaged; reduce UV exposure time
Poor sperm motility after UV: Sperm may have been too warm during treatment; ensure watchglass is well-chilled
crumbs: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback

title: 77  Production of Haploid Embryos in Stickleback
text:
Associated Papers

Papers on haploid screening in fish
Streisinger, G., et al. (1981). Production of clones of homozygous diploid zebra fish (Brachydanio rerio). Nature.
Walker, C. & Streisinger, G. (1983). Induction of Mutations by γ-Rays in Pregonial Germ Cells of Zebrafish Embryos. Genetics.
Papers on gynogenesis and androgenesis techniques

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text: Introduction

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Purpose: Storage of unfertilized stickleback eggs for fertilization up to 24 hours post-stripping. This protocol allows for temporal separation of egg collection and fertilization, facilitating experimental design and cross logistics.
Procedure Type: Vertebrate Experimental
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 01, 2024







IACUC Protocol Required



This procedure requires an active IACUC protocol covering egg stripping and fertilization procedures.








Background



Unfertilized stickleback eggs can be stored in a specialized storage medium containing antibiotics to prevent bacterial growth. This allows eggs to be: - Transported between facilities - Collected and fertilized at different times - Stored while preparing sperm or other materials
Storage on ice extends egg viability up to 24 hours, with best results when fertilized within 12 hours.

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Materials

Streptomycin & Penicillin Solution (PenStrep) from Sigma (P-0906) - 100% stock
50 ml sterile polypropylene conical tubes
90 mm petri dishes (sterile)
Ice bucket or cooler with ice
Transfer pipettes

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Solutions

Holtfreter’s Solution - see ?sec-general_recipe_holtfrieters
Embryo medium - see ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium
Egg storage solution (prepare fresh for each use):

Add PenStrep to Holtfreter’s solution for a final concentration of 1%
(10 ml PenStrep stock into 1 liter Holtfreter’s solution)
Keep chilled at 4°C

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Procedure

Egg Collection and Storage

Prepare egg storage solution:

Add 10 ml of PenStrep stock to 1 liter of Holtfreter’s solution (1% final concentration)
Chill on ice

Collect eggs:

Strip eggs from ripe female into a 50 ml conical tube containing 25 ml of cold egg storage solution
Work quickly to minimize time eggs are unfertilized

Store eggs:

Cap the tube tightly
Store on ice (or at 4°C)








Storage Duration



Eggs can be transported on ice and fertilized up to 24 hours later. However, fertilization success is highest when eggs are used within 12 hours of collection.




Fertilization of Stored Eggs

Equilibrate temperature:

Transfer eggs to a 90 mm petri dish
Allow temperature to equilibrate to 20°C (room temperature)
This takes approximately 15-20 minutes

Prepare for fertilization:

Remove egg storage solution from petri dish
Rinse eggs once with fresh embryo medium
Important: This rinse lowers the salt concentration, which is essential for optimal sperm activation

Fertilize:

Add macerated testis preparation as usual (see Chapter 49)
Cover eggs with embryo medium
Allow fertilization to proceed for 1-2 minutes
Add additional embryo medium to dilute sperm

Incubate: Transfer fertilized eggs to incubator at 20°C for development.

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Quality Control






Monitoring Fertilization Success




Check fertilization rates after 2-4 hours (look for cell division)
Compare to fresh (non-stored) egg controls
Expected fertilization rates may be slightly lower than fresh eggs, especially after 12+ hours storage
Document storage time and fertilization success for optimization

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Related Protocols

Stickleback crossing (fertilization): Chapter 49
Holtfreter’s solution preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_holtfrieters
Embryo medium preparation: ?sec-general_recipe_embryo_medium

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Low fertilization rates: Eggs may have been stored too long; try to fertilize within 12 hours. Check that eggs were kept cold throughout storage.
Bacterial contamination: Ensure egg storage solution contains fresh antibiotics and all materials are sterile.
Poor egg quality: Female may not have been fully ripe; ensure proper conditioning and timing of egg stripping.
Sperm not activated: Ensure thorough rinse with embryo medium to remove high salt from storage solution.

title: 78  Storage of Stickleback Eggs
text:
Associated Papers

Papers on fish egg storage and viability
Stickleback husbandry and breeding protocols
Studies on gamete storage in teleost fishes

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text: Introduction

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Purpose: This procedure describes how to dechorionate zebrafish embryos.
Procedure Type: Vertebrate experiment
Species:

Zebrafish (Danio rerio)

Author:
Date Created:

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Materials

Two pairs of Dumont #5 forceps
Fire-polished wide-bore Pasteur pipet
If using enzymatic dechorionation:

6X flyfishing tippet
Capillary tube

Microscope

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Solutions

E3 medium (quantities for 5 L of 60X stock listed after each ingredient in parentheses)

5 mM NaCl (86 g)
0.17 mM KCl (3.8 g)
0.33 mM CaCl2 (14.5 g CaCl2 x 2H2O)
0.333 mM MgSO4 (24.5 g MgSO4 x 7H2O)
0.00001% (w/v) Methylene Blue (to be added to 1X solution)

2 mg/ml Pronase in E3 medium (Pronase Solution made from solid Powder (Roche 165921))

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Procedure

Method 1: Manual Dechorionation
Chorions can be removed easily using two pairs of forceps. Critical: Forceps tips must be sharp and able to touch precisely.

Position embryo: Place embryos in E3 medium in a petri dish under a dissecting microscope.
Tear chorion:

Using one pair of forceps, gently hold the chorion to stabilize it.
With the other pair of forceps, make a small tear in the chorion.

Release embryo:

Grasp the chorion on the side opposite the tear with one pair of forceps.
Gently push the embryo through the opening by passing the chorion and embryo between the tips of the other pair of forceps.
The embryo should slide out through the tear.








Handle with Care



Embryos younger than 15 hours post fertilization (hpf) are particularly fragile and great care must be taken not to damage them. Work slowly and gently.




Method 2: Enzymatic Dechorionation (Bulk Processing)
Alternatively, embryos can be enzymatically dechorionated in bulk:

Prepare embryos: Collect embryos in a petri dish.
Pronase treatment:

Incubate embryos in Pronase Solution (2 mg/ml in E3) at room temperature.
Duration: 1-10 minutes, depending on embryonic stage (older embryos require longer treatment).

Monitor chorion integrity:

Use a poker (made by attaching a loop of 6X flyfishing tippet to a capillary tube).
Gently depress chorions under a microscope.
When chorions no longer return to a spherical shape, the Pronase treatment is complete.

Wash embryos:

Thoroughly wash embryos 3-4 times in fresh E3 medium to remove all Pronase.
Using a fire-polished wide-bore Pasteur pipette, gently pipette embryos back and forth.
The weakened chorions should break open, releasing embryos.

Transfer dechorionated embryos:

Handle dechorionated embryos using only fire-polished Pasteur pipettes to minimize damage.
Transfer to fresh E3 medium.

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Post-Dechorionation Care






Maintaining Embryo Health




Keep dechorionated embryos in E3 medium at 28.5°C
Dechorionated embryos are more susceptible to bacterial contamination - maintain clean conditions
Remove dead embryos promptly
Change medium daily
Expect slightly higher mortality compared to chorionated embryos

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Related Protocols

Zebrafish husbandry and breeding
Embryo microinjection procedures
Live imaging protocols

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Troubleshooting






Common Issues




Embryos damaged during manual dechorionation: Forceps may be too dull or technique too forceful; practice on older, more robust embryos first.
Incomplete pronase digestion: Increase pronase concentration or incubation time; check pronase activity.
Over-digestion with pronase: Embryos appear damaged or sticky; reduce incubation time and monitor more frequently.
High mortality after dechorionation: May indicate damage during processing; ensure pipettes are properly fire-polished and handle embryos gently.

title: 79  Dechorionating Zebrafish Embryos
text:
Associated Papers

Westerfield, M. The Zebrafish Book. A Guide for the Laboratory Use of Zebrafish (Danio rerio). 5th Edition. University of Oregon Press, Eugene.
Kimmel, C.B., et al. (1995). Stages of embryonic development of the zebrafish. Dev Dyn 203:253-310.
