title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text: Introduction

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Purpose: Recipe for Dietrich’s fixative for preserving sentinel fish and tissue samples
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: February 29, 2024







Note



When fixing sentinel fish use Dietrich’s fixative.








Safety Warning



Chemical Hazards: Formalin (formaldehyde solution) is toxic, carcinogenic, and irritating to skin, eyes, and respiratory system. Glacial acetic acid is corrosive and causes severe burns.
Required PPE: - Nitrile gloves (double-gloving recommended) - Safety glasses or goggles - Lab coat - Work in a fume hood
Disposal: Formalin-containing waste must be disposed of as hazardous chemical waste. Label container clearly and follow institutional chemical waste disposal procedures.

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Materials

Ethanol (95%)
Formalin (Formaldehyde 37% solution, histological grade, contains 10-15% methanol, Sigma # F1635)
Glacial Acetic Acid
Distilled Water

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Procedure

Prepare Dietrich’s Fixative (100 ml) in a fume hood by mixing:

30 ml Ethanol (95%)
10 ml Formalin (Formaldehyde 37% solution, histological grade, contains 10-15% methanol, Sigma # F1635)
2 ml Glacial Acetic Acid
58 ml Distilled Water

Mix thoroughly and transfer to a labeled, sealed container.

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature
Duration: Stable for several months when properly sealed
Container: Glass bottle with tight-sealing lid, stored in chemical cabinet or fume hood
Label: Clearly mark as “Dietrich’s Fixative” with date prepared and hazard warnings

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Quality Control

Solution should be clear and colorless
Discard if solution becomes cloudy or develops precipitate
Strong formaldehyde odor is normal

title: 81  Dietrich’s Fixative
text:
Related Protocols

Used in sentinel fish preservation protocols

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text: Introduction

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Purpose: Recipe for embryo medium used in stickleback embryo culture and rearing
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 1, 2004

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Materials

Instant Ocean Salt
Baking Soda (sodium bicarbonate)
Nanopure water (npH2O)
2 liter glass flasks
pH meter or pH strips
Analytical balance
Weigh boats or paper

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Procedure
For 2 liters:

Add 8 g Instant Ocean Salt to 2 liters of npH2O
Add approximately 0.5 g baking soda
Mix thoroughly until all solids are dissolved
Check pH and adjust to 7.0 - 8.0

If pH is too low, add small amounts of baking soda
If pH is too high, allow to equilibrate or prepare fresh solution








Note



Salt and baking soda are located in containers near the weigh station. Rinse 2 liter flasks with DI water between uses.

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature
Duration: Use within 1-2 weeks; prepare fresh for optimal embryo health
Container: Clean, sterile 2 liter glass flasks
Label: Mark with “Embryo Medium”, date prepared, and pH value

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Quality Control

pH: Must be between 7.0 - 8.0 for optimal embryo development
Appearance: Solution should be clear and free of particulates
Conductivity: Should be approximately 4-6 mS/cm (similar to natural freshwater conditions)
Verification: Check pH before each use; discard if pH has drifted outside acceptable range







Best Practices




Prepare fresh embryo medium weekly for best results
Always rinse flasks thoroughly with DI water between batches
Allow solution to equilibrate to room temperature before adding embryos

title: 82  Stickleback Embryo Medium (EM)
text:
Related Protocols

Used in embryo collection and rearing protocols
See stickleback husbandry protocols for additional information

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text: Introduction

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making Ginzberg’s Ringer solution, a physiological saline solution for fish tissues
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 1, 2004

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Materials

NaCl (sodium chloride)
KCl (potassium chloride)
CaCl2 (calcium chloride)
NaHCO3 (sodium bicarbonate)
Nanopure water (npH2O)
1 liter glass bottle or flask
Analytical balance
Weigh boats or paper
Stir bar and stir plate







Note



All of these reagents should be located in the chemical cabinet.








Safety



PPE Required: Lab coat, safety glasses, and gloves when handling chemicals.
Handling: Calcium chloride is hygroscopic and can cause skin and eye irritation. Handle in well-ventilated area.

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Procedure
For 1000 ml:

Add 750 ml of npH2O to a clean 1 liter glass bottle
Add the following reagents while stirring:

6.6 g NaCl
0.25 g KCl
0.3 g CaCl2
0.2 g NaHCO3

Stir until all solids are completely dissolved
Bring to 1 liter total volume with npH2O
Mix thoroughly and transfer to labeled storage bottle

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Storage

Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator)
Duration: Stable for 2-3 months when stored properly
Container: Clean glass bottle with tight-sealing lid
Label: Mark with “Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution”, date prepared, and storage temperature

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
pH: Should be approximately 7.2-7.6
Verification: Check for clarity before each use; discard if cloudy or contaminated
Sterility: For long-term storage, solution can be filter-sterilized (0.22 μm) or autoclaved







Usage Notes




Allow solution to warm to room temperature or desired working temperature before use
Used for tissue dissection, sperm collection, and other physiological procedures
See Chapter 85 for modified version with antibiotics

title: 83  Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in testes dissection and sperm collection procedures
Base solution for Chapter 85 (Testes Storage Solution)

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text: Introduction

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making a mesab (tricaine) stock solution used for fish anesthesia
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 1, 2004







Note



Mesab also known as Tricaine must be pharmaceutical-grade. We use tricaine purchased from Pentair, manufactured by Western Chemical and FDA approved. Tricaine (3-amino benzoic acid ethyl ester also called ethyl m-aminobenzoate) comes in a powdered form. Purchase the smallest amount possible because tricaine expires quickly.








Safety Warning



Chemical Hazards: Tricaine (MS-222) can cause skin and respiratory irritation. Avoid breathing powder or mist.
Required PPE: - Nitrile gloves - Safety glasses - Lab coat - Dust mask when handling powder
Handling: Work in well-ventilated area. Wash hands thoroughly after handling.
Disposal: Follow institutional guidelines for pharmaceutical waste disposal.

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Materials

Mesab powder (MS-222, tricaine, or 3-aminobenzoic acid ethyl ester) - pharmaceutical grade
1 M Tris (pH 9)
Distilled deionized (DD) water
pH meter or pH strips
Analytical balance
1 liter graduated cylinder or volumetric flask
50 ml conical tubes for aliquoting
Stir bar and stir plate

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Procedure
For 1 liter stock solution (4 g/L):

Weigh 4 g tricaine powder and add to a clean 1 liter container
Add 979 ml DD water
Stir to dissolve powder completely
Add approximately 21 ml of 1 M Tris (pH 9)
Check pH and adjust to pH 7.0 using additional Tris solution
Mix thoroughly to ensure complete dissolution and pH equilibration
Aliquot into 50 ml conical tubes
Label each tube with “MESAB Stock Solution 4 g/L”, date prepared, and expiration date

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Storage

Temperature: -20°C (freezer)
Duration: 3-6 months; tricaine degrades over time
Container: 50 ml conical tubes with tight-sealing caps
Label: Include concentration (4 g/L), date prepared, and expiration date
Expiration: Note that tricaine powder expires quickly; check manufacturer’s expiration date

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Quality Control

pH: Must be pH 7.0 for safe use in fish
Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless to pale yellow
Efficacy: If fish take longer than normal to become anesthetized, solution may be degraded
Storage check: Discard if solution has developed precipitate or unusual odor







Usage Notes




Stock solution (4 g/L) must be diluted before use with fish
Typical working concentration is 1:10 to 1:20 dilution (200-400 mg/L)
Always buffer to pH 7.0 before use
Thaw aliquots at room temperature before use
Do not refreeze thawed aliquots

title: 84  Mesab Stock Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in fish anesthesia protocols for surgery, imaging, and tissue collection
See husbandry protocols for proper dilution and usage instructions

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text: Introduction

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making testes storage solution with antibiotics for preserving dissected testes and sperm
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: January 1, 2004

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Materials

Gentamycin (antimycotic) stock - 10 mg/ml
Cell Culture antibiotic/antimycotic from Gibco-BRL (catalog #15240-096), 100x concentration
Micropipettes (100 μl)
Sterile pipette tips
Sterile containers for storage







Note



Both of these reagents are located in separate boxes in the scientific -20°C freezer. They are partitioned into 100 μl aliquots.








Safety



PPE Required: Gloves and lab coat when handling antibiotics.
Sterile Technique: Use aseptic technique when preparing solution to prevent contamination.

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Solutions

Chapter 83 (Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution) - 100 ml

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Procedure
For 100 ml:

Thaw one 100 μl aliquot of Gentamycin (10 mg/ml) and one 100 μl aliquot of antibiotic/antimycotic (100x) at room temperature
Prepare 100 ml of Ginzberg’s Ringer Solution (see Chapter 83)
Add 100 μl of Gentamycin to the Ginzberg’s Ringer solution
Add 100 μl of antibiotic/antimycotic to the Ginzberg’s Ringer solution
Mix thoroughly by swirling or gentle inversion
Transfer to a sterile, labeled container

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Storage

Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator)
Duration: Use within 1-2 weeks; prepare fresh for best results
Container: Sterile glass or plastic bottle with tight-sealing lid
Label: Mark with “Testes Storage Solution”, date prepared, and expiration date

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
Sterility: If cloudiness or contamination appears, discard immediately
Effectiveness: Testes/sperm should remain viable for several hours when kept on ice in this solution







Usage Notes




Keep solution on ice during testes dissections
Use sterile instruments to prevent contamination
Solution helps preserve sperm viability and prevent bacterial growth
Typically used during breeding season for in vitro fertilization procedures

title: 85  Testes Storage Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in testes dissection and sperm collection protocols
Required for Chapter 83 as base solution
See breeding and fertilization protocols for detailed usage

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text: Introduction

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for 8% Paraformaldehyde (PFA) Stock Solution used for tissue fixation in immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: February 29, 2024







Safety Warning



CRITICAL: This procedure must be performed in a chemical fume hood at all times.
Chemical Hazards: Paraformaldehyde is highly toxic, carcinogenic, and a severe irritant. Powder and vapors are extremely dangerous.
Required PPE: - Double nitrile gloves - Safety goggles or face shield - Lab coat - Work entirely in fume hood
Acute Exposure Risks: - Inhalation: Severe respiratory irritation, potential lung damage - Skin contact: Burns and sensitization - Eye contact: Severe damage, potential blindness - Ingestion: Potentially fatal
Disposal: PFA waste must be disposed of as hazardous chemical waste. Never pour down drain. Follow institutional chemical waste disposal procedures.

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Materials

Paraformaldehyde powder (located in chemical cabinet)
Distilled water
Hot plate with magnetic stirrer
Magnetic stir bar
pH meter
Thermometer
0.45 μm or 0.2 μm filter apparatus
Cryogenic vials or tubes for aliquoting
Graduated cylinders

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Solutions

10 N NaOH
20% HCl

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Procedure






Critical Warning



USE A FUME HOOD FOR THE ENTIRE PROCEDURE!
All steps must be performed with adequate ventilation. Never remove containers from fume hood until sealed.



In fume hood, add 40 g paraformaldehyde powder to 450 ml distilled water in a glass beaker (or scale for desired final volume)
Add 1 μl of 10 N NaOH per ml of water (i.e., 500 μl for 500 ml total volume)
Place beaker on hot plate with stir bar and apply medium heat while stirring at medium speed

Heat for approximately 15-20 minutes
Monitor temperature - solution must not exceed 60°C
Granules will gradually dissolve and solution will become translucent








Critical Warning



DO NOT LET THE SOLUTION STIR BEYOND THIS POINT - over-stirring will form a fuzzy precipitate that reduces the solution strength after filtering. Stop immediately when solution clears.



Once granules have completely dissolved and solution is clear, turn off heat
Allow to cool slightly, then equilibrate to pH 7.4 using approximately 1.5 ml of 20% HCl

Add HCl slowly while monitoring pH
Scale HCl volume depending on final target volume
Bring final volume to 500 ml (or scaled volume) with distilled water

Filter while still warm through 0.45 μm filter (or 0.2 μm for extra purity)

Filtering while warm improves flow rate
Use vacuum filtration apparatus in fume hood

Aliquot into labeled cryogenic vials or tubes

Typical aliquot size: 1-5 ml
Label clearly with “8% PFA”, date, and hazard warnings

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Storage

Temperature: -20°C (freezer)
Duration: Stable for 6-12 months when frozen
Container: Cryogenic vials or sealed tubes that can withstand freezing
Label: Must include “8% PFA”, “TOXIC”, date prepared, and expiration date
Thawing: Thaw aliquots in fume hood or well-ventilated area

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Quality Control

pH: Must be 7.4 ± 0.1 for optimal fixation
Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
Concentration verification: Can be verified by refractive index or other analytical methods
Discard if: Solution is cloudy, has precipitate, or has been frozen/thawed more than 3 times







Usage Notes




For 4% PFA working solution, dilute 8% stock 1:1 with 2x PBS
Always work with PFA in fume hood, even when using working solutions
Warm aliquots to room temperature before opening to prevent condensation
Do not refreeze thawed aliquots multiple times

title: 86  8% Paraformaldehyde Stock Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in immunohistochemistry protocols
Used in in situ hybridization protocols
See fixation protocols for proper usage and timing

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text: Introduction

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for Hank’s balanced salt solution, a physiological buffer used for cell and tissue culture
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 07, 2024







Note



This protocol uses a stock solution system. Prepare all stock solutions first, then make the premix, and finally prepare the working solution fresh as needed.

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Materials

NaCl (sodium chloride)
KCl (potassium chloride)
CaCl2 (calcium chloride)
MgSO4·7H2O (magnesium sulfate heptahydrate)
Na2HPO4 anhydrous (sodium phosphate dibasic)
KH2PO4 (potassium phosphate monobasic)
NaHCO3 (sodium bicarbonate)
Distilled deionized water (ddH2O)
Analytical balance
Graduated cylinders
Glass bottles for stock storage
Stir bars and stir plate







Safety



PPE Required: Lab coat, safety glasses, and gloves when handling chemicals.
Handling: Calcium chloride is hygroscopic. Keep container tightly sealed when not in use.

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Solutions

Hank’s Stock Solutions
Prepare the following stock solutions:
Stock #1: - 8.0 g NaCl - 0.4 g KCl - Dissolve in ddH2O and bring to 100 ml total volume
Stock #2: - 0.358 g Na2HPO4 (anhydrous) - 0.60 g KH2PO4 - Dissolve in ddH2O and bring to 100 ml total volume
Stock #4: - 0.72 g CaCl2 - Dissolve in ddH2O and bring to 50 ml total volume
Stock #5: - 1.23 g MgSO4·7H2O - Dissolve in ddH2O and bring to 50 ml total volume
Stock #6: - 0.35 g NaHCO3 - Dissolve in ddH2O and bring to 10.0 ml total volume


Hank’s Premix
Combine the following stock solutions in order: - 10.0 ml Stock #1 - 1.0 ml Stock #2 - 1.0 ml Stock #4 - 86.0 ml ddH2O - 1.0 ml Stock #5
Total volume: 99 ml






Note



Store Hank’s Premix in the refrigerator (4°C) along with the stock solutions.

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Procedure

To prepare final working Hank’s solution (10 ml):

Add 9.9 ml Hank’s Premix to a clean container
Add 0.1 ml Stock #6 (NaHCO3)
Mix thoroughly by swirling or gentle inversion
Use immediately or store at 4°C for short-term use



To scale for different volumes:

For each 1 ml final volume: use 0.99 ml Premix + 0.01 ml Stock #6
For 50 ml: use 49.5 ml Premix + 0.5 ml Stock #6
For 100 ml: use 99 ml Premix + 1 ml Stock #6

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Storage
Stock Solutions: - Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator) - Duration: Stable for 2-3 months - Container: Glass bottles with tight-sealing lids - Label: Mark each stock with number, contents, date prepared
Hank’s Premix: - Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator) - Duration: Stable for 2-3 months - Container: Glass bottle with tight-sealing lid - Label: Mark as “Hank’s Premix” with date prepared
Final Hank’s Solution: - Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator) or use immediately - Duration: Use within 1-2 weeks - Container: Sterile bottle if needed for cell culture

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Quality Control

pH: Final solution should be approximately 7.2-7.4
Appearance: All solutions should be clear and colorless
Sterility: For cell/tissue culture, filter-sterilize (0.22 μm) or autoclave stocks before use
Verification: Check for precipitates before use; discard if cloudy







Usage Notes




Stock #6 (NaHCO3) is added last because it provides CO2 buffering
For best results, prepare final working solution fresh from premix
Solution can be warmed to room temperature or 37°C before use
Adjust pH if needed for specific applications

title: 87  Hank’s Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in tissue dissection and cell culture protocols
Alternative to Chapter 83 for certain applications
See cell culture and embryology protocols for specific uses

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text: Introduction

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Purpose: Recipe for Holtfreiter’s solution, a physiological saline solution used in amphibian and fish embryology
Procedure Type: recipe
Species:

Threespine stickleback, (Gasterosteus aculeatus)
Bay pipefish, (Syngnathus leptorhyncus)
Gulf pipefish (Syngnathus scovelli)

Author: Mark Currey
Date Created: March 07, 2024

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Materials

NaCl (sodium chloride)
KCl (potassium chloride)
CaCl2 (calcium chloride)
NaHCO3 (sodium bicarbonate)
Tris buffer (1 M, pH 7.4-8.0)
Nanopure water (npH2O)
1 liter glass bottle or flask
Analytical balance
Weigh boats or paper
Graduated cylinders
Stir bar and stir plate
pH meter or pH strips







Safety



PPE Required: Lab coat, safety glasses, and gloves when handling chemicals.
Handling: Calcium chloride is hygroscopic and can cause skin and eye irritation. Handle in well-ventilated area.

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Procedure
For 1 liter stock solution:

Add 750 ml of npH2O to a clean 1 liter glass bottle
Add the following reagents while stirring:

3.5 g NaCl
0.05 g KCl
0.1 g CaCl2
0.02 g NaHCO3

Stir until all solids are completely dissolved
Add 1.0 ml Tris buffer (1 M)
Bring to 1 liter total volume with npH2O
Mix thoroughly and check pH (should be approximately 7.4-7.8)
Transfer to labeled storage bottle







Note



Store at 4°C. This solution is similar to Chapter 83 but optimized for embryological work.

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Storage

Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator)
Duration: Stable for 2-3 months when stored properly
Container: Clean glass bottle with tight-sealing lid
Label: Mark with “Holtfreiter’s Solution”, date prepared, and storage temperature

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
pH: Should be approximately 7.4-7.8 (verify with pH meter)
Verification: Check for clarity before each use; discard if cloudy or contaminated
Sterility: For embryological work, solution can be filter-sterilized (0.22 μm) or autoclaved if needed







Usage Notes




Allow solution to warm to room temperature before use with embryos
Can be used for embryo rearing, tissue dissection, and other physiological procedures
Solution composition provides balanced osmolarity for developing embryos
For dilute Holtfreiter’s (often used in embryo studies), dilute stock 1:10 with npH2O

title: 88  Holtfreiter’s Solution
text:
Related Protocols

Used in embryo culture and manipulation protocols
Alternative to Chapter 83 and Chapter 87 for certain applications
See embryology and developmental biology protocols for specific uses

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text: Introduction

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making 50 ml of 2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20 wash buffer used in in situ hybridization protocols
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 5, 2024

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Solutions

20x SSC (5 ml)

Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores
SSC = Saline-Sodium Citrate buffer

Tween-20 (100 μl)

Located in the chemical cabinet on the “Oxidizers A-Z” shelf
Non-ionic detergent

Nanopure water (45 ml)

Located in the Nalgene at the north sink

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Materials

50 ml Falcon tube
Pipettes (1-5 ml and 100-200 μl)
Pipette tips
Graduated cylinder (optional)







Scaling



This recipe can be scaled proportionally: - For 100 ml: 10 ml 20x SSC + 200 μl Tween-20 + 90 ml water - For 200 ml: 20 ml 20x SSC + 400 μl Tween-20 + 180 ml water

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Procedure

Add 5 ml of 20x SSC to a clean 50 ml Falcon tube
Add 100 μl of Tween-20 to the tube






Note



Tween-20 is a very viscous solution, which can make it challenging to pipet. Push the pipette to the first stop, place the pipette tip in the Tween-20, and wait at least 10 seconds for the Tween-20 to fill the pipette tip. Due to its high viscosity, the Tween-20 will take longer to fill the pipette tip compared to less viscous liquids. Once the pipette tip is full, slowly dispense the Tween-20 into the tube.


Fill tube to 50 ml mark with nanopure water (approximately 45 ml)
Cap tube and mix thoroughly by inverting 10-15 times until solution is homogeneous

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature
Duration: Stable for 2-3 months at room temperature
Container: 50 ml Falcon tube or glass bottle with tight-sealing cap
Label: Mark with “2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20”, date prepared, and room temperature storage

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear and slightly viscous
Homogeneity: Should be well-mixed with no visible Tween-20 droplets
pH: Should be approximately 7.0 (inherited from SSC buffer)
Verification: Check that solution mixes evenly and shows no phase separation







Usage Notes




Used as a wash buffer in in situ hybridization protocols
Tween-20 reduces non-specific binding and surface tension
Always mix well before use as Tween-20 may settle slightly over time
Compatible with most nucleic acid hybridization procedures

title: 89  2x SSC, 0.2% Tween-20
text:
Related Protocols

Used in in situ hybridization wash steps
See molecular biology protocols for detailed applications
Related buffers: Chapter 93 (for different wash applications)

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text: Introduction
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making 10 ml of blocking buffer for in situ hybridizations to reduce non-specific antibody binding
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 5, 2024
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Solutions

Goat or sheep serum (200 μl) - 2% final concentration

Located in the “Pistol Frog Pond” freezer in 1.5 ml aliquots
Heat-inactivated serum preferred

BSA (0.02 g) - 0.2% final concentration

Bovine Serum Albumin, powder form
Located in the “Cruella Cooper” fridge in a white bottle with a red lid

Chapter 93 (10 ml)

Phosphate Buffered Saline with Tween-20
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Materials

15 ml plastic Falcon tube
Pipettes (200 μl and 1-10 ml)
Pipette tips
Analytical balance
Weigh paper or weigh boat







Note



Prepare fresh blocking buffer on the day of use for best results. For large-scale experiments, can be prepared the day before and stored at 4°C.
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Procedure

Remove one aliquot of goat or sheep serum from freezer and thaw at room temperature

Once melted and warmed to room temperature, flick the tube to mix and ensure the serum is homogenized

Add 200 μl of the goat or sheep serum to a clean 15 ml Falcon tube
Weigh 0.02 g of BSA powder using the analytical balance

Use clean weigh paper or weigh boat
Add the 0.02 g of BSA to the tube with serum

Fill tube to 10 ml mark with PBT (see Chapter 93)
Cap tube and mix thoroughly by inverting 15-20 times until BSA is completely dissolved

May take several minutes for BSA to fully dissolve
Can gently vortex if needed to speed dissolution

Check that solution is homogeneous with no visible BSA particles
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Storage

Temperature: 4°C (refrigerator)
Duration: Use within 24 hours for best results; maximum 2-3 days
Container: 15 ml Falcon tube with cap tightly sealed
Label: Mark with “Blocking Buffer”, date prepared, and expiration date
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear to slightly opalescent
Protein dissolution: No visible BSA particles should remain
Contamination check: Discard if solution becomes cloudy or shows signs of bacterial growth
Efficacy: Effective blocking reduces background staining in in situ hybridization







Usage Notes




Blocking buffer is used to pre-treat tissues before antibody incubation
Serum source (goat vs sheep) should match the host species of secondary antibody when possible
BSA provides additional protein to block non-specific binding sites
Typical blocking time is 1-2 hours at room temperature or 4°C
Can be scaled proportionally for larger or smaller volumes









Protein Handling



Gentle handling: Avoid creating foam when mixing (proteins can denature at air-water interface)
Temperature: Keep cold when not in use to prevent bacterial growth and protein degradation
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations
text:
Related Protocols

Used in in situ hybridization protocols
Requires Chapter 93 as base solution
See immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization protocols for detailed applications
crumbs: 90  Blocking Buffer for in situ Hybridizations

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text: Introduction
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making 200 ml of Fake Hyb, a simplified hybridization buffer used in in situ hybridization protocols
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 5, 2024







Safety Warning



CRITICAL: All steps involving formamide must be performed in a chemical fume hood.
Chemical Hazards: Formamide is a developmental toxicant and may cause reproductive harm. It is irritating to skin, eyes, and respiratory system.
Required PPE: - Nitrile gloves - Safety glasses or goggles - Lab coat - Work in fume hood at all times
Disposal: Formamide waste must be disposed of as hazardous chemical waste. Never pour down drain. Follow institutional chemical waste disposal procedures.
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Solutions

100% formamide (100 ml)

Located in the “Cruella Cooper” refrigerator
Deionized formamide preferred

10x SSC (50 ml)

Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores
Saline-Sodium Citrate buffer

Tween-20 (400 μl)

Located in the chemical cabinet on the “Oxidizers A-Z” shelf
Non-ionic detergent

Citric acid powder (0.35 g)

Located in the chemical cabinet on the “Acid and Base Incompatibles A-Z” shelf
Used for pH adjustment

Nanopure water (to 200 ml)

Located in the Nalgene at the north sink
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Materials

200 ml glass Pyrex jar or beaker
4 × 50 ml plastic Falcon tubes (for aliquoting)
Pipettes (1-100 ml and 100-1000 μl)
Pipette tips
Fume hood
Analytical balance
Weigh paper or weigh boat
Graduated cylinder
Stir bar and stir plate (optional)
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Procedure






Critical Warning



WORK IN FUME HOOD FOR ENTIRE PROCEDURE
Formamide vapors are hazardous. Keep all containers in fume hood until sealed.



Warm the 100% formamide to room temperature in the fume hood

Allow at least 1-2 hours for warming
Do not heat; allow to warm naturally

In fume hood, add 100 ml of 100% formamide to the 200 ml glass Pyrex jar
Add 50 ml of 10x SSC to the jar
Add 400 μl Tween-20 to the jar






Note



Tween-20 is a very viscous solution, which can make it challenging to pipet. Push the pipette to the first stop, place the pipette tip in the Tween-20, and wait at least 10 seconds for the Tween-20 to fill the pipette tip. Due to its high viscosity, the Tween-20 will take longer to fill the pipette tip compared to less viscous liquids. Once the pipette tip is full, slowly dispense the Tween-20 into the jar.
Alternative: If pipetting 400 μl of Tween-20 is too difficult, make a 20% Tween-20 dilution (mix 1 ml Tween-20 with 4 ml nanopure water), and add 2 ml of the 20% Tween-20 to the jar.


Weigh out 0.35 g of citric acid powder using the analytical balance and add to the jar

Citric acid helps maintain proper pH for hybridization

Add nanopure water to bring total volume to 200 ml
Mix the solution thoroughly by swirling or gentle stirring

If using stir bar, stir for 5-10 minutes to ensure complete mixing
Solution should be homogeneous

In fume hood, aliquot the Fake Hyb into 4 × 50 ml Falcon tubes

Each tube will contain approximately 50 ml
Cap tubes tightly while still in fume hood

Label tubes clearly with “Fake Hyb”, date prepared, and hazard warnings
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Storage

Temperature: -20°C (freezer)
Duration: Stable for 6-12 months when frozen
Container: 50 ml Falcon tubes with tight-sealing caps
Label: Must include “Fake Hyb”, “FORMAMIDE - TOXIC”, date prepared
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Usage Instructions

When ready to use, remove one 50 ml tube from freezer
Thaw in water bath (37°C) or at room temperature in fume hood
Once melted, mix thoroughly by inversion to ensure solution is homogeneous
Use appropriate volume for in situ hybridization protocol
Return unused portion to -20°C freezer immediately after use







Freeze-Thaw Cycles



Minimize freeze-thaw cycles. Aliquoting into smaller volumes (e.g., 15 ml tubes) may be preferable for frequent use.
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Solution should be clear to slightly viscous
pH: Should be approximately 6.0-6.5 (citric acid provides slight acidity)
Homogeneity: No phase separation or precipitates
Efficacy: Effective hybridization buffer for RNA and DNA probes in in situ protocols







Usage Notes




“Fake Hyb” refers to simplified hybridization buffer without heparin and tRNA
Used for whole-mount in situ hybridization of embryos and tissues
Formamide prevents non-specific hybridization and allows lower temperature hybridization
Typical hybridization temperature: 55-70°C depending on probe
Always handle in fume hood, even after freezing
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)
text:
Related Protocols

Used in in situ hybridization protocols
See molecular biology protocols for detailed hybridization procedures
Related to Chapter 89 for wash buffers used with this hybridization buffer
crumbs: 91  Fake Hyb (Hybridization Buffer without Heparin/tRNA)

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text: Introduction

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making 25 ml of NTMT buffer (NaCl-Tris-MgCl2-Tween) used in alkaline phosphatase detection reactions for in situ hybridization
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 5, 2024

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Solutions

5 M NaCl (0.5 ml)

Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores
Final concentration: 100 mM

1 M MgCl2 (1.25 ml)

Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores
Final concentration: 50 mM

1 M Tris pH 9.5 (2.5 ml)

Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores
Final concentration: 100 mM
High pH is critical for alkaline phosphatase activity

20% Tween-20 (62.5 μl)

Located in the chemical cabinet on the “Oxidizers A-Z” shelf
Final concentration: 0.05%

Nanopure water (to 25 ml)

Located in the Nalgene at the north sink

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Materials

50 ml Falcon tube (or 25 ml tube)
Pipettes (100 μl, 1 ml, and 5 ml)
Pipette tips
Graduated cylinder (optional)







Scaling



This recipe can be scaled proportionally: - For 50 ml: 1.0 ml 5M NaCl + 2.5 ml 1M MgCl2 + 5.0 ml 1M Tris + 125 μl 20% Tween-20 + water to 50 ml - For 100 ml: 2.0 ml 5M NaCl + 5.0 ml 1M MgCl2 + 10.0 ml 1M Tris + 250 μl 20% Tween-20 + water to 100 ml

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Procedure

Add 0.5 ml of 5 M NaCl to a clean 50 ml Falcon tube
Add 1.25 ml of 1 M MgCl2 to the tube
Add 2.5 ml of 1 M Tris pH 9.5 to the tube
Add 62.5 μl of 20% Tween-20 to the tube






Note



Tween-20 is a very viscous solution, which can make it challenging to pipet. Push the pipette to the first stop, place the pipette tip in the Tween-20, and wait at least 10 seconds for the Tween-20 to fill the pipette tip. Due to its high viscosity, the Tween-20 will take longer to fill the pipette tip compared to less viscous liquids. Once the pipette tip is full, slowly dispense the Tween-20 into the tube.


Fill tube to 25 ml mark with nanopure water (approximately 20.7 ml)
Cap tube and mix thoroughly by inverting 10-15 times until solution is homogeneous

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature or 4°C
Duration: Stable for 2-3 months at room temperature; 3-6 months at 4°C
Container: 50 ml Falcon tube or glass bottle with tight-sealing cap
Label: Mark with “NTMT Buffer”, date prepared, and storage conditions

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Quality Control

pH: Should be 9.5 ± 0.1 (critical for alkaline phosphatase activity)
Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
Verification: Verify pH with pH meter if critical application
Efficacy: Proper NTMT buffer should support strong alkaline phosphatase color development







pH Critical



Important: The pH 9.5 is essential for optimal alkaline phosphatase enzyme activity. Do not substitute with Tris at different pH. If pH drifts below 9.3, prepare fresh buffer.








Usage Notes




NTMT buffer is used immediately before alkaline phosphatase color development reaction
Provides optimal pH and salt conditions for NBT/BCIP or other AP substrates
Mg2+ is a required cofactor for alkaline phosphatase activity
Tween-20 reduces background and surface tension
Equilibrate to room temperature before use
Used after antibody detection steps in in situ hybridization protocols

title: 92  NTMT Buffer
text:
Related Protocols

Used in in situ hybridization color development steps
Essential buffer for alkaline phosphatase-based detection
Used with NBT/BCIP or other chromogenic AP substrates
See in situ hybridization protocols for detailed usage

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text: Introduction

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Purpose: Recipe for making 500 ml of PBT (Phosphate Buffered Saline with Tween-20), a versatile wash buffer used in immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 5, 2024

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Solutions

10x PBS (50 ml)

Phosphate Buffered Saline, pH 7.4
Purchase pre-made from Chem Stores

Nanopure water (450 ml)

Located in the Nalgene at the north sink

Tween-20 (1 ml)

Non-ionic detergent
Located in the chemical cabinet on the “Oxidizers A-Z” shelf
Final concentration: 0.2% (v/v)

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Materials

500 ml glass Pyrex jar or bottle
Pipettes (1 ml and 50 ml)
Pipette tips
Graduated cylinder







Scaling



This recipe can be scaled proportionally: - For 100 ml: 10 ml 10x PBS + 90 ml water + 200 μl Tween-20 - For 250 ml: 25 ml 10x PBS + 225 ml water + 500 μl Tween-20 - For 1 liter: 100 ml 10x PBS + 900 ml water + 2 ml Tween-20

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Procedure

Add 50 ml of 10x PBS to a clean 500 ml glass Pyrex jar
Add 450 ml of nanopure water to the jar

Mix gently to dilute PBS

Add 1 ml of Tween-20 to the jar






Note



Tween-20 is a very viscous solution, which can make it challenging to pipet. Push the pipette to the first stop, place the pipette tip in the Tween-20, and wait at least 10 seconds for the Tween-20 to fill the pipette tip. Due to its high viscosity, the Tween-20 will take longer to fill the pipette tip compared to less viscous liquids. Once the pipette tip is full, slowly dispense the Tween-20 into the jar.


Cap jar and mix thoroughly by swirling or gentle inversion

Invert 15-20 times to ensure Tween-20 is fully dispersed
Solution should be homogeneous

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature or 4°C
Duration: Stable for 2-3 months at room temperature; 3-6 months at 4°C
Container: 500 ml glass Pyrex jar or bottle with tight-sealing cap
Label: Mark with “PBT (1x PBS + 0.2% Tween-20)”, date prepared, and storage conditions

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Quality Control

pH: Should be approximately 7.4 (from PBS)
Appearance: Solution should be clear and colorless
Homogeneity: Should be well-mixed with no visible Tween-20 droplets or phase separation
Verification: Mix well before each use as Tween-20 may settle slightly over time







Usage Notes




PBT is a general-purpose wash buffer for reducing non-specific binding
Tween-20 (0.2%) reduces surface tension and helps prevent tissue/sample adhesion
Used extensively in immunostaining, antibody washes, and in situ hybridization
Can be used for washing embryos, tissues, and whole-mount specimens
Compatible with most antibodies and molecular biology applications
Mix well before each use









Sterility



For cell culture or sterile applications, PBT can be: - Filter-sterilized through 0.22 μm filter, or - Prepared using sterile PBS and water, adding Tween-20 aseptically

title: 93  PBT (PBS + Tween-20)
text:
Related Protocols

Used in immunohistochemistry protocols as wash buffer
Required for Chapter 90 (Blocking Buffer for in situ)
Used in in situ hybridization wash steps
General wash buffer for antibody-based detection methods
See molecular biology and histology protocols for detailed applications

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text: Introduction

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Purpose: Recipe for diluting 10x TBE and 10x TAE stock solutions to make working concentration electrophoresis buffers for agarose and polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis
Procedure Type: Recipe
Author: Micah Woods
Date Created: March 4, 2024







Buffer Selection



TBE (Tris-Borate-EDTA): Better buffering capacity, preferred for long runs and small DNA fragments. Common for polyacrylamide gels.
TAE (Tris-Acetate-EDTA): Lower buffering capacity but DNA elutes more easily. Preferred for large DNA fragments and DNA recovery from gels. Common for agarose gels.

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Solutions

If making TBE buffer dilution:

10x TBE stock (Tris-Borate-EDTA)
Located in the cabinet above the microwave
If none is available, obtain 2 liters of pre-made 10x TBE from Chem Stores

If making TAE buffer dilution:

10x TAE stock (Tris-Acetate-EDTA)
Located in the cabinet above the microwave
If none is available, obtain 2 liters of pre-made 10x TAE from Chem Stores

Nanopure water

Located in the Nalgene at the sink on the north end of the laboratory
If Nalgene is empty, refill using the Phillips Laboratory nanopure water dispenser located in Pacific 317

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Materials

Appropriate vessel for desired final volume:

Small volumes (100-500 ml): graduated cylinder or bottle
Medium volumes (1-5 L): glass bottle or carboy
Large volumes (20 L): 20 liter Nalgene (for 0.5x TBE)

Graduated cylinders for measuring stock and water
Funnel (for large volume preparations)







Note



If making 0.5x TBE buffer for large-scale gel electrophoresis, use the dedicated 20 liter Nalgene located at the sink at the south end of the laboratory.

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Common Dilutions
Most common working concentrations: - 0.5x - Standard for most agarose gel electrophoresis - 1x - Higher buffering capacity, used for some applications - 0.25x - Sometimes used for very large DNA fragments
Dilution calculations: - For 0.5x from 10x: Mix 1 part 10x stock + 19 parts water - For 1x from 10x: Mix 1 part 10x stock + 9 parts water - For 0.25x from 10x: Mix 1 part 10x stock + 39 parts water

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Procedure

Method 1: For 0.5x TBE Buffer (20 L) - Large Scale

Ensure the 20 liter Nalgene is completely empty and clean
Fill the Nalgene with 19 liters of nanopure water

The 19 liter mark is marked in Sharpie on the Nalgene

Add 1 liter of 10x TBE stock

The 20 liter mark is marked in Sharpie on the Nalgene

Cap and mix thoroughly by inverting or swirling

May need to mix several times over 5-10 minutes




Method 2: For Custom Concentrations and Volumes

Calculate volumes needed:

Use dilution formula: C₁V₁ = C₂V₂
C₁ = initial concentration (10x)
V₁ = volume of stock needed
C₂ = final concentration (0.5x, 1x, etc.)
V₂ = final volume desired

Example: For 1 liter of 0.5x TBE:

10x × V₁ = 0.5x × 1000 ml
V₁ = 50 ml of 10x TBE
Water needed = 1000 ml - 50 ml = 950 ml

Prepare buffer:

Add calculated volume of 10x TBE or TAE stock to vessel
Add calculated volume of nanopure water
Mix thoroughly

Verify preparation:

Check that final volume matches desired volume
Mix well to ensure homogeneous solution

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Storage

Temperature: Room temperature
Duration:

TBE: Stable for several months at room temperature
TAE: Stable for 1-2 months; longer storage may lead to precipitation

Container: Appropriate sized bottle or carboy with tight-sealing cap
Label: Mark with buffer type (TBE or TAE), concentration (0.5x, 1x, etc.), date prepared

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Quality Control

Appearance: Both buffers should be clear and colorless
pH:

TBE: pH approximately 8.3
TAE: pH approximately 8.5

Conductivity: Can verify dilution using conductivity meter if available
Performance: Buffer should support good DNA separation without smearing







Buffer Reuse



Important: Do not reuse electrophoresis buffers. Buffer ions become depleted during electrophoresis, reducing buffering capacity. Prepare fresh buffer for each run or set of runs.








Usage Notes




For agarose gels: Either 0.5x TBE or TAE works well; TAE is more common
For polyacrylamide gels: TBE is preferred
For DNA recovery: TAE is preferred (no borate to inhibit downstream enzymes)
Gel buffer matching: Always use same buffer in gel and running tank
Temperature: Allow buffer to equilibrate to room temperature before use
Buffer level: Ensure gel is completely submerged in buffer during electrophoresis

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Troubleshooting

Smearing bands: Buffer may be exhausted; prepare fresh
Poor resolution: Verify correct buffer concentration
TAE precipitate: Prepare fresh; old TAE can precipitate
Unusual migration: Check pH and buffer concentration

title: 94  TBE/TAE Buffer
text:
Related Protocols

Used in DNA/RNA agarose gel electrophoresis protocols
Used in polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis protocols
Essential for molecular cloning and PCR analysis
See gel electrophoresis protocols for detailed running conditions

title: Bioinformatic
text:
This ection of the book contains protocols for basic bioinformatic skills such as using our laboratory cluster ‘Genome’, as well as our account Nereus on the UO supercomputer Talapas.
Note that there are several appendices that contain greater details and training on things such as the use of command line, R and Python, markdown and literature programming, and documentation using Quarto and Jupyter notebooks.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 95  A field guide to base R
text:
Introduction
To finish off the programming section, we’re going to give you a quick tour of the most important base R functions that we don’t otherwise discuss in the book. These tools are particularly useful as you do more programming and will help you read code you’ll encounter in the wild.
This is a good place to remind you that the tidyverse is not the only way to solve data science problems. We teach the tidyverse in this book because tidyverse packages share a common design philosophy, increasing the consistency across functions, and making each new function or package a little easier to learn and use. It’s not possible to use the tidyverse without using base R, so we’ve actually already taught you a lot of base R functions: from library() to load packages, to sum() and mean() for numeric summaries, to the factor, date, and POSIXct data types, and of course all the basic operators like +, -, /, *, |, &, and !. What we haven’t focused on so far is base R workflows, so we will highlight a few of those in this chapter.
After you read this book, you’ll learn other approaches to the same problems using base R, data.table, and other packages. You’ll undoubtedly encounter these other approaches when you start reading R code written by others, particularly if you’re using StackOverflow. It’s 100% okay to write code that uses a mix of approaches, and don’t let anyone tell you otherwise!
In this chapter, we’ll focus on four big topics: subsetting with [, subsetting with [[ and $, the apply family of functions, and for loops. To finish off, we’ll briefly discuss two essential plotting functions.
crumbs: 95  A field guide to base R

title: 95  A field guide to base R
text:
Prerequisites
This package focuses on base R so doesn’t have any real prerequisites, but we’ll load the tidyverse in order to explain some of the differences.

library(tidyverse)
crumbs: 95  A field guide to base R

title: 95  A field guide to base R
text:
Selecting multiple elements with [
[ is used to extract sub-components from vectors and data frames, and is called like x[i] or x[i, j]. In this section, we’ll introduce you to the power of [, first showing you how you can use it with vectors, then how the same principles extend in a straightforward way to two-dimensional (2d) structures like data frames. We’ll then help you cement that knowledge by showing how various dplyr verbs are special cases of [.

Subsetting vectors
There are five main types of things that you can subset a vector with, i.e., that can be the i in x[i]:

A vector of positive integers. Subsetting with positive integers keeps the elements at those positions:

x <- c("one", "two", "three", "four", "five")
x[c(3, 2, 5)]

[1] "three" "two"   "five" 


By repeating a position, you can actually make a longer output than input, making the term “subsetting” a bit of a misnomer.

x[c(1, 1, 5, 5, 5, 2)]

[1] "one"  "one"  "five" "five" "five" "two" 


A vector of negative integers. Negative values drop the elements at the specified positions:

x[c(-1, -3, -5)]

[1] "two"  "four"


A logical vector. Subsetting with a logical vector keeps all values corresponding to a TRUE value. This is most often useful in conjunction with the comparison functions.

x <- c(10, 3, NA, 5, 8, 1, NA)

# All non-missing values of x
x[!is.na(x)]

[1] 10  3  5  8  1

# All even (or missing!) values of x
x[x %% 2 == 0]

[1] 10 NA  8 NA


Unlike filter(), NA indices will be included in the output as NAs.
A character vector. If you have a named vector, you can subset it with a character vector:

x <- c(abc = 1, def = 2, xyz = 5)
x[c("xyz", "def")]

xyz def 
  5   2 


As with subsetting with positive integers, you can use a character vector to duplicate individual entries.
Nothing. The final type of subsetting is nothing, x[], which returns the complete x. This is not useful for subsetting vectors, but as we’ll see shortly, it is useful when subsetting 2d structures like tibbles.
crumbs: 95  A field guide to base R

title: 95  A field guide to base R
text:
Summary
In this chapter, we’ve shown you a selection of base R functions useful for subsetting and iteration. Compared to approaches discussed elsewhere in the book, these functions tend to have more of a “vector” flavor than a “data frame” flavor because base R functions tend to take individual vectors, rather than a data frame and some column specification. This often makes life easier for programming and so becomes more important as you write more functions and begin to write your own packages.
This chapter concludes the programming section of the book. You’ve made a solid start on your journey to becoming not just a data scientist who uses R, but a data scientist who can program in R. We hope these chapters have sparked your interest in programming and that you’re looking forward to learning more outside of this book.
crumbs: 95  A field guide to base R

title: Appendix B — Gel electrophoresis tips
text:
Introduction
The effect of electrophoresis is to separate DNA fragments by size in an agarose matrix and buffer using an electrical current. DNA is negatively charged and will migrate toward the positive pole. Many parameters can affect how the DNA moves through the gel: buffer composition, voltage, length of the gel, percentage of agarose in the gel (in other words, the density of the gel matrix), presence of salt in the DNA, protein bound to DNA, and other factors. Some of these conditions also affect which size ranges of DNA will effectively be “resolved” (i.e., separated enough from one another so you can see them as distinct fragment sizes). “Safeview” is a dye we use in the gel that fluoresces under UV or blue light when bound to DNA, allowing us to see and photograph it when viewed through a special orange filter to cut out the background light. The research goals of using electrophoresis might include:

title: Appendix B — Gel electrophoresis tips
text:
Purpose: To help members of the laboratory run the perfect gels - every time.
Procedure Type: Molecular
Species: N/A
Authors

Susan Bassham




measuring the size of fragments in a DNA sample such as the products of PCR or assessing the intactness of the purified DNA from a tissue extraction
separating fragments from one another so that a particular amplicon or size range of DNA can be purified out of the gel for other downstream applications (such as for cloning a PCR fragment for making probes or for Sanger sequencing, or for size selecting a smear of fragments for making a RAD library) while excluding the other fragment sizes
checking for the presence or absence of a particular product of PCR as in a screen for orientation of a cloned fragment in a plasmid present in different bacterial colonies, a screen for an insertion in a transgenic animal, a screen to determine the genetic sex or the mitotype of a fish.

title: Appendix B — Gel electrophoresis tips
text:
Common Mistakes






Warning



These common mistakes will give you a big headache when trying to run gels



Boiling over the agarose when making a gel.

Result: failure to monitor the agarose when you are trying to dissolve it in the microwave can easily cause it to boil over because powdered substances create a lot of “nodes of nucleation” for bubbles to form. This is especially easy to accidentally do with higher percentages of agarose. It wastes expensive agarose and creates a mess in the microwave. What remains in the bottle will be of an indeterminate percentage/gel stiffness.

Not making sure the tape is adhering well to the mold before casting a gel.

Result: liquid agarose will leak out causing a mess and reagent waste. Make sure the mold is dry beforehand, and use the back edge of a comb, e.g., to run across the tape and make sure it has firm contact.

Positioning the comb teeth too close to one side or to the bottom of the mold when setting up for pouring a gel.

Result: the bottoms (or that side) of wells may be torn when the comb is pulled out, causing the loaded samples to leak out into the buffer during gel loading. Note: even when the comb teeth are not too close to the bottom, low percentage gels are soft and will benefit from having the comb pulled while submerged in the tank - otherwise the suction created by surface tension between the comb plastic and the agarose as you pull up on the comb can tear the bottoms out of the wells, causing loss of samples during loading.

Not using the right % of agarose for your DNA size range of interest.

Result: bands you care about won’t resolve optimally (i.e., you might not be able to accurately measure the sizes of your bands and might not be able to tell if something is one band or multiple bands). Pour a higher percentage gel to resolve large fragments (e.g. less than 1%) or a lower percentage gel (i.e. between 1 and 4%) to resolve small to very small ones, depending on your needs/expectations for what size bands you will see, how many of them, or how important it is to accurately estimate their sizes.

Not homogeneously mixing the Safeview into the agarose before pouring.

Result: DNA might not be visible in all parts of the gel.

Over-cooling the agarose before pouring.

Result: Safeview will not be evenly distributed in the gel, and/or the gel have lumps and not be of uniform thickness because some of the agarose will have already started polymerizing.

Running a gel with a lot of bubbles in it.

Result: DNA migration can be impeded/distorted by bubbles in the gel. Usually as a gel is cooling, bubbles will migrate to the top where (usually) they will be out of the path of the DNA unless the DNA volume fills the wells to the top. But bubbles can sometimes occur deeper in the gel – particularly in a very high % agarose gel. Try to nudge bubbles out of the way before the gel solidifies, either by raking them with a comb that is not on a holder or nudging individual bubbles with a pipette tip before the gel congeals. If the gel is already solid, avoid loading in lanes that will run across a bubble.

Running a gel that wasn’t mixed homogeneously before pouring in the mold.

Result: there will be lumps in the gel of more dense agarose that will cause distortion of how the DNA migrates.

Accidentally contacting the agarose with a pipette tip.

Result: the bottom or side of the well can become perforated, causing the sample to leak out the bottom or into the next well. If the tip is pressed against the agarose, the sample can be forcefully and suddenly expelled and blast out of the well.

Overloading the wells with too much sample volume.

Result: samples can become cross-contaminated by DNA from adjacent wells.

Overloading the lane with too much DNA.

Result: DNA can become retarded during running and the apparent size will not be accurately gauged by the ladder.

Forgetting to load a DNA ladder.

Result: you won’t know if your DNA bands are the right size when you look at and photograph your gel.

Not using gel loading mix in the DNA or using ladder that isn’t premixed with gel loading mix.

Result: The DNA or ladder (which is also DNA) will be lost mostly during loading without the gel loading mix that makes it sink to the bottom of the wells in the gel and stay there while you are loading. Both your samples and the ladder are DNA in an aqueous solution that is about the same density as the buffer (usually) – therefore they both should have gel loading mix in them in order to be denser than the tank buffer. The gel loading mix also includes convenient, charged dyes that migrate at different rates to help you see that your gel is running and how far it has progressed. The gel loading mix types only really matter if one type happens to have a dye that migrates exactly like your band of interest - in that case, you may want to switch to a different mix so that the dye doesn’t block the fluorescence of your band during visualization.

Not thoroughly mixing gel loading mix into your DNA before loading.

Result: you could lose part of your DNA to floating out of the well during loading. (This can also happen if there are other reasons your DNA is not very dense, such as if there is residual ethanol in it from preceding processing. In that case, you will see your DNA rapidly floating up to the surface as soon as you start expelling it from the tip).

Adding premixed DNA ladder to your samples instead of gel loading mix.

Result: ladder will appear in every lane, obscuring your bands and wasting expensive ladder.

Forgetting to start the current on your loaded gel.

Result: DNA will diffuse both out of the wells and into the gel in all directions causing loss of some of the DNA and blurriness of the remaining DNA once the gel is run. Diffusion can also happen if it takes a long time to load the gel. If there are a great number of samples to load – such as in a two- or three-comb gel, it is often best to load one tier and run the gel for 5 minutes so the DNA enters the gel and diffuses more slowly before moving on to load the next tier. Diffusion can happen more quickly if the buffer is warm from a previous run. If the buffer is warm, replace it before trying to load another gel in the same box.

Not keeping track of the order of sample loading.

Result: you won’t know which lane corresponds to which sample. This can happen, for example, when loading samples from a strip of PCR tubes, where their order can accidentally be rotated 180 degrees, or when loading from a PCR plate, where the plate orientation can be rotated 180 or 90 degrees (e.g., wells are loaded with respect to rows versus columns).

Running your gel backwards by accidentally reversing the positive and negative electrodes.

Result, your DNA will migrate out of the end of the gel nearest the wells (the “top” of the gel) and be lost into the tank buffer. Always check that your electrodes are hooked up to the correct leads relative to the terminals at the power source, that your gel is oriented so that the DNA will run toward the positive pole. If you have already loaded your gel in the wrong orientation, do not lift the gel out of the tank, but just reverse the leads (red to black) to correct the current. Remember that DNA is negatively charged and will run to the positive (red) pole. When you start the current, the negative electrode (anode) at the well end of the gel should be making noticeably more bubbles than the positive electrode (cathode) at the bottom end of the gel. That’s because electrolysis of water (H2O) will produce twice as much free hydrogen at the anode than the cathode makes free oxygen. Making a habit of checking that tells you two things: that current is really flowing and that you do have the right orientation of poles.

Running a gel at too low a voltage.

Result: low molecular weight bands may look fuzzy and faint because they will be diffusing in random directions as they migrate.

Running DNA that is too salty - e.g., DNA in Phusion buffer or in NEB restriction buffer 3 (or 3.1) etc.

Result: a “salt front” will form where DNA in those salty buffers will be slowed (“retarded”) relative to the ladder, making the ladder a useless measure of the actual size of the DNA. Bands will be compressed at a “front” and will be a weird shape like a smile or a frown rather than a straight band.
If you know your DNA is in a salty buffer, you can remove this problem by cleaning the DNA first (i.e., via a cleanup column or with paramagnetic beads), or you can mitigate the problem by diluting only a few microliters (e.g. 5 µl) of your DNA into water and gel loading mix before loading (assuming you have a high enough concentration of DNA that it can still be seen if you load only a small fraction of it).

Running a gel made up in a different buffer (or different concentration of buffer) than the buffer in the gel tank; this includes using old buffer that has been evaporating in the tank through multiple runs or over time.

Result: bands will not migrate as expected. “Fronts” may form where the leading edge of the migrating DNA is compressed.

Losing your gel of the end of the gel mold when you are taking it out of the tank.

Result: the gel could shatter and be unsalvageable. Solution: transport gels in a dish and be especially careful when moving flabby, low percentage agarose gels (under 1%).

title: Appendix B — Gel electrophoresis tips
text:
Potentially dangerous and/or destructive mistakes:






Warning



Running gels is so standard in a laboratory that we can take if for granted, but these mistakes can be costly in terms of ruining a gel at best, or posing human safety risks at worst



Heating a bottle with a lid on it.

Result: possible explosion. Just leave the lid off when heating agarose.

Adding Safeview to molten agarose that is too hot.

Result: much of the Safeview will be degraded by heat, causing your DNA to be hard to see or image. The plastic gel mold could be permanently warped if the agarose is too hot. The tape may fail, causing a mess in the fume hood and reagent wastage. A swirled bottle should be just comfortable (70 degrees C or a bit less).

Running a gel at too high a voltage.

Result: buffer could overheat during running and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box. Bands might look smear and not be well resolved.

Dissolving agarose in water instead of electrophoresis buffer or putting water in the electrophoresis tank instead of buffer.

Result - total failure for DNA to migrate into the gel, loss of samples. If there is only water and not buffer in the tank, it could overheat and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box.

Over-running your gel.

Result: the DNA might run off the bottom of the gel and be lost. If you had more than one tier of wells in the gel, the DNA in the top tier will run into the zone of the next tier down, causing distortion and blurriness of the bands as they cross the wells of the lower tier and creating confusion in interpretation because very small fragments from the top tier will be overlapping very large fragments of the lower tier. If the gel runs for a long time, the buffer could overheat and permanently warp the plastic of the gel box.

title: Appendix B — Gel electrophoresis tips
text:
Conscietiousness






Warning



We all work in our laboratory together. Please think of your labmates when you are done running your gel.


Please really clean the gel molds and combs after use. The next person shouldn’t have to fish another lab mate’s combs and molds out of the sink and clean and dry them before they can pour their gel. After pulling combs from a polymerized gel, make sure to really rub them under a flow of water; a skin of polymerized agarose left on the combs (higher percentages of agarose are especially prone to this) will mean the next person has to clean this off before they can pour a gel. Likewise, make sure the gel melting bottle is rinsed immediately after you pour your gel. If residual agarose is allowed to dry in the bottle, it can create an almost insoluble blob in the gel of the next person to use the bottle. If you see that some of your agarose has polymerized in the bottle, add water to the bottle and microwave it for a few minutes to dissolve and discard the residue.
